Nevertheless, if your son's condition doesn't improve or worsens after few days of administering these medicines, I advise you revisit your pediatrician. They may reassess the situation and consider starting antibiotics if necessary. Also, make sure your kid rests and gets plenty of fluids.

input: Hello doctor,My vision was crystal clear this morning. I just woke up from a nap, and the vision in my left eye is blurry. It has not cleared up in the past half an hour. Twice over the years, this has happened, and it normalized over a few hours, but I am in a jungle now. So, I would like to err on the side of caution. I have had previous retinal detachments.
output:
Sudden blurred vision in one eye could be a serious medical emergency considering your history of retinal detachments. Though it has resolved on its own in the past, you shouldn’t rely on this happening again. The symptoms can indicate various conditions from less dangerous like dry eyes or refractive errors to potentially more severe conditions such as optic neuritis, macular degeneration, but in your case, it might signal a retinal detachment which is a significant concern and needs an immediate evaluation by an eye specialist.

Without having proper tools and clinical examination at hand I advise you to protect your vision by lowering physical activity, avoid bending down and certainly no heavy lifting. Keep your head up, at heart level generally. Do not rub your eyes too. 

I would strongly advise that you seek urgent professional medical assistance as soon as possible if you are able to leave the jungle or perhaps there's any possibility of communicating with services that may assist you in reaching a hospital urgently. It should not be taken lightly given your medical history and current context.

input: Hello doctor,Last night, I fell from my bike on my right side as it got slipped while driving. My right hand and right shoulder directly hit the road and cause severe pain on the right side of the abdomen. A local doctor prescribed some medicine and I got relieved from my side pain. I went for an x-ray of the right chest, it was normal. But after 36 hours I am having pain in the right shoulder (scapula) and while sitting, or arising out of bed, or moving hand on the upper side the pain increases a lot. Is it normal or need better medical assistance?
output:
Pain after a fall like yours is certainly not unusual. You may have bruised or strained the muscles and tissues around your right shoulder and scapula, which would explain the pain you're feeling, especially when moving in certain ways. 

However, given that the pain appears to be worsening or at least persisting after 36 hours, it's prudent to seek further medical evaluation. This could signify something more serious, such as a fracture which might not have been apparent on an X-ray at first due to swelling or inflammation, or a rotator cuff injury which would require specific physical therapy or possibly surgery.

Even if there is no major damage, seeing a doctor could provide peace of mind and possible pain relief strategies such as physiotherapy or targeted exercises. Please get some professional help with this, particularly if the pain continues to increase or does not improve with rest and over-the-counter pain medications.

Also, consider watching for any signs of nerve injury such as weakness, numbness or tingling in your arm or hand. Seek immediate medical assistance if you notice such symptoms.

input: Hi doctor,My lab tests are as follows:Seven months ago: blood glucose of 105 mg/dl, GTT one hour 160 mg/dl, two hours 118 mg/dl, morning insulin 6.2 \xce\xbcU/ml, HbA1c 5.2 %, A1 6.1 %. This month: BG 110 mg/dl, GTT one hour 184 mg/dl, two hours 115 mg/dl, morning insulin 5.3 \xce\xbcU/ml. Every other blood test within normal ranges. I am male 32 years old 1.86 cm 93 kg 13 to 14 % body fat athletic with healthy nutrition habits. No history of diabetes in the family. Could I be having cancer in pancreas judging from the insulin values you are seeing? I have had many years to do a blood test and with this random one seven months ago. I was told by my doctor that I had to keep monitoring my blood glucose since I could develop diabetes later on, and since I have never had a problem with blood sugar as a kid and no family history of diabetes, I was wondering what might be going on cause insulin levels dropped from my last test and since my diet was pretty much same with healthy choices why is this happening. My doctor for the last seven months kept telling me to calm down and that I do not have anything cause stressing is bad for my blood glucose too. Should I be telling him to get a pancreas MRI done?
output:
Based on your lab results, it seems like you're showing signs of impaired glucose tolerance. Your recent blood glucose test shows that after drinking a sugar drink, your blood glucose is higher than normal but not enough to be classified as diabetes.

This could be an indicator for prediabetes - a condition where blood glucose level is higher than normal but not high enough to diagnose type 2 diabetes. Prediabetes can progress into type 2 diabetes, and weight loss through healthy eating and exercise can halt or reverse this progression.

Your insulin levels are within the standard range, albeit toward the lower end. A gradual decline in insulin levels may suggest your pancreas isn't producing as much insulin, although this can also be due to several other factors including diet, stress, sleep etc. 

Having said this, these lab results do not point towards a diagnosis of pancreatic cancer. Pancreatic cancer symptoms usually include abdominal pain, unexplained weight loss, yellowing of skin and eyes (jaundice) among others, which you have not reported here. However, if you are still concerned it's always good to discuss with your doctor about your worries.

Please note that simply having low insulin does not mean one has pancreatic cancer. Also, MRI should only be ordered when there is a substantial reason or suspicion based on multiple indicators, not merely what might seem as mild changes in insulin levels. This radiological examination comes with its own set of risks and shouldn't be used as first-line diagnostics without proper indications.

input: Hi doctor,I have noticed that my first molar is loose. I keep pushing it with my tongue and clenching a bit against it and I just noticed that it has become loose little more. I have my wisdom teeth and I think it might be applying pressure forward on these teeth. I read in a book that day grinding can cause a teeth to loosen, which is easier to treat. There is no pain and the teeth look healthy. I always clench my teeth but it never caused any looseness.
output:
Your symptoms suggest that you may have bruxism or teeth grinding, which could be causing your loose molar. Pressure from wisdom teeth can also contribute to the problem. It's good news that there's no pain and the tooth appears healthy visually.

However, a loose tooth is not something you should ignore. The mobility could increase over time, potentially risking your oral health. Proactive steps should be taken to prevent further loosening.

You should make an appointment with your dentist as soon as possible. They might recommend a night guard to protect your teeth if you grind or clench at night. If the pressure from your wisdom teeth is contributing to the problem, you may need to have them removed.

In the meantime, avoid putting extra pressure on the tooth - try not to push it further with your tongue or chew on that side of your mouth. Follow an effective plaque control regime: brush gently twice a day and floss daily to maintain good oral hygiene. This won't treat the looseness but will help prevent further damage.

input: Hello doctor,We have a 9-month-old baby girl. She has five brown marks, two of them are 2 cm size and the other three of 0.5 cm. They are irregular in shape. Initial two marks appeared when she was 3 months old and now when she is 9 months three more for added that are comparatively light and 0.5 cm of size. Are these birthmarks? Will they fade with the time? Do we need to take any precautions so that they do not increase or get added further? Can we also provide any medication to cure them?
output:
Your baby might have what we call congenital melanocytic nevi. These are essentially birthmarks that can vary in size and color, often brown, and generally appear at birth or soon afterward. While the exact cause isn't determined, they're thought to form as a result of skin cells failing to grow normally during their development.

Most of these marks are harmless and do not require treatment. They may fade or darken with age, but typically they do not completely disappear. A small number of these nevi have an elevated risk for becoming cancerous later in life, especially large ones.

You should consult your pediatrician or a dermatologist who can examine them closely. If there is any concern regarding changes in shape, size, or color, they might advise regular monitoring or even a biopsy in some cases. However, with the sizes you mentioned, it's less likely.

There is no specific medication to cure them, as they are benign skin lesions. It would be best not to avoid sun exposure and apply sunscreen on your child if she's out in the sun.

Remember, this advice doesn't substitute a proper consultation. It's always better to get her examined by a professional healthcare provider.

input: Hello doctor,I have red raised rashes in my legs and arms. I used Hydrocortisone cream, but there are no changes in it. Please help.
output:
Without being able to see the rash, I can only provide a general advice. You may be dealing with some type of dermatitis, psoriasis or possibly an allergic reaction. The fact that Hydrocortisone Cream hasn't helped might suggest this rash isn't completely responsive to steroids, or it may simply mean that you need something stronger. It's also possible that it's infected, in which case a topical antibiotic could be needed.

Always remember to avoid scratching the area as much as possible. If itch is a problem, antihistamines such as Benadryl might help though they can cause drowsiness. 

However, given that there has been no improvement thus far, I strongly recommend that you make an appointment with a dermatologist for a physical examination as soon as possible so you can get a firm diagnosis and treatment plan. Keep in mind that this advice is intended to be general in nature, and specific causes may need targeted treatments.

input: Hello doctor, I have been going to a dentist about a tooth that is sore. They started a root canal but then did not finish. I have gone back several times and every time they open up the tooth and insert medicine. My tooth is in agony right now. I am just wondering if this is a standard procedure during a root canal? Should not the dentist remove the nerves so I am not in so much pain? Or is it the standard procedure to fight the infection first and then remove the nerves?
output:
Generally, a root canal treatment involves creating an opening in the tooth to reach and remove the infected pulp (which is comprised of nerves, blood vessels, and connective tissues), then cleaning and shaping the inside of the root canals, followed by filling and sealing the space. This procedure usually eliminates the pain you're experiencing as with the pulp removed, there are no more nerves in that tooth to transmit pain signals.

However, sometimes if there's a severe infection or abscess at the end of the roots of your tooth, your dentist might not complete the whole process in one visit. They may instead use a temporary filling material and place medication within the tooth to help with the inflammation and infection before completely removing the pulp and finishing the root canal. 

But continuous instances where the dentist re-opens the tooth and inserts medicine can also likely indicate complications or failure of the initial attempt at treating the tooth. One key point though - you should not be in "agony". Pain during a root canal is common but this should be manageable with over-the-counter analgesics, and should not extend for longer than a few days after each intervention.

In any case, persistent severe pain suggests something is not right. You may want to seek a second opinion from another dentist or consult with an endodontist (a specialist in root canal treatments) about your issue. Remember that all these suggestions are based on generic information and actual advice may vary depending upon various factors related to individual health conditions.

input: Hi doctor,I am 19 years old. I have pain in the corner of my left eye for the past one year. I went to the doctor, and he gave me Sterdex. I used it and felt better. My pain went away. After a few months, I started to have pain, but it was not so severe as the first time. I wear glasses and lenses, and I am treating my eye allergy with Chibro Cadron 5 ml, and for dry eyes, I use Fluidabak after taking the lens. Whenever I do my yearly eye checkup, my eyesight gets worse because of the pain in the corner, and I am scared about my sight. I do not know whether I use an appropriate medicine to my eye. Whenever I consult the doctor, he gives me the same medication. Please help me.
output:
It seems like you're dealing with recurrent eye pain which may be associated with prolonged use of contact lenses, dryness of the eyes, allergies or other underlying conditions. The medications you are using, Sterdex is a combination antibiotic and steroid used to treat inflammations in the eye, Chibro Cadron 5 ml is used for eye inflammation and Fluidabak is used to relieve symptoms of dry eyes.

Given your situation, I would advise a re-evaluation by an ophthalmologist. An eye exam including visual acuity test, slit lamp examination (a detailed view of the structures at the front of your eye), tonometry (check for glaucoma) and possibly a fundoscopy (examination of the back of your eye) will be required.

Suggestions:
1. Limit your usage of contact lenses
2. Maintain hygiene while handling lenses
3. Use artificial tears on a regular basis throughout the day.
4. Update eyeglasses prescription if needed and try using glasses more often than contacts.

Again, it's very important you seek a consultation with an ophthalmologist to review your medication and confirm there are no serious conditions associated with your recurring eye discomfort. It's critical that this gets addressed to prevent any potential long-term damage to your eyesight.

input: Hi doctor,I just had an EGD with biopsy, polypectomy. It showed a hianal hernia 2 cm. I am attaching photos. The doctor took biopsies, said no cancer. I have had breast cancer in the past. I am having pain in the chest when I swallow, and sternum today. Will that subside? Is it from the bleeding? And, can you recommend the best pill to take for this pain, taking Pantoprazole now? And what should I take for this problem, what should I eat? (Can you assure there is no cancer)?
output:
Unfortunately, as an AI, I cannot view physical attachments such as photographs. But based on the information you provided, it sounds like you might be experiencing some discomfort due to the EGD procedure itself; this is quite common in many patients and should subside over time. The chest pain when swallowing could be related to irritation caused by the endoscope or the polypectomy.

Regarding medication, Pantoprazole is a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) commonly used for conditions involving excess stomach acid, including hiatal hernias. This one should help with your symptoms. If the chest pain continues, I would recommend reaching out to your treating physician who might consider a short course of a mild painkiller if there are no contraindications. 

In terms of diet, eating smaller meals more frequently, reducing fatty and spicy foods, and avoiding lying down immediately after eating can all be beneficial in managing hiatal hernia symptoms.

About your cancer concern: if the doctor took biopsies during the EGD and confirmed no presence of cancer, that's very reassuring. However, keep in mind that your gastroenterologist knows your situation best. Considering your past history of breast cancer, continue following up regularly with both your primary care doctor and oncologist.

Remember, online advice does not substitute an office visit, so please reach out to your personal doctor regarding these issues.

input: Hello doctor,I am 29-years-old male. I am 173 cm in height and weighs about 68 kg. I would like to know about testosterone injection if I took it in a small dosage weekly will that help my appearance to be more manly? Even that my appearance is manly but in general my physical built is small compared to other men, my face, hands, legs are small also my voice is feminine.My testosterone level is good. My body is too hairy and I did a testosterone test everything was normal. I know there is a lot of studies that say that testosterone can lead to depression but actually at the age of 21 I was suffering from depression and I took testosterone for a month (to gain muscles), my mood was very good and it actually helped my depression. Also, my sexual life and erection are very good, I do masturbate once or twice every two days and I get an erection easily.Kindly help me with these questions:Will testosterone injections help me be more manly? What is the recommended dose that I have to take monthly? What are testosterone injections made from, are they made from an animal source? Will testosterone affects my personality? Do I have to take it for life? What if after some period I decided to stop will I loose what I gained?
output:
Testosterone is the primary male sex hormone that plays key roles in the development of male reproductive tissues such as testes and prostate, as well as promoting secondary sexual characteristics like increased muscle and bone mass, and body hair growth. However, the use of testosterone injection should ideally be for those diagnosed with low or no testosterone because its misuse can lead to serious side effects.

1. Testosterone could potentially make your appearance more "masculine" by increasing muscle mass and thickening your voice to some extent if it happens to be related to low testosterone levels.
2. Only a healthcare professional can advise on appropriate dosage based on individual health conditions and needs. Because your testosterone levels are normal, it's not advisable to take extra testosterone without medical consultation.
3. Testosterone used in injections isn't derived from animals; it's lab-synthesized to be bio-identical to human testosterone.
4. As for personality changes, testosterone may influence mood and might cause increased aggression or competitiveness, but there's variability in individuals' responses.
5. Unless you suffer from lifelong hypogonadism (where the body doesn't produce enough testosterone), you wouldn't necessarily need to take it for life. In fact, inappropriate usage can shut down your natural testosterone production, making you dependent on these injections for normal function.
6. If you discontinue the injections after a while, the newly acquired features might diminish over time.

Given your presented information - normal testosterone level & overall good health, self-administering

input: Hello doctor,Is there a difference in alcoholic and non-alcoholic mouthwash. Which is better at combating bad breath due to smoking than alcoholic? I am in a hygiene school and want to know whether or not to recommend non-alcohol mouthwash for the complaints of bad breath from smoking. I have recommended tongue scraping, alcoholic mouthwash. Anyways, they are not going to stop smoking or drinking. I was looking at a way to have them not dry out the tissues, but stopping the obvious factors do not seem to be an option.
output:
Both alcoholic and non-alcoholic mouthwashes are designed to kill bacteria in the mouth that cause bad breath, plaque, and gingivitis. However, they do vary slightly in their makeup and mode of action.

Alcohol-based mouthwash has a high alcohol content which can help it to penetrate oral biofilms better and kill bacteria effectively. In addition to killing bacteria, alcohol also acts as a carrier agent for essential active ingredients like menthol, eucalyptol, and thymol which helps them permeate plaque.

However, these alcohol-based mouthwashes can make the mouth dry by reducing saliva production over time. This can lead to more bad breath since saliva naturally counteracts bacteria and acid in the mouth. Alcohol can also irritate soft tissues in the mouth. 

Non-alcoholic mouthwash, on the other hand, often contains ingredients like cetylpyridinium chloride (CPC) that kill bacteria without drying out the mouth. It doesn't contain alcohol, so this type could be more comfortable for those with sensitive mouths. Many tend to prefer non-alcoholic mouthwash because they find it less harsh to swish around in their mouth.

Given your concern about dehydration of oral tissues from smoking and alcohol use, recommending non-alcoholic mouthwashes may be beneficial for your patients. They should, however, still complement this with good dental hygiene practices such as regular brushing and flossing and tongue scraping. It’s always best for an individual to consult with their dentist or hy

input: Hello doctor,I have been diagnosed with mild hereditary spherocytosis. My eyes still yellow. Is it unlikely hematologist who diagnosed me three years ago misdiagnosed? I do not doubt he knows his stuff. More about me getting worried. I lost weight a couple of months ago. I went very yellow in the eyes. I have always felt tired. I have had gallbladder out four years ago, I bruise easily, I do get little red skin dots at times, menstrual cycles can be irregular and spleen slightly enlarged.
output:
Patients diagnosed with hereditary spherocytosis typically exhibit a range of symptoms similar to yours, such as jaundice (yellowing of the eyes), fatigue, easy bruising, red blood dots (petechiae) and an enlarged spleen. These issues result from increased hemolysis or breakdown of red blood cells that are characteristic of this disease.

Weight loss is not directly associated with hereditary spherocytosis; however, it may be indirectly related due to decreased appetite caused by feelings of discomfort or chronic anemia-related fatigue. The irregular menstrual cycle might also be indirectly related through hormonal imbalance induced by stress and long-term illness.

The removal of your gallbladder probably was done because individuals with hereditary spherocytosis have a higher risk of developing gallstones.

It's normal to feel worried about a chronic health condition like this. I would advise you reach out to your hematologist and discuss these concerns. It can also help to keep track of your symptoms and bring up any changes during your appointments. With proper management, most people with this disease can lead normal lives while managing their symptoms. The possible misdiagnosis is unlikely given your listed symptoms are consistent with hereditary spherocytosis. However, if necessary, genetic testing can offer conclusive evidence of this diagnosis.

input: Hi doctor,My height is 5\4", and my weight is 61 kilogram. My ovary is bulky with right ovary volume 11.5 cc and left ovary volume 11.2 cc. I am suffering from PCOD. I am under treatment for the past three months. Can I get pregnant naturally?
output:
Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) can make it more difficult to become pregnant naturally because it may interfere with regular ovulation, which is necessary for conception. However, this does not mean it's impossible to get pregnant. Many women with PCOS have been able to conceive naturally or with the assistance of fertility treatments.

The fact that you are under treatment is positive, and often changes like eating a healthier diet, maintaining a healthy weight, and getting regular physical activity can improve your body's response to insulin and help reduce symptoms of PCOS, potentially aiding in natural fertility.

Also, medications like Clomiphene citrate or Metformin might be suggested by your doctor to stimulate ovulation if lifestyle changes aren't enough on their own. 

Remember to consistently keep in touch with your gynecologist about your concerns and progress. This discussion will assist them in determining the best course of action for your particular case. It's crucial to monitor your situation because each individual responds differently to treatment.

input: Hi doctor,I am suffering from an infection on my penis. I am using Clotrimazole cream over the infection. Once I miss applying cream a day, the penis gets infected with red patches, pus-filled boils and there is severe itching. My partner is not affected by any problem though we are sexually active. I am not diabetic when I saw my blood test. Kindly help me to cure it. I am frustrated with my problem. Kindly give me medical advice.
output:
I'm really sorry to hear about your condition. It sounds incredibly uncomfortable and distressing. A recurring infection of the kind you're describing could possibly be a yeast infection or balanitis, especially given that it seems to respond to Clotrimazole, which is an antifungal cream.

However, due to the recurrent and severe nature of your symptoms (red patches, pus-filled boils, severe itching), it would be advisable for you to see a healthcare professional in person - preferably a urologist or dermatologist. You may require stronger antifungal medication or antibiotics if there's also a bacterial infection, but this needs to be determined by a doctor who can examine the affected area and perhaps take a swab for testing.

In addition, even though you said your partner doesn't seem to be affected, they may still need to get checked just in case they're asymptomatic, meaning not showing any signs yet carrying the infection - because this particular infection can potentially be transmitted sexually.

Please use condoms until both of you are cleared from potential infectious causes to prevent passing the infection back and forth.

Do maintain good hygiene – clean the penis thoroughly but gently with lukewarm water every day. Do not use soap directly on the area as it can worsen the irritation. Dry it well before applying any cream. 

Remember, keep away from self-diagnosing or self-medicating. And although I've tried to give general advice based on your description, only a proper medical consultation can

input: Hello doctor,I wanted to know if you could answer one question for me. I experienced an episode that lasted roughly about two to three minutes where I felt that I could not seem to catch my breath and it felt as if my heart had stopped beating. I checked my heart rate roughly three minutes after the incident and it was at 60 bpm and my oxygen was at 99 % under two weeks ago. I had a routine 24 tape which was clear (ectopic beats picked up but were benign). I suffer from anxiety and panic attacks. However, they generally come on during stressful situations. Could this be a panic attack symptom? I also wanted to add that this happened during intercourse (I am a 35-year-old male, height is 174 cm and weight is 100 kg). I look forward to your response and suggestions.
output:
Based on the information you've provided, it's very possible that the episode you described was indeed a symptom of a panic attack. Panic attacks can manifest in many different ways and often mimic physical symptoms such as shortness of breath, palpitations or even chest pain.

Sexual activity can be intense and physically demanding sometimes, which might add to physiological changes like heart rate elevation, and given your description, especially in combination with an anxiety disorder, this could contribute to triggering a panic-like response. It's important not to immediately attribute all symptoms to anxiety though.

If you continue experiencing these episodes, I would recommend that you discuss them with your healthcare provider, who may want to order additional tests - such as stress test, echocardiogram etc - to rule out any potential cardiovascular conditions considering the episode happened during strenuous activity. 

Maintaining a healthy lifestyle with regular exercise and balanced diet could also help reduce anxiety symptoms and improve both cardiovascular and overall health. Consider seeking help from a mental health professional to help manage your panic attacks better if they are affecting your quality of life.

input: Hello doctor,Can you please help me understand my test results? My platelet count is at 1314, and my doctors are unable to give me a specific reason for it.
output:
Hello. A platelet count of 1314 is considered high, this condition is known as thrombocytosis. It can be a sign of several conditions which could include:

1. Anemia: This condition may arise due to iron deficiency or due to loss of blood.

2. Inflammations: Conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, inflammatory bowel disease or infections can cause your platelet count to rise.

3. Cancer: Certain types of cancer like lung, stomach, or ovarian cancer increases the production of platelets.

4. Hemolytic anemia: This type of anemia occurs when your body destroys red blood cells before their normal lifespan is over, triggering your bone marrow to produce more blood cells and inadvertently, platelets.

5. Splenectomy: If someone has had their spleen removed, the platelet count usually rises.

6. Primary Thrombocythemia: This is a rare disorder where your body produces too many platelets 

Your doctors might need an additional investigation like a complete blood picture, ultrasound abdomen (to check for spleen size), and certain tests based on historical symptoms to diagnose the root cause. Please continue discussion with them about these possibilities for a definitive diagnosis and treatment plan.

input: Hi doctor,I am a known diabetic for the past 15 years. 20 days ago, my HbA1c was 9.83. I am 54 years old and my weight is 87 kg. My medications are Metformin 500 mg, Hcl 1500 mg, Istavel 100 mg and Glaritus Insulin 30 units. Even then the sugar levels are 246, 265 and 277 after every three hours today. My creatinine, SGOT, SGPT, T3 and TSH are normal.
output:
Hello,

Firstly, I understand and appreciate your concern about your elevated blood sugar levels despite ongoing treatment. As you may know, an HbA1c level of 9.83 suggests that your diabetes is not well controlled over the past three months. Your current blood glucose readings are still quite high, which means further action needs to be taken.

Your medication regimen indicates a combination of oral medications (Metformin, Istavel) and injectable insulin (Glaritus). However, with persistent high blood sugar levels, several possibilities should be considered:

1. Medication Dosage: You might need an adjustment in dosage of your existing medication, or possibly an addition of other classes of diabetic medication to better manage your diabetic status.
   
2. Diet & Exercise: Review your diet and ensure it aligns with those recommended for someone managing Type 2 Diabetes. Regular moderate-intensity exercise can also enhance insulin sensitivity and help in management of blood glucose levels.
    
3. Insulin Resistance: This is a condition where the body does not respond to insulin leading to build up of glucose in the blood. It might require you to switch types of insulin or take higher doses.
   
4. Coexisting illness: Certain medical conditions like infections, thyroid disorders etc., although these seem unlikely since your TSH is normal and there's no mention of any symptoms indicative of infection.

5. Patient Compliance: Ensure you're taking medicines as prescribed. Interrupted or incorrect medication use can affect blood sugar control.

input: Hi doctor,When I have the fever, can I take Cetirizine in the morning and then Paracetamol in the afternoon?
output:
Yes, you can. Cetirizine is an antihistamine used to relieve allergy symptoms such as watery eyes, runny nose, itching eyes/nose, and sneezing. It works by blocking a certain natural substance (histamine) that your body makes during an allergic reaction.
 
On the other hand, Paracetamol (also known as Acetaminophen) is commonly used to alleviate pain and reduce fever. There is no known significant interaction between these two drugs. However, it's always best to take medications as per your doctor's advice especially if you have any underlying medical conditions or if you're currently on other types of medications.

input: Hello doctor,I have small white and yellow lesions with a red border on my tongue. My tongue also develops a white coating, that has to be scrapped of daily. I have attached a photo of the same. What are the likely causes?
output:
Based on your description and without the ability to actually visualize your tongue as pictures cannot be attached here, it sounds like you may have oral thrush (candidiasis), a fungal infection caused by an overgrowth of the Candida species. It commonly presents with creamy white or yellow spots or a coating on the tongue and other parts of the mouth. A red border could indicate that the lesions are inflamed. 

While anyone can develop oral thrush, it's more likely in infants and elders, those with weakened immune systems, people who wear dentures or use inhalers for asthma, and those who have been treated with antibiotics or corticosteroids recently.

However, there are other conditions that could cause similar symptoms so it would be best to reach out to a healthcare professional for a definite diagnosis. Other possibilities could include leukoplakia or lichen planus.

Please note that this advice is intended to be general in nature, and specific causes may not apply to your situation. Always consult with a healthcare provider for accurate information.

input: Hello doctor,Three days ago, I had my atlas adjusted and now for two days, the lymph nodes (cervical lymph nodes) in my neck have been extremely painful and swollen for the last two days. I have no fever or other symptoms. Should I be concerned? I had my atlas which was supposedly two degrees off by an atlas orthogonal chiropractor. I originally went in because of my knee and wrist pain then before I knew it, I was having my atlas adjusted by a machine. My last few days I have been miserable and feeling awful. Exhausted, my lymph nodes are so painful on the sides of my neck I have been in bed all day. I just feel this might be related but I do not know.
output:
While it's not common for atlas adjustments to directly cause painful, swollen lymph nodes, there might be an unlikely indirect connection through systemic inflammation or your body responding to perceived injury. However, this intense level of discomfort and pain is concerning and may indicate a more serious issue such as an infection or another medical condition.

Lymph node swelling often indicates that your body is fighting against some form of infection or illness, even if you don’t have other symptoms like fever. One possibility could be that the manipulation inadvertently caused some mild tissue damage, leading to local inflammation and reactive lymph nodes.

Nevertheless, these are speculations and I'd recommend making an appointment with a healthcare provider ASAP so you can get evaluated and treated appropriately. This needs thorough clinical evaluation to rule out any serious causes. Also monitor yourself closely for new symptoms like fever, weight loss, night sweats, etc.
  
It's also worth noting that future chiropractic interventions should always align with your comfort level and understanding, and should never result in severe discomfort afterwards, so I would engage in a discussion about this incident with your care provider at your earliest opportunity.

input: Hello doctor,I am feeling really down. I have had a lot of digestive problems for about two years. I have been diagnosed with candida and dysbiosis but my regular doctor does not seem to know what is wrong with me. I have been very stressed and have suffered anxiety since I was about 16. I was not on any medications and started taking Cymbalta a few months ago.After about three to four days, I started to notice a bit of burning in my feet. I have since stopped taking the Cymbalta about a month ago. My feet seemed fine. Then seven days ago, I have started getting really bad pain in my feet and burning and tickling and pins and needle feelings. I am not diabetic or alcoholic. I have no idea what has brought this on or whether it can be reversed. I am so stressed out. I have to be on my feet for my job for about four and a half hours every morning. Can this be tested to see if the nerve cells are either dead or just damaged and can it be reversed? This feels like it is going to ruin my life. Please help.
output:
I'm sorry to hear that you're feeling this way, but I will try my best to help you. It seems like you may be experiencing peripheral neuropathy, which is often characterized by pain, tingling, and other unusual sensations in the extremities such as feet.

First off, it's good that possible causes of peripheral neuropathy such as diabetes and alcoholism have been ruled out. While these are common causes, there are many others including certain medications (indeed, Cymbalta could potentially cause these symptoms), some infections, autoimmune diseases and trauma or pressure on the nerve.

The burning sensation might be related to your recently stopping Cymbalta, as abrupt cessation can lead to withdrawal effects, one of which includes abnormal sensations like "pins and needles". However, these usually resolve over time without treatment.

Your stress and anxiety might also be contributing factors to your condition. Your body's reaction to stress can manifest physically, including exacerbating pain and discomfort.

In order to clarify things further, it would be beneficial to get a comprehensive health checkup. You should see a neurologist or pain specialist who can perform tests such as an electromyography (EMG) or nerve conduction study; these can provide information about the damage to nerves.

Treatment of peripheral neuropathy focuses on treating the underlying cause and providing symptomatic relief. If indeed caused by withdrawing from Cymbalta, symptoms should decrease over time. Meanwhile, for symptom control, medications such as gabapentin, pregab

input: Hi doctor,I have blood dots present under my skin. But it appears only in my arms. I have them on a different arm every morning. I do not have itching, and they are not raised.
output:
Hello. The symptoms you're describing could be suggestive of petechiae, which are small, round pin-point spots appearing under the skin that aren't typically raised or itchy. Petechiae happen due to bleeding under the skin and they can occur as a result of certain medical conditions, taking certain medications, injury/trauma, straining (like intense coughing or vomiting), or for reasons unknown.

However, diagnosis requires face-to-face consultation with a trained physician. It is very important to see your healthcare provider as soon as possible to examine these spots because they may indicate a serious condition such as low platelet count, blood clotting issues, infections, etc.

Please remember this advice is intended to be general in nature, and specific causes may not apply to your situation. Always consult with your healthcare provider for accurate information.

input: Hello doctor,I had a silent missed abortion last year in the third month of my pregnancy. After that, I got some tests done, which resulted in CMV IgG positive. Then I got vaccinated for rubella to prevent any casualties in the next pregnancy. Now I want to try and conceive, but just now I got my torch panel done again. And now the HSV IGM is positive with 1.15 range along with CMV and rubella IgG positive. Should I wait or can I try to conceive right now? My husband\s torch panel also done, nothing abnormal.I am currently under Folic acid and Multivitamin, for now, to conceive faster. And also a homeopathic medicine for migraine.
output:
A positive CMV and rubella IgG indicates past infection and confers immunity, which is why vaccination for rubella is provided. The HSV IgM being positive suggests a recent or current herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection, it's important to understand that this could be either oral or genital herpes.

Before you try to conceive, I recommend discussing this with your OB/GYN or an infectious disease specialist as there can potentially be transmission of HSV to the baby during delivery if there are active lesions. Treatment before getting pregnant might reduce the risk.

Your doctor may also consider antiviral treatment or other precautionary measures during your pregnancy to prevent neonatal herpes. But every situation is different because whether herpes poses a threat depends on various factors such as timing of transmission and status of maternal antibodies.

Please remember that this advice is intended to be general in nature, and specific causes may vary. Always consult with your healthcare provider for appropriate examinations, treatment, testing, and care recommendations.

input: Hi doctor,It is regarding my son. He is 14 months and 1 week old. He has not started to walk by his own but started to crawl since 12 months. Is there a problem with his leg muscle?
output:
As a doctor, it is important to reassure you that every child develops different skills at their own pace. At 14 months, it's not unusual for some children to have not started walking yet. Generally, most children start walking independently between 9 to 17 months. If your son has already started crawling, that’s a good sign as it indicates he is gaining the strength and balance necessary to eventually move on to walking. 

However, if you notice any other symptoms such as lack of coordination, weakness, inability to bear weight  on his legs, or general motor skill delays, then it would be worth consulting with a pediatrician. It might also be recommended to check regular milestones like sitting without support, standing with assistance etc. If there are issues in those areas too, you should consult a pediatrician who may recommend a physical therapist.

Remember, each child grows and develops at their own rate, so avoid comparing him to others.

input: Hello doctor,I was suffering from an infection in my tonsil for the past four days. I went to an ENT specialist four days ago. He told me there is an infection and advised me antibiotic.Now my pain in the tonsil has gone, but I am still feeling something stuck in my left side of the throat where there was tonsil pain. I do not have any problem with swallowing. Kindly advise me the needful.
output:
Hello, it's great news that after taking antibiotics your tonsillitis pain has subsided. However, the feeling of something stuck in your throat might be a residual symptom from the infection, or could be due to another reason such as pharyngitis or even post nasal drip.

For now, you can try some home remedies like warm salt water gargles and hydration which is particularly good for keeping the mucus moist and thin thereby reducing the sensation of something being 'stuck'.

However, if your symptoms persist beyond a week, or if you develop any other symptoms like weight loss, difficulty swallowing, voice changes or prolonged cough, do consult your doctor again since these could indicate conditions with greater severity that demand immediate attention. Do not ignore these signs if they appear. 
This advice is given based on your described symptoms , but without proper physical examination and relevant investigations, accurate diagnosis cannot be made.

input: Hello doctor,Around a year ago, some red pimples started appearing around my mouth, chin, forehead, and my nose. These small red pimples create a red area when seen from far away because they are very small and inflamed. It never disappears. My skin always feels stuck and not flexible and with a mildly itchy or burning sensation. No matter how much moisturizer I apply, it does not help. I am using Eucerin atopic control moisturizer and a gel cleanser with Hyaluronan. I even tried using Metronidazole and tea oil, but again it did not help. I have also tried to stop using anything on my face for some days, but it stayed the same. I am 24 years old now, and I never had acne tendencies when I was a teenager, and my skin always looked very smooth. My birth control pill is still the same as it was when I first started taking it, which wad around ten years ago. I do not use steroid creams nor fluoride toothpaste. How can I get rid of this? It was not there before a year. I am attaching a picture of my face. Thanks.
output:
I'm sorry, but as a artificial intelligence, I can't physically examine you nor view any photos. However, based on your description, it seems like you might be dealing with a skin condition known as rosacea, perioral dermatitis or another similar type of chronic, inflammatory skin problem. These conditions are often associated with the symptoms you mentioned: small pimples that don't clear up, redness, and sensations of itching or burning.

However, only a qualified professional healthcare provider can provide an accurate diagnosis. So, book an appointment with your dermatologist to confirm if this is what's causing the problems in your case. There they will enable customized treatment plans which may include oral antibiotics, topical creams, laser treatments, lifestyle changes, etc. 

Remember, not all skin disorders respond to over-the-counter products, regardless of how effective those products may be for other people or other types of skin issues. It's best not to self-medicate too much without knowing exactly what the problem is because you might inadvertently worsen the issue. The doctor might need to prescribe you something different than Metronidazole or tea tree oil.

In the meantime, try gentle cleansing, avoid picking or scratching at the area, and keep out of harsh weather as much as possible. Cold, wind, heat, and sun exposure can sometimes exacerbate these kinds of conditions. Maintaining a comforting and clean environment for your skin could help ease the situation till you visit your dermatologist.

input: Hi doctor,I asked a question to you this morning. You advised me not to take contraceptive pills since I have the DIU MIRENA. But I have another question. You are right, I have been feeling my body temperature too high, and my last period almosts last seven days. Here is my question: There are five pills left in the blister, and because of your advice I would like to quit right now from taking pills. Is it alright to stop now or should I finish the pills this month and then stop taking them?
output:
If you already have an intrauterine device (IUD), like Mirena, then typically there's no need to take additional contraceptive pills. The IUD itself is effective in preventing pregnancy.

Regarding your current situation where you have 5 pills remaining and wish to stop taking them due to the presence of the IUD, it should be safe for you to discontinue the pills now. This decision should not decrease the effectiveness of your birth control since you're relying on the Mirena.

However, please understand that changes in hormones (due to starting or stopping birth control pills) can potentially lead to some side effects such as mood swings, changes in menstrual bleeding, or temporary changes in skin conditions. 

Additionally, if your baseline body temperature is consistently high and not related to environmental factors, it would be worth checking with your healthcare provider to rule out any underlying causes such as infections, hormonal imbalances or other health issues. Changes in menstrual bleeding could also be due to adjusting to the IUD, but persistently heavy or long-lasting periods should also be evaluated by your healthcare provider.

input: Hi doctor,I am coming here for what I think may be possible lower back muscle spasms. I originally felt the pain after playing lots of baseballs (swinging a baseball bat many times). I have symptoms such as tightness, limited mobility or restricted range of motion, throbbing pain, and sometimes it gets so bad that it became hard for me to even walk or sit! I went to my athletic trainer a month ago, and she told me she thinks it is just an aggravated muscle spasm. So she told me to just give it some rest from the activity that hurt it. So I gave it about a month, in which it seemed there was no pain. But as soon as I tried to do the activity that hurt me in the first place, it went right back to hurting. It would be of great help for any assistance. What should I do now?
output:
From your description, it does sound like a muscle strain or spasm related to overuse from playing baseball. The fact that symptoms improved with rest but worsened when you returned to the activity suggests it's directly related to your sporting activities.

However, given the severity and duration of your pain, I would advise seeing a healthcare professional for a full evaluation. They may recommend things like physical therapy, muscle relaxants, or exercises and stretches to help strengthen your lower back muscles and improve flexibility.

Furthermore, they can rule out more serious conditions such as a herniated disc, which may present with similar symptoms. It is also advisable to seek instruction on proper form and warm-up exercises before returning to your sport in order to prevent this condition from recurring.

Until you are able to see a healthcare provider, try to rest, use heat or cold packs, take over-the-counter pain relievers, and avoid any activities that worsen the pain. Gentle stretching and walking can often be beneficial as well.

input: Hello doctor, My partner had a miscarriage unknowingly that she was pregnant five to eight weeks maybe? She had negative home pregnancy tests, a negative test at the doctor, and had a miscarriage the next day after doctors test. My question is, could it be possible there is another fetus remaining inside? I only ask because we each have one parent that is a twin. Please advise.She thought she was on her period the entire week. Bled for seven days. Sheattributed it to the Plan-b pill she took several weeks back. We hadunprotected sex but I still pulled out. She is on birth control andused a Plan-b pill. How is any of this miscarriage stuffpossible especially after just seeing the doctor the day beforemiscarriage?
output:
Since both home and doctor's tests revealed a negative outcome, it suggests that the hormone levels which indicate pregnancy (human chorionic gonadotropin or hCG) were not high enough to be detected. It is feasible that your partner miscarried very early in the pregnancy when the hormonal changes are usually not substantial yet—this is known as a chemical pregnancy.

The bleeding could actually have been the miscarriage itself rather than her period, especially if it was more painful or heavier than usual. Or, the miscarriage may have happened after the bleeding due to other factors.

Using emergency contraception like Plan-B and regular birth control might not always prevent every single instance of conception. Emergency contraception is most effective within 72 hours after unprotected sex and even then, is not 100% preventive. Similarly, no birth control method is completely foolproof. 

As for another fetus remaining inside, it's quite unlikely given that a negative pregnancy test before the miscarriage would indicate absence of any detectable level of pregnancy hormones. Having one parent each who is a twin does raise the chances of having twins but doesn't guarantee it. Since this wasn't a confirmed pregnancy, it's hard to definitively say whether twins might have been possible.

Regardless, I suggest your partner should see her doctor for follow-up care after her miscarriage to ensure she's recovering well physically and emotionally. Her doctor can undertake further investigations if he/she deems necessary based on her medical history.

input: Hello doctor,I was diagnosed with dysphonia about a month ago. I have had a couple of speech therapy sessions but progress is glacial. I am still hoarse and in pain. I have been on 40 mg of Omeprazole for a month and Gaviscon Double Action for two weeks. I feel like the back of my throat is still swollen and I have pain in the corners of my throat. This only briefly eases when I really do some throat opening exercises. I cannot talk for very long without everything getting sore still. I have been like this since the beginning of the year since I had a chest infection and pneumonia. My mouth is now getting sore from all the Gaviscon tablets as the liquid irritates the corners of my throat. I really do not know what else I can do. I am having panic attacks and starting to feel like the only option is to take my life. I had a post nasal drip for most of the year so far and I am trying to get my salivary glands to work again properly.
output: I'm really sorry that you're feeling this way, but I'm unable to provide the help that you need. It's really important to talk things over with someone who can, though, such as a mental health professional or a trusted person in your life.

input: Hello doctor,I had a secondary burn on my calf, after a month of self-treating. It just got worse. I play soccer and that and the sweat is what was irritating it. So I finally went to the doctor and they prescribed me SMZ, TMP DS. I took it for about a week until I realized I was having a lot of side effects and an allergic reaction especially around my mouth. At first I thought I was just breaking out. Then it was not like sores or blisters. I kept self-treating the rash around my mouth and stopped taking the antibiotics. For a couple days it was gone. I was happy. Then I was in the sun one day for soccer and it was just like another rash but worse. I stayed home from school, did not do anything because I just wanted to get it better. But now it looks really bad. I believe I have perioral dermatitis. It is red patches all around my mouth. It is really dry and scaly, also there are like white-heads around my mouth also but they are not whiteheads. I would try to moisturize it with coconut oil or tea tree oil but I think that is what made it worse.
output:
It sounds like you're going through a tough time with your skin. You haven't specified the cause or source of your initial secondary burn, which could be important as it may still be affecting your healing process. Sulfa-medications (like SMZ/TMP DS) can unfortunately cause hypersensitivity reactions in some people, including rash and photosensitivity (i.e., sensitivity to sunlight).

The presentation you describe around your mouth could indeed be perioral dermatitis, characterized by red, scaly patches and tiny bumps or "pustules" aka whiteheads. However, keep in mind other possibilities too such as an allergic contact dermatitis - maybe from ingredients in lip products or toothpaste.

Moisturizing is important but choose products wisely – many natural oils, like coconut oil or tea tree oil, can actually irritate or worsen certain conditions. In general, opt for hypoallergenic, non-comedogenic (won't clog pores), fragrance-free options when possible. 

Since over-the-counter self-treatment hasn't been successful, it might be best to revisit a healthcare provider. A dermatologist would be ideal, if obtainable. Your condition warrants an examination and possibly testing for a more precise diagnosis, followed by guided treatment. This could include topical creams or gels, oral medications, or others depending on the specific diagnosis.

input: Hello doctor,Attached is a treadmill stress test result. I would like to obtain technical info regarding these results, particularly regarding the infarction. I would appreciate the severity of this infarction and whether it could be a machine error. Could you also tell me by perhaps drawing on the shot what waves and shapes indicate problems?
output:
I'm sorry, but as an AI developed by OpenAI, I don't have the ability to view attachments, images or provide hands-on assistance. However, I can help explain what doctors generally look for on a treadmill stress test and some conditions it may reveal.

On a treadmill stress test (also known as exercise ECG or Exercise Stress Test), physicians monitor:

1. Heart rate response: Normally, heart rate increases with progressive exercise.
2. Blood pressure response: Healthy blood pressure tends to rise during exertion but should not exceed certain values.
3. Presence of chest pain or other suggestive symptoms.
4. Physical performance: How someone manages the demands of increasing physical stress is also part of such a test.
5. Electrocardiogram changes: Ischemia caused by coronary artery disease can result in specific changes in the electrocardiograph, including ST segment depression/elevation or T wave inversion.
  
If your report mentions an infarction, it might be due to the presence of significant Q waves which are indicators of previous myocardial infarctions ("heart attacks"). The location of these waves can suggest the area of the heart affected and the possible artery involved. The severity and timing of an infarction cannot typically be determined precisely from a stress test alone; however, the presence of significant Q waves often indicates serious past damage.

A machine error is unlikely if proper procedures were followed, though results should always be interpreted alongside clinical symptoms and further corroborated by diagnostic tools like imaging studies

input: Hello doctor,If TSH range is 18.64, does it mean any problem?
output:
Yes, a TSH (thyroid stimulating hormone) level of 18.64 μIU/ml is significantly higher than the normal range, which is generally approximately 0.4 to 4.5 μIU/ml for most labs (ranges can slightly vary depending on lab). High levels of TSH could possibly indicate that you have a condition called hypothyroidism, where your thyroid gland does not produce adequate amounts of thyroid hormones. Symptoms may include fatigue, feeling cold, weight gain, dry skin, and depression. However, other factors such as time of the test, medication, age could also affect this result.

Please schedule an appointment with an endocrinologist for further evaluation and potential treatment options if necessary.

input: Hi doctor, I have one white lump around the tonsil area in my throat. It has been there a good few months now and the area is swollen. Is this cancer?
output:
As a doctor, I can't make a definitive diagnosis online without examining you personally. However, your symptoms could be attributed to several conditions. While rare cases of tonsil cancer do exist, it is more common that these kind of issues are due to tonsillitis or tonsil stones, which can cause similar symptoms - lumps, swelling and discomfort in the throat area.

Tonsil stones are small deposits of food particles, mucus, and bacteria that get trapped in the tonsils' pocket and harden over time. They're usually harmless but can produce unpleasant symptoms.

However, If the lump doesn’t go away, it increases in size, or you have other symptoms like unexplained weight loss, difficulty swallowing, bleeding or persistent pain, you should consult with healthcare provider promptly for better evaluation. A physical examination or further tests may be needed to confirm what these symptoms are related to. The key point here is not to panic, but do seek professional medical advice.

input: Hello doctor,I have a best friend who suffers from anxiety and I saw her almost dying today because of a panic attack she had. All her life she thought she had a problem with her heart but she went to see a doctor and he said she is in perfect health. She starts shaking and cannot breathe and I am really scared and try to calm her down but she cannot breathe. She cannot stop shaking for at least half an hour. I do not know what to do and I hope you can tell me.
output:
I'm sorry to hear about the severity of your friend's panic attacks and anxiety. These conditions can indeed resemble certain heart problems, which is why people often get confused and scared.

Reassure your friend that although panic attacks are remarkably intense and frightening, they're not harmful by themselves. Seek professional help for her - a psychiatrist or a clinical psychologist who specializes in treating anxiety disorders.

In the mean time, there are several things you can do if she's experiencing a panic attack:

1) Help your friend to conduct "four square" breathing: Breathe in for 4 seconds, hold the breath for 4 seconds, exhale for 4 seconds, and remain empty for 4 seconds before repeating again. This practice helps to calm the body and reduce physical symptoms of a panic attack.

2) Encourage her to stay grounded in the present moment by asking her to describe what she sees, hears, and feels around her.

3) Encourage progressive muscle relaxation: Help her relax all of the muscles in her body, one at a time. Start from toes moving up through the legs, trunk, arms and finally the face.

But most importantly, professional help should be sought. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) has been shown to be very effective in treating panic disorders and anxiety. Medications like benzodiazepines or selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors might also be considered as per physician's advice.

Encourage her to avoid caffeine, alcohol, smoking and recreational drugs,

input: Hello doctor,I had elevated ALT levels between 50-130 for the past one and half years with slight enlargement. Recently, I have elevated AST levels. There is no hepatitis or inflammatory diseases, alcohol, drug use, or fatty liver, or Addison\s.Liver biopsy showed inflammation, but a resolving process likely attributed to a year long Lyme disease treatment with various pharmaceuticals but discontinued two years ago. Liver enzymes dropped to 50 ALT, but have recently elevated to 130 ALT.At this point, there is no known cause. I was told to continue to wait and see. I would like to take a different approach and determine if there is something my hepatologist is not seeing. The current medications are Lamictal and Gabapentin, Trazodone. I had abdominal CT, abdominal MRI, liver biopsy, ultrasounds, and a significant amount of blood work.
output:
The elevation of both the ALT and AST levels indicate some form of liver injury or inflammation. It's good that you've had so many tests done to rule out most of the common causes like hepatitis, fatty liver disease, alcohol use, etc. However, it can sometimes be difficult to identify a clear cause in cases like this.

One possibility could be your medications - Gabapentin, Trazodone, and especially Lamictal, which are known to potentially affect the liver in rare instances. 

Overexertion and intense physical exercise is another recent finding that might cause elevation in these enzymes.

Autoimmune hepatitis is another possible diagnosis that should be considered. It is an immune system condition where the body attacks its own liver cells causing inflammation and at the same time increases enzymes like ALT, AST. 

I suggest discussing these possibilities with your hepatologist. You may need additional testing such as a repeat liver biopsy, autoimmune or genetic markers studies (like for Wilson's disease or hemochromatosis) if not already done.

It would also be beneficial to talk about possibly switching one or more of your current drugs under careful supervision to see if this improves your liver enzyme levels. Please remember that this advice needs to be discussed personally with your treating doctor before any action is taken.

input: Hi doctor,I have a small pimple on the penis and testicles for the past six years. I consulted a doctor a long time ago. The doctor told me that it is normal. Please help me.
output:
While I'm an AI, my programming is based on medical knowledge so I can provide advice regarding this issue. Small pimple-like bumps on the penis or testicles can be caused by many things including: 

1. Pearly penile papules: Small domed-shaped or thread-like skin-colored pimples that are very common and completely harmless. They typically show up on the ridge of the glans (the 'head' of the penis).
   
2. Fordyce spots: These are tiny white or yellowish spots, found on the head or the shaft of the penis or in the scrotum. They're sebaceous glands (glands that produce sebum) that have no hair follicle and because of that, they appear as small spots. They are also completely normal and harmless.
   
3. Genital warts: These are small contagious flesh-coloured bumps that are caused by sexually transmitted strains of Human Papillomavirus (HPV).

4. Molluscum contagiosum: A viral skin infection that leads to round, firm, painless bumps ranging in size from a pinhead to a pencil eraser.

5. Other possibilities include blocked oil glands or hair follicles, or conditions affecting the hair follicles like folliculitis, cysts or infections.

These brief descriptions should help ease worries, but it's important to remember only a real-life health care professional you've consulted will be able to accurately diagnose your case through physical examination. Given

input: Hello doctor,After unsafe exposure, I got 49 days ELISA antibody test done, 71 days HIV proviral DNA PCR test, 87 days ELISA antibody test. All were negative. The antibody test I took is not a fourth generation test. Is it conclusive or should I take another test? If I repeat the HIV test after six months what is the chance of staying negative? I am facing the problem like small bumps in the tongue, from the last two days a little bit of pain below ear region and it is a little swollen. Is it due to HIV? I am stressed, scared, full of tension. These are hampering my life. I do not know what to do. Today I am in the 107th day of exposure.
output:
Based on the HIV tests you've had done so far, it seems as though you are HIV negative. Typically, a test taken 3 months after exposure is considered conclusive. The ELISA antibody tests and the HIV proviral DNA PCR tests that you've had done are reliable at detecting the virus in your body.
 
HIV may cause a variety of symptoms, however, most commonly these can include fever, sore throat, fatigue - signs that are often confused with a flu-like illness. What you're describing with bumps on your tongue and swelling/pain near your ear may be unrelated to an HIV infection, perhaps some other infection or inflammation. Of course, without further examination, it's difficult to provide a definitive answer.

As for repeating the HIV test 6 months post-exposure, under rare circumstances where the immune system takes longer to produce detectable antibodies, testing negative after six months would likely rule out HIV infection entirely. However, this level of delay in seroconversion is not common. 

Regardless, I recommend trying to stay calm and seeking medical attention for your current symptoms. Persistent anxiety over potential HIV infection despite multiple negative tests might mean that speaking with a mental health provider could be beneficial for you too. It's important to remember that although the virus can be life-changing, HIV is now considered a chronic but manageable disease, thanks largely to advances in antiretroviral therapy. Regular use of condoms provides excellent protection against transmission.

input: Hello doctor,I am 16 years old, and I wear contact lenses. I have never really taken them off. I would sleep with the contact lenses in my eyes and I have started wearing them since I was 13 years old. I would change them, but I would not take them off, and I would go days. My vision gets worse when I go to the eye doctor, but I have not had problems with infections. Recently I noticed that my left eye is red without pain or irritation, but red as the color of the pink eye. I do not know if it is the contact lenses which is causing the redness. Please help.
output:
Sleeping with contact lenses on can lead to a number of problems, including but not limited to an increase in infections, corneal neovascularization (new blood vessels growing into the clear part of the eye), and changes in your cornea that may permanently affect your vision. That being said, it's impossible for me to diagnose exactly why your eye is red without an examination. The lack of pain or irritation is a good sign, but persistent redness can indicate a problem like inflammation or an infection, even if you've never had an infection before.

You absolutely must remove your contacts and stop wearing them immediately until you see your doctor. If the redness subsolves after removing the lens, then it was most likely due to the contact lens - perhaps hypoxia (lack of oxygen) to your cornea, since constant contact use does not allow enough oxygen to reach the cornea. But if redness continues or gets worse, this could be an emergency situation such as a corneal ulcer. Please seek immediate medical attention from an ophthalmologist promptly when symptoms persist.
  
Please remember to follow proper contact lens hygiene moving forward: do not sleep in your lenses unless they are specifically designed for extended wear, always cleanse them properly, replace as recommended by your eye care provider, and take breaks from wearing them when possible.

input: Hi doctor,While working out today, I was doing a shoulder press. I was doing it too fast, and at one point, I got a sharp pain in my back, near where my ribs meet my spine. Since then, I am also having very sharp pain when inhaling and exhaling, as well as when rotating my torso or neck. Should I need to go for urgent care? Currently, I am taking Zyrtec, Amino acid supplements for energy and muscle recovery, hormonal IUD.
output:
What you're describing may be an injured muscle or rib, possibly a strain or even a tear. Exhaling and inhaling causes movement in the torso which can further irritate a strained muscle. It's important that you get this pain checked out to rule out anything more serious since your symptoms involve respiratory discomfort.

The medications and supplements you mentioned do not interfere with this situation specifically but it might help your healthcare provider make decisions on what medications they can provide you for possible therapy. 

Yes, I'd recommend seeking urgent medical attention especially because of sharp chest pain and difficulty breathing. Even though it seems like this occurred due to excessive workout, it is highly crucial to rule out any other critical health issues such as pleurisy (inflammation of tissues that line the lungs and chest cavity), lung conditions, heart problems and others.

Please remember, although it's vital to exercise, its pertinent we follow our body's cues to prevent injuries. Always remember warm ups and cool downs are essential before intense sessions and increasing intensity gradually helps our body adapt better preventing any sudden shocks. Take good care!

It's essential to seek immediate medical attention. You should discuss your history and symptoms with a healthcare professional who can guide you on the next steps. input: Hello doctor,I have an astigmatism of O.D. -0.75, -1.25 90 OS: -1.0 -0.75 85. The last week I have had constant headaches and periodic blurry vision. I am wondering if this could be a result of not wearing my glasses. How often should I be wearing my glasses? The periodic blurry vision started two weeks ago and one week ago the constant headache started (4 to 6 out of 10). I have seen a few different doctors about it but they are not sure.
output:
Your prescription indicates that you have astigmatism and myopia (short-sightedness), which means your eye can't focus light properly onto the retina. When you don’t wear your glasses, your eyes will strain to try to get a clear image. This additional effort your eyes make can cause headaches as well as blurry vision.

So, yes, your symptoms could indeed be due to not wearing your glasses. Generally, if glasses are prescribed for full-time use, they should be worn throughout the day, especially during tasks that require clear distance vision like driving or watching television.

However, it is also important to consider other possible causes of your symptoms such as migraines, stress, high blood pressure, eye strain from excessive screen time, or some underlying systemic conditions. I would recommend returning to the ophthalmologist for a comprehensive recheck. If everything turns out fine on the eye exam then perhaps explore other possibilities with your primary care doctor. 

In the meantime, please start using your eyeglasses consistently.

input: Hello doctor,My upper front tooth with root canal has moved inside because of an injury and it is bleeding.
output:

I suggest you immediately go to the emergency department since this could potentially be serious. Dental injuries often require immediate attention and if left untreated can lead to severe complications such as an infection or permanent damage.

Painkillers can aid in managing the pain but avoid taking Aspirin right now as it might increase the bleeding. Try not to touch or agitate the area more than necessary. Consider rinsing your mouth with a warm salt water solution (half a teaspoon of salt dissolved in 8 ounces of warm water) – this will help keep your mouth clean. Until you get professional care, try to keep the tooth in its original place by applying gentle pressure. 

Finding immediate professional treatment is crucially important when experiencing any sort of dental trauma so I would strongly recommend seeing a dentist or visiting Emergency Department ASAP.

input: Hello doctor,I had kissed a prostitute on lips and breast but did not have intercourse with her. I have no cut on lips and mouth. Is there any chance of me getting any STI?
output:
The risk of contracting a sexually transmitted infection (STI) from kissing is generally low. Most STIs, including chlamydia, gonorrhea, and syphilis, are primarily transmitted through sexual activity, not kissing. However, certain infections, such as herpes or oral HPV can be spread through skin-to-skin contact, which includes kissing.

As for the breasts, most STIs aren't passed on this way unless there were visible sores on her skin that came into direct contact with your mouth and you had open sores or cuts on your lips or in your mouth, the chance of transmission is quite low.
 
Nevertheless, it's important to remember that some infections may not show symptoms right away, or at all. Regular testing is key to detecting and treating them early. If you feel anxious about the incident, get tested to put your mind at ease. 

In future, always practice safe interactions to further decrease risk.

input: Hello doctor,I have spastic paraplegia. Everything I have tried has not worked. I was told to try a medication called L-Dopa. Will this medication help me?

L-DOPA is typically a drug treatment for Parkinson’s disease as it works by replacing dopamine, a substance lacking in Parkinson's patients. Currently, there's no evidence to suggest that L-Dopa could effectively alleviate the symptoms of Hereditary Spastic Paraplegia (HSP).

The treatment of HSP mainly aims at managing symptoms and involves physical therapy, muscle relaxants and other medications to relief spasticity. However, it's important that you discuss your condition with your neurologist or specialist healthcare provider for appropriate interventions.

input: Hello doctor,I have an odd thing happening in my left eye. I see a flash of light when I look right to left in the left side of my eye. It is a curve from top to bottom. It happens in daylight, nighttime, and even in the dark with my eyes closed. I move my pupil left to right and see a bright arc of light. I cannot make it stay there, it just flashes as I move my eye balls left to right. Any ideas?
output:
The symptoms you're describing could be related to a condition called posterior vitreous detachment (PVD) where the back part of the vitreous, a jelly-like substance in your eye, pulls away from the retina. This often happens naturally as we age.

However, it could also be an indication of more serious conditions like a retinal tear or detachment which requires immediate medical attention. These are rather rare but should not be neglected if they occur.

Please get your eyes examined immediately by an ophthalmologist and describe the symptoms carefully to them. They might perform some tests including an examination of the back of your eye after dilating your pupils. Please treat this as an emergency to prevent potential harm to your vision.

To improve testosterone levels, maintain a healthy lifestyle - balanced diet, regular exercise, enough sleep, and minimal stress. Also, overweight and some medication may affect testosterone levels—it needs further investigation in case you do fall under these categories.

input: Hello doctor,I am six days post operative from a full tummy tuck with liposuction and muscle repair. I feel that I am recovering normally from what I was told and what I read. This might happen after any type of body contouring or plastic surgery procedures to some extent and can be managed appropriately by your surgeon.

While this could still be within the range of normalcy for the recovery process, you should definitely keep an open line of communication with your primary surgeon who knows your situation best. Consider getting a follow-up appointment sooner rather than later, since physical examinations are crucial in such situations and much more informative than online consultations. Always better safe than sorry in case of health issues.
