It would all then be held by plates and screws. My biggest concern is that she is a beautiful girl and he says that her face will not change at all. Is that true with this kind of procedure?
output:
It's completely understandable to be concerned about possible changes in your daughter's appearance from maxillofacial surgery. The kind of procedure being proposed, known as orthognathic surgery, is typically performed to correct functional problems, like improving "bite" or to help with sleep apnea, rather than to alter appearance.

In general, when done correctly by a skilled surgeon, the change in facial structure can be minimal and subtle. However, each individual’s results may vary. Aspects such as swelling after the operation would temporarily alter her face but once healed, it should return to normal. One aspect to keep in mind is that these procedures do tend to highlight the patient's existing facial features, so this could slightly change the overall aesthetic look. 

I recommend you have an in-depth conversation with the maxillofacial surgeon. Ask if they can show you before-and-after photos of patients who've had similar procedures. You might also consider getting a second opinion for additional reassurance. 

Remember, the main goal here is to improve her oral health and quality of life.

input: Hello doctor,I am a 21 year old female. Yesterday, doctors have checked my blood. I am visiting a hospital frequently as I have iron deficiency anemia. The thing I am scared about is, my doctor asked me why my ferritin has not increased (just the opposite, it has decreased from 5.79 to 5.77) after three months of taking iron supplements. My other iron levels are at 39 which has increased considering those references. But, that was probably because I did not use the medicine correctly, I was only taking 5 mg a day. Another thing I am worried about is, my lymphocytes kind of got increased in my blood: (52.8) - the reference is 19.4 to 44.9, and the other one is 3.57. My neutrophils kind of decreased too (36.9) and the reference was between 41.0 to 73.0.In the last week, I had a viral infection as both my parents were sick. Is it why my levels got high? My WBC is 6.77 and RBC is 4.52. My hemoglobin is also increasing actually, last time I checked, it was 11.0 and now it is 11.2. Still low, but it was good to see that it was increasing. My thrombocyte levels got higher again, unfortunately. The first time I was told that I was anemic, my thrombocyte levels were on 485, then in my second blood test (after using iron supplements correctly it decreased to 380. And yesterday, when I checked, it increased to 435 (reference is 156 to 373).I was also told that I have an infection in my urinary system and he gave me antibiotics. Honestly, I have been always getting suspected about it since my anemia has started. Should I be worried about my condition or is it normal?
output:
As a doctor, there are several things I would like to address regarding your condition.

Firstly, Iron deficiency anemia is most commonly due to insufficient dietary intake or absorption of iron. So even if you're taking supplements, it may take some time for the body to absorb enough to replenish stores (represented by ferritin), especially if the oral dosage isn't high enough. The standard daily dose is usually above 150 mg, from which about 5-10% is absorbed. 

Increased lymphocytes (which make up part of your white blood cell count) and decreased neutrophils probably correspond with the viral infection you mentioned. It's not unusual. When your immune system fights infections, these levels can change. It's also what could cause your thrombocyte (platelet) level to be a bit higher – it's an acute phase reactant and can increase during inflammation or infection. 

Though the increase in thrombocyte levels stands out slightly, its association with anemia is rather non-specific. It can be increased in an inflammatory response, which may be why it was raised after your diagnosis of a urinary tract infection. However, you should note that high platelet counts might also suggest other conditions including certain cancers, so regular follow-up is important.

Your RBC count and Hemoglobin levels are indeed on the low side but showing improvement, which again supports the possibility that this just needs more time given that you were only taking a small amount of iron until now. Be sure

input: Hi doctor,I am 27 years old, and I have multiple symptoms including nervousness, anxiety and weight loss. These symptoms are troubling me a lot. I experience extreme nervousness, even when I do not have any emotional struggles. I have a feeling of having a fast heartbeat. At the age of 16, my blood report showed me a result of subclinical hyperthyroidism. I have done breast surgery. Due to my health concern, I always have my blood tested for thyroid.Before eight months, I also had done a Holter monitor, which showed my heart palpitations. On my final blood test, my thyroid results came normal. But still, I have the symptoms. I am trying for a baby. But I heard an issue that underlying or undiagnosed thyroid issue could become a terrible one during pregnancy. Do I need to consult an endocrinologist soon? Do these fluctuations are common in hyperthyroidism?
output:
Yes, your symptoms such as anxiety, nervousness, weight loss and fast heartbeat are consistent with an overactive thyroid (hyperthyroidism). Even if your most recent blood test results came back normal, with your history of having subclinical hyperthyroidism as a teenager and persistent symptoms, there could be fluctuations in the thyroid hormone levels that aren't picked up in routine testing. 

Thyroid disorders can indeed have adverse effects on pregnancy including fertility problems, recurrent miscarriage, preterm birth, and negative impact on fetal development. Therefore, it might be a good idea to consult with an endocrinologist soon. He/she will likely order additional tests and possibly start you on medication to manage your thyroid function better. Moreover, they'll provide advice tailored to your situation for when you're trying to conceive and during pregnancy. 

So while fluctuations do happen in patients with hyperthyroidism, it's still a good idea to check-in with a specialist because managing your condition aims at providing you with a consistent, balanced amount of thyroid hormone in your body to keep your symptoms at bay. Please make an appointment with an Endocrinologist soon to address your concerns and best prepare for a healthy future pregnancy.

input: Hi doctor,I have red bumps, which are non-itchy and keep on spreading. Also, I am attaching the picture for your reference. Please explain me.
output:
As a text-based AI, I currently can't view pictures. However, from your written description, it sounds like you could be experiencing several possible skin conditions including hives, heat rash, contact dermatitis, or even certain infections like folliculitis. 

It is best to consult a dermatologist in person who can examine the bumps closely and possibly perform tests if needed. Make sure you mention any other symptoms or possible triggers (e.g., new soaps/lotions, foods, medicines) that might help pinpoint the cause. Prevention also depends on the underlying cause of the red bumps.

input: Hello doctor,On my left eye, on the corner, nearest my nose on the sclera there is a tiny clear bubble. I have has this for years and it does not bother me. On the conjunctiva, it appears also a little puffy but I have noticed on the lacrimal caruncle there seems to be a red little spot. My eyes are always dry and I suffer from allergies. Is this of any concern or is it associated with dry eyes/allergies?
output:
Based on your description, it appears that you have a pinguecula, which is a common type of benign growth that can occur on the sclera, or white part, of the eye. Often, they form on the side of the eye nearest to the nose. Dry eyes and exposure to dust, sun, and wind are believed to contribute to their development. 

The red spot on the lacrimal caruncle may be due to irritation or allergies. It could also be caused by minor infection. Observation for changes in size, shape, or color can be helpful, as well as for new symptoms like pain, itchiness, increased tearing, or discharge.

While pingueculas and small irritations are usually nothing to worry about, any noticeable change in the eye should be checked out by an ophthalmologist just to be certain. Particularly if you feel persistent discomfort or observe worsening symptoms. Using over-the-counter lubricating eye drops (artificial tears) can help with dry eyes. However, in case of continuous dryness or allergic reactions, wrap-around sunglasses outdoors to protect from wind and sunlight, avoidance from allergens and use of anti-allergic eye-drops might benefit. But do consult with your healthcare specialist before starting any medications.

input: Hello doctor,What is HMD (hereditary macular degeneration) and what is the maximum possible impact of this disease in future on a person? Can this disease make one blind?
output:
Hereditary Macular Degeneration (HMD), often referred to as Stargardt's Disease or Juvenile Macular Degeneration, is a genetic eye disorder that leads to progressive vision loss. It affects the macula, an area in the center of the retina responsible for sharp, central vision needed for detailed tasks such as reading, driving, and recognizing faces.

HMD predominantly affects the macula, however, it can also harm other parts of the eye which results in further complications such as retinal dysfunction or even total visual loss in some extreme cases. Besides losing sharp central vision, you may also experience blurriness or haziness in your overall field of view, impaired color discrimination, and sensitivity to light.

It must be noted though that blindness due to HMD doesn't hold same significance as complete blackness or the inability to see anything at all. Most people with advanced stages of macular degeneration are considered legally blind because their vision is 20/200 or less, but they still have some peripheral or side vision remaining. 

The exact prognosis varies significantly from person to person and depends on various factors like how early the condition is diagnosed, how fast it progresses, whether it affects one or both eyes, etc. Currently, there isn’t a cure for HMD, but there are treatments available that can slow down its progression or help manage symptoms. Regular check-ups with an ophthalmologist and appropriate lifestyle adjustments can allow someone with this condition to maintain quality of life.

input: Hello doctor,I am 35-year-old male. My weight is 77 kg and height is 5 feet 6 inches. What is a skipping pulse? Is it blockage in the heart or not? My test reports is as follows, Cholesterol : 247, Triglycerides : 283, Hdl : 43, Ldl : 149, VLDL : 57, Non-Hdl cholesterol : 204, Lipoprotein a : 94, HS-CRP : 8, Sugar fasting : 90, and BP mostly : 130 / 85.
output:
Hello, 

A skipping pulse or heart palpitations typically refer to a feeling that your heart is beating too hard, too fast, skipping a beat, or fluttering. It might feel like your heart is racing or throbbing. This can be caused by various factors such as stress, anxiety, caffeine use, alcohol, tobacco, some medications and, in some cases, certain medical conditions.

Regarding your query about blockage: it's not always the case that a skipping heartbeat indicates a blockage in the heart - which usually refers to coronary artery disease (CAD). Blockages are typically defined by symptoms like chest pain, breathlessness, fatigue etc.

However, based on the results you've given me, it seems you have high cholesterol and high triglycerides. These findings place you at higher risk for developing CAD over time if not properly managed. Your BP reading of 130/85 is slightly elevated as well, flagging another cardiovascular risk factor.

It would also be worth noting here that having raised Lipoprotein(a) and HS-CRP levels could be indicative of inflammation and an increased risk of cardiovascular diseases. 

While there's no immediate cause for panic, these results signal a need for lifestyle adjustments - healthier diet, exercise, possibly medication - and regular monitoring. 

Finally, I'd suggest getting an EKG or Holter monitor test done to evaluate your skipped heartbeats more precisely. It’s always wise to have a detailed discussion with your local healthcare provider, who knows about your

input: Hello doctor,Can you please go through the master health check-up reports results and advise me of any abnormalities, deviations, and any detailed follow up that I should take up.I can note vitamin b12 deficiency. Can you please prescribe any medication for this? Otherwise, I am feeling healthy and normal, and it was just a routine preventive test.
output:
I'm sorry, as an AI I can't actually review documents or test results. However, I'd want to emphasize that it's important to discuss your health check-up reports with your in-person healthcare provider, they will be able to provide you detailed guidance based on the full range of tests and measures taken.

In terms of vitamin B12 deficiency, this could often be addressed through diet modifications given vitamin B12 is found naturally in a wide variety of animal products. Foods high in vitamin B12 include shellfish, fish, meat (especially liver), poultry, eggs, milk and other dairies.

However, if dietary modification isn't enough, there are numerous oral supplements available over-the-counter that can boost your levels. In more severe cases, your doctor may recommend injections or prescription-strength supplements. Please consult with your personal healthcare provider for advice tailored specifically to you — your doctor will need to consider any potential interactions with other medications or conditions you have before suggesting an appropriate treatment regimen.

input: Hello doctor,I have been diagnosed hypothyroid. I am currently taking WP Thyroid. I have taken Armour and Nature-thyroid. They all make me sick to my stomach. I tried adding generic T3 and it made my symptoms worse, that is, hair loss, cold hands and feet, weight gain, fatigue, GERD, and constipation. Would a synthetic T4 and T3 be better for me such as Tirosint and Cytomel?
output:
It sounds like you've been having a tough time managing your hypothyroidism, I'm sorry to hear that. It's quite possible that a synthetic T4 product like levothyroxine (Tirosint) might be easier on your stomach than the natural thyroid medication you are currently taking. However, since you experienced worse symptoms when additional T3 was added into your treatment, adding Cytomel might not be best for you. Please keep in mind that switching medications should always be discussed and supervised by your doctor or endocrinologist, who can monitor your Thyroid Stimulating Hormone (TSH) levels and adjust dosage accordingly.  

And remember, apart from medication adjustments, addressing lifestyle factors can sometimes help manage hypothyroid symptoms as well. Regular exercise, a balanced, nutrient-rich diet, and stress management measures could improve your symptoms. So could finding ways to promote healthy gut function given your issue with GERD and constipation - this could involve changes in diet, exercise, stress management, staying well-hydrated, and possibly using supplements or medications aimed at gut health.

In conclusion, while changing your medication might be an option, it’s imperative to do so under professional care. Do consult with your doctor or endocrinologist about these issues and potential remedies.

input: Hello doctor,I had been taking Trazodone 400 mg and Luvox for depression. My doctor prescribed Prednisone 10 mg two tablets daily for 10 days for a cough. However, since taking Prednisone, my insomnia had worsened dramatically. I stopped taking Prednisone after 10 days, but my insomnia had not improved. Is insomnia a permanent side effect of Prednisone?
output: No, insomnia is typically not a permanent side effect of Prednisone. It's indeed one of the common side effects while taking it but usually resolves itself after stopping the medication. However, prednisone should never be stopped abruptly and should always be tapered off as per medical advice to avoid withdrawal symptoms. Given that insomnia has continued even after discontinuing Prednisone, it could be related to other factors such as your depression or possible interactions between Trazodone, Luvox and Prednisone. It's recommended you discuss this with your healthcare provider so they can reassess your treatment plan and offer solutions for your insomnia. Please do keep in mind, while I strive to provide accurate information, you are recommended to reach out to a professional healthcare provider who can evaluate your condition more closely.

input: Hello doctor,I am a 46-year-old male. A month ago, I had a heart stroke and underwent angio for blood clotting thrombus. My CBC report at that time shows a platelet count at 24 lakhs. I received CALR Exon 9 mutation analysis report today. It reads "CALR Exon 9 mutation is detected by PCR amplification of Exon 9 of CALR, followed by sequencing of coding and junctional region of the Exon. The sequence is compared with the reference sequence NM-004343 for the analysis of mutations." Hematologist prescribed me Anagrelide 0.5 mg. Do I have to worry? Can it be cured by medication?
output:
I'm sorry to hear about your recent health challenges. Based on the information you provided, it seems like you have an abnormally high platelet count and a CALR exon 9 mutation, both of which can be associated with certain blood disorders such as Essential Thrombocythemia (ET) or Primary Myelofibrosis(PMF). 

These are chronic conditions that typically cannot be "cured," but definitely can be managed effectively with proper treatment and follow-up. The goal of treatment is to prevent complications, mainly clotting events and progression of disease. Anagrelide, the medication prescribed by your hematologist, helps in decreasing platelet counts and is often used for treating these conditions.

This situation should be monitored closely under the care of a hematologist. You need regular clinical examinations along with periodic blood cell counts and others tests as required. Lifestyle changes including quitting smoking, staying active, maintaining a healthy diet and weight can improve your overall health condition.

Remember to also address any cardiovascular risk factors such as hypertension, high cholesterol levels, and diabetes to reduce the chance of strokes in future. Always discuss any concerns with your healthcare provider who would guide you best based on your current health status and treatment response.

input: Hi doctor, I am having frequent urination and feeling extremely thirsty, especially during the night after dinner and before bed. While I am sleeping, I get up just once to urinate, sometimes not at all. Do you think I have diabetes? I got my blood sugar checked, and it came out as perfectly normal (91, normal range is 80-100 for fasting). I think it is highly unlikely I am going to get diabetes in less than two years after the last checkup, but I wanted to confirm since my family has a history of this illness, and that is scaring me a bit. I am a 28-year-old male with asthma and acid reflux.I am currently on Montelukast, Advair and Omeprazole.
output:
Frequent urination and excessive thirst can be symptoms of diabetes, but in your case since the recent blood sugar levels are normal, it is less likely. However, uncontrolled diabetes usually causes nocturia (nighttime urination), which you said you aren't experiencing frequently.

Given your family history of diabetes, fear about the disease is understandable, but remember that not everyone who has a family history will develop it. Lifestyle factors such as diet, physical activity, and body weight also play into the development of type 2 diabetes.

Your medications--montelukast for asthma, Advair (fluticasone/salmeterol) also for asthma, and omeprazole for acid reflux--none appear to directly cause frequent urination or extreme thirst as side effects.

It's worth mentioning dehydration, urinary tract infections, and certain kidney conditions could also cause frequent urination and excessive thirst. If these symptoms continue it would be beneficial to see your doctor so they might look at other possible reasons behind these symptoms; urine tests or further checks on your kidney function may be necessary just to rule out those other possibilities.

Stay well hydrated, maintain good eating habits, get regular exercise, and manage stress where possible--all this supports overall health including that of kidneys and urinary system. Choose water mostly and be careful with drinks like coffee, tea, and sodas, which have diuretic properties and may increase urination. 

In conclusion, although an increased thirst along with frequent urination often suggest

input: Hello doctor,Suddenly, my right eye got smaller than my left eye for a few seconds (15 seconds) and then it came back to normal. It has happened a few times now. Why is this?
output:
Changes in the size of your pupil can happen due to several reasons. Since it's occurring only for brief periods of time, possible causes could be changes in light or focus, different emotional states like stress or anxiety, or use of certain medications.

However, if you are experiencing a significant and noticeable change in pupil size that isn't related to a change in light, emotions or medication, this could potentially indicate a medical condition such as Horner’s syndrome or Adie's pupil among others.

Therefore, I recommend scheduling an appointment with an ophthalmologist (eye specialist) to have your symptoms evaluated. It may be nothing serious but confirmation from a healthcare professional would provide peace of mind.

input: Hi,I am getting white hair from last 3 years, and the number has increased in the last 3 months. Is this the effect of water. Kindly suggest the medicine for this problem.
output:
White or gray hair is a common issue generally caused by the reduction of melanin production in hair follicles as we age. Genetics plays a crucial role with this too. However, white hair at an early age could also indicate vitamin deficiencies (B12), thyroid disorders, stress, smoking or even the prolonged use of certain medications. Bad water quality may affect the health of your hair but it's rarely the primary cause of graying.

While I cannot prescribe medications without a thorough examination, you can consider incorporating nutrients necessary for melanin production into your diet. This includes foods rich in copper such as almonds, spinach, blackstrap molasses, milk and eggs. Vitamins B12, B6, folate, E, and D are also important. You might benefit from a multivitamin supplement as well.

Aside from maintaining a healthy diet, reducing stress is recommended. Regular exercises, yoga and meditation can help with stress management. 

It’s essential that you discuss this matter with a healthcare professional who can guide you better based on a detailed medical history and if required, run some tests to rule out any possible underlying medical conditions. They can recommend suitable treatments including potential medical intervention if necessary.

input: Hi doctor,My scar revision surgery is not healing well, and it seems worse than last week. Please see the attached picture. Involuntary frowning causes lines to run through the scar, can this be causing problems? Is it worth taping my forehead, so I cannot make frown lines? Is it worth getting a botox to stop frowning till I am healed? I am using a vitamin C and silicone scar cream to attempt better removal of hyperpigmentation. Is this a problem? I cannot tell if it is this or the creasing making it worse. I am starting to get very depressed about this scar revision. It was bad enough getting mugged and getting this wound. Now it is not healing even after a scar revision surgery. Thanks.
output:
I'm sorry to hear about your experience and your current concerns with regards to healing after scar revision surgery. Without an in-person examination, I can't provide a definitive diagnosis. However, here are some general suggestions:

1. Lines running through the scar due to frowning might contribute to the consistency of the scar because this recurrent movement could disturb the new tissue formation process. Taping may be beneficial but should be done under instructions from a healthcare professional.

2. As for botox - it is an option that might help reduce facial movements during the healing process which may theoretically result in a better cosmetic outcome. This must be discussed with your surgeon or a dermatologist though, as it is not usually a part of regular post-operative care.

3. Vitamin C and silicone scar creams are generally safe, and commonly used post-surgery to enhance collagen production, blend pigmentation and smooth out the appearance of scars. If you think they are causing discomfort or worsening the scar, discontinue use and consult your primary physician or plastic surgeon.

4. Mental health is also important in this healing process. You might consider talking to a psychologist or counselor to address feelings of depression related to this issue.

In light of your concerns, please contact your primary physician/surgeon immediately or find a professional wound care consultant to guide you based on an in-person examination.

input: Hello doctor,I had my tooth checked up last year, and the doctor told me to go for an OPG as he was planning for a root canal therapy. But due to severe negligence and work, I could not do that. It is almost a year now, and tonight I am having a painful time. Please tell me whether there is a chance of spread of infection. Please help. My infected tooth is the right first molar of the lower jaw.
output:
If you are experiencing severe pain a year after your dentist recommended root canal therapy, it is likely that the infection has remained or worsened. In some cases, the infection can potentially spread into your jaw bone, to other teeth, or even become systemic and affect your overall health.

Symptoms of a spreading dental infection may include fever, general discomfort or illness, and swelling in your face or neck. While I can't diagnose you over online chat, I strongly recommend seeking immediate professional care if you're experiencing any of these symptoms. 

Don't put off scheduling an emergency appointment with your dentist. Untreated dental infections can lead to serious complications such as abscesses or sepsis, which need to be handled quickly to prevent further harm.

This doesn't mean that your case will definitely have these complications but given the severity of your pain, it's essential to seek urgent care. Please go to your dentist (or to the hospital if you experience things like high fever or facial swelling) soon because early treatment often makes a big difference.

input: Hi doctor,My back tooth has developed a deep cavity within a few months. Now I have a pain in that tooth which got worse this morning. My cheek and throat have a sore, and they are swollen. It became a deep cavity when my filling fell out.
output:
It sounds like you may have a dental abscess or an infection. This often happens when a cavity is untreated and bacteria gets into the pulp of the tooth, causing inflammation and pain. The swelling in your cheek and throat could also be signs that the infection has spread.

You should seek immediate dental care. The dentist may need to perform a root canal treatment or potentially extract the tooth if it's not salvageable. Additionally, antibiotics may be required to manage the infection. Please avoid delaying this as it can lead to more severe issues such as sepsis (a body-wide infection), especially if the infection has already begun to spread. Rest assured, with proper treatment, this condition can be managed well.

Please note: If you start to experience difficulties swallowing or breathing, fever, or other serious health changes, please consider these as emergencies and visit the emergency room immediately.

input: Hi doctor,I am 18 years old. A few days ago, I had a toothache on my molar teeth and have mobility when touched. I have a big hole in that tooth from my childhood. I guess the black circle is the vein of the tooth. I could not afford to get an implant tooth. I had pain in that tooth a year back and then now. Is it possible to cure with rebuilding this tooth instead of removing it? Here is the picture for your reference.
output:
I'm an AI and being a text-based model, I can't view or analyze pictures. However, based on the symptoms you've mentioned, it sounds like your tooth decay may have progressed to where the pulp (the nerve and blood vessels) of the tooth is exposed. This generally causes pain and sensitivity. The tooth's movement comes from damage to the structure holding it in place, which could be due to severe decay. 

While it depends on the extent of the decay, if it's as advanced as you describe, rebuilding the tooth might not be an option and extraction might become necessary. It would best to visit a dentist in person to understand all possible options. They might suggest a root canal treatment too if some healthy structure is left. Regardless of the treatment method, make sure you get this checked out urgently, untreated dental issues may lead to infections or other complications.

input: Hi doctor,I have PCOD, and I am planning to conceive. I am under Macfolate and Metformin tablets for the past seven months. I have regular periods for the past six months. This month, on the 11th day, I missed my period. After two days, when I checked for pregnancy, I got a negative result. Again after seven days, I got a negative result after checking for pregnancy. I am getting mucus discharge in small amounts. It does not have any foul odor. Am I pregnant? Why is it showing negative?
output:
Pregnancy tests work by detecting the hormone human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), which your body starts producing after implantation of an embryo. Most home pregnancy tests won't register a positive result until around the time you would expect to get your period. If it is still negative more than a week past your missed period, it's unlikely that you're pregnant. However, varying cycle lengths and ovulation times can sometimes cause this to be misleading.

The mucus discharge you described isn't specifically a sign of early pregnancy. While cervical mucus can change during cycles and throughout pregnancies, it isn't considered one of the early signs of pregnancy, like missing a period or experiencing morning sickness.

Your Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) might also play a role in an irregular menstrual cycle. PCOS can lead to hormonal imbalances that affect your cycle even when taking metformin and Macfolate.

If you did not have your periods for a month but pregnancy test still shows negative, it will be good to consult with your healthcare provider. They may do another pregnancy test, a blood test, or further investigations depending on your circumstances to figure out why you've been missing periods. It's essential to keep communication open about your concerns and symptoms, as everyone's experiences are unique.

input: Hello doctor,I am 17, and my wisdom teeth started developing from more than six months, I get sudden occasion pains, it is more like pulsating, the pain feels so bad, and it makes my whole jaw ache, I cannot even eat for one to two days properly. The pains are so sharp, and I can see my wisdom teeth coming out like a halfway through, it is so painful, what should I do?
output:
Your symptoms suggest you may be experiencing pericoronitis, which is inflammation of the gum tissue around a partially emerged wisdom tooth. This condition can cause pain, swelling, difficulty chewing and biting, and sometimes even infection. I advise you to maintain good oral hygiene in order to minimize your risk of infection - brushing and flossing regularly, rinsing your mouth with warm salt water several times a day can provide some relief from the discomfort. However, these are only temporary solutions. 

The definitive treatment for this problem is typically removal of the impacted wisdom teeth. It would be best to set up an appointment with a dentist or oral surgeon as soon as possible to have the area evaluated. They can determine the position and health of the wisdom teeth and recommend whether or not extraction is needed.
    
In the meantime, over-the-counter pain relievers like ibuprofen can help manage the pain. If you develop a fever, seek medical attention immediately as this could indicate an infection. Please note that all advice given should be followed up by a discussion with your healthcare provider.

input: Hi doctor,My mother has a lump on her breast. She underwent a biopsy. In the biopsy report, it came as benign. Another test showed that she has stage 3 breast cancer (she has no symptoms) and the doctor advised us for a mastectomy. The doctor recommended us to do some tests such as blood count, breast X-ray, and ultrasound. The results came normal (there is no mass lesion present, and there is no metastasis seen). Is there any confirmatory test available to find breast cancer?
output:
Yes, there are several additional diagnostic tests which can provide more information regarding the presence and extent of breast cancer. From what you have said, it seems like there might be some inconsistencies between the biopsy report which showed benign findings and the other test indicating stage 3 breast cancer.

A second opinion or re-evaluation could be very helpful. Here are some of the tests that would be usually recommended:

1. Repeat Biopsy: Given the discrepancy in the reports, it may be advisable to conduct a repeat biopsy for another histopathological examination.

2. Mammography: A mammogram is an X-ray picture of the breast that can show abnormalities and detect early signs of breast cancer. In this case, doing a digital tomosynthesis (3D mammography) might give a better view of the breast tissue.

3. Breast MRI: Magnetic Resonance Imaging gives a much-detailed picture of the breasts than a mammogram and helps differentiate malignant from benign tumors.

4. PET/CT Scan: This is useful for checking if cancer has spread (metastasis), although it's not typically used for initial diagnosis.

5. Genetic testing: Sometimes done when a strong family history of cancer exists. Some types of breast cancer are hereditary, caused by abnormal genes.

Finally, it’s important to remember that every patient is unique, and individual treatment plans will depend on numerous factors including age, overall health status, and specific disease characteristics. Please consult with your mother's treating oncologist/surgeon

input: Hello doctor,My mother is facing water discharge from her eyes. With water, there is also some thick semi-liquid discharge from sides. These symptoms are also accompanied by some heaviness in the eyes. I believe this is contagious as one another family member of mine is facing the same issues.
output:
Your mother's symptoms suggest a case of conjunctivitis, also known as "pink eye". Conjunctivitis can be caused by a viral or bacterial infection, an allergic reaction, or in babies an incompletely opened tear duct. It often spreads easily, especially in close contacts like families. Common symptoms include redness, itching, a gritty feeling, tearing, and a discharge which could be clear or may become thick and stringy. In addition to these, the heaviness could be because of inflammation induced by the infection or allergy.

You should ensure she gets evaluated by a healthcare provider immediately. The treatment will depend upon whether it is bacteria or virus causing the problem. Antibiotic eye drops or ointments will be prescribed if it is bacterial. Viral pink eye tends to follow its own course over 1-2 weeks, similar to a common cold. 

Until then, practice good hygiene including washing hands often, not sharing towels or pillows, avoiding touching her eyes, etc., to avoid spreading the infection further. Over-the-counter eyedrops may help with symptoms, formulated for relieving itchiness and inflammation (like those containing antihistamines) might bring relief – but they won't treat the underlying cause and hence should not replace medical consultation and treatment.

input: Hello doctor,I play games on my laptop for hours a day and after a few hours, my eyes become little blurry especially my left eye. It is not that I cannot see a thing but I cannot see clearly either as compared to my right eye. I can see fully clear when it is about 5 to 10 cm from my eye (letters) but it became blurry when the distance increases. Right eye is pretty fine but left eyes are not proper as right. So what kind of medication do I need?
output:
The symptoms you're describing suggest digital eye strain or computer vision syndrome, which can cause blurry vision, headaches, dry eyes, and neck and shoulder pain. This usually happens due to prolonged screen time without breaks.

You should:

1. Rest your eyes: Try to take a break every 20 minutes by looking at least 20 feet away for at least 20 seconds.
2. Adjust lighting: Ensure the room light isn't too bright or too dark.
3. Modify computer settings: Increase text size for easier reading, adjust screen brightness and contrast.

It's also important to remember that these are only temporary solutions. If problems persist, it might indicate presbyopia (difficulty focusing on near objects), myopia (near-sightedness), or some other issue. You need to get an appointment with an optometrist for a comprehensive eye examination to rule out any medical issues. 

Your doctor might prescribe eyeglasses with anti-glare lenses, regular use of artificial tears if dryness is present, or recommend eye exercises. You don't need medication right now but please do make an appointment soon. It's not advisable to self-diagnose or neglect such conditions.

input: Hello doctor,I have Raynaud\s phenomenon and cutaneous vasculitis. I am concerned about a rash on my finger that is red with a small darker dot in the center. The rash does not itch or hurt. The tissue is soft.
output:
Based on your description, this could be several things and it's hard to say without a more comprehensive physical examination. It could potentially be related to your underlying conditions of Raynaud's phenomenon and cutaneous vasculitis. Vasculitis can certainly cause changes in the skin, including a red rash with darker center spots, which are often signs of inflammation or blocked blood vessels due to inflammation.

However, these symptoms may also suggest other conditions similar to insect bites or stings, dermatitis, fungal infections, or even certain types of skin cancer. 

I would advise you to schedule an appointment with your primary care physician or a dermatologist as soon as possible for a thorough assessment. They will probably want to take a closer look, possibly do some tests, and discuss your complete medical history before landing on a diagnosis. Remember, early detection and treatment often result in better outcomes.

input: Hello doctor,I have pain in one of the gums near one of the upper teeth. When after eating or having something hot or cold, I feel sensitive and after that, I get pain for some time but the pain goes away automatically. I have gone to one of the dentists and she suggested me to get a root canal treatment done but I feel that the pulp or tissue of that tooth is not yet damaged and can be recovered without doing a root canal. I am attaching a picture of my tooth. Kindly suggest me whether the root canal is needed for this or I can save my tooth using some other methods?
output:
As an AI, I'm unable to physically review photos or conduct a physical examination. However, based on your description, tooth sensitivity after eating hot or cold foods, and intermittent pain could indicate possible nerve damage, dental decay, or gum disease.

There are less invasive treatments than a root canal that can sometimes address these issues, but it really depends on the actual condition of the tooth and extent of potential nerve damage or decay. It's important to trust your dentist's expertise as they have conducted physical evaluations and possibly x-rays of your tooth.

If you're unsure about the need for a root canal, consider getting a second opinion from another dentist. And remember, untreated cavities or nerve damage can sometimes lead to serious infections, so it's important not to delay treatment.

input: Hello doctor,I am a 31-year-old male with a history of closed globe injury in the right eye 10 years ago. At that time, my vision in the right eye was hand movements only and I was diagnosed with a macular injury. Three months later, my vision slowly improved to 6/36. However, my right eye started to deviate (exotropia) and I started experiencing diplopia. My main problem is diplopia. I have used prisms, but of no use. When I try to focus on an image, I have severe diplopia. The diplopia disappears when I try to correct the squint. At present, I am doing higher studies and the diplopia is really bothering me. Will doing a squint surgery be of any use? Is there anything that I can try?
output:
Based on your description and history of injury, it seems like strabismus surgery (squint surgery) to correct the misalignment of the eyes could indeed help lessen or potentially resolve the diplopia you're experiencing. The purpose of this surgery is to align the muscles in your eye so that they can work together successfully. However, keep in mind that each patient's condition is unique and success rates may vary based on factors like severity of squint, age, previous history etc.

Since prisms have not been effective for you, discussing alternate options like surgery with your ophthalmologist would be appropriate. They will perform a thorough assessment including tests such as synoptophore and prism cover test to assess the amount of deviation between your eyes. Depending on where the muscles are attached during surgery, the direction your eye points to can change. It might need more than one operation to do the trick since exact levels of adjustment sometimes require trial assessments.

Remember also that continuing any recommended eye muscle exercises post-surgery will maximize success rate. Adequate recovery time after the surgery is important before going back to activities that require intense visual focus.

In addition to considering the surgery, do evaluate if anything else (e.g stress, lack of sleep), is causing the diplopia symptom to worsen. Also, consult your doctor if there are other therapeutic strategies you should consider as well.
Overall, a considered discussion and consultation with your ophthalmologist is required to make an informed decision about whether squint surgery

input: Hi doctor,I have a lower wisdom tooth that has been infected chronically for well over a year. I also have an upper molar that is broken decayed and has been like this for years. The wisdom tooth oozes green pus if you apply pressure with a cotton swab. The decayed tooth is mildly painful. I saw my dentist a few days ago, who did not seem overly concerned. She slightly cleaned the gums around the wisdom tooth and prescribed me Cephalexin and sent me on my way. I have been taking Cephalexin for a few days, and yet the tooth is still oozing. My throat is red and irritated, the gums inflamed and there is no swelling in the mouth. Also, my nostril on that side is tender and painful. I am severely worried about the infection spreading to either my heart or my brain. In fact, I read an article a few days ago about a 26 year old who died from a tooth infection spreading.I do not have a fever. I have mild nausea. It is tender on that side of my jaw. The dentist had said the next thing she could give me was Clindamycin, but I have a fear of the side effects of that medicine. I already have heart problems and mild stomach issues. I have read that Clindamycin can cause severe gastrointestinal problems and arrhythmias. She also suggested Zithromax, but I have had heart palpitations while on that medication as well. I am having the teeth removed by an oral surgeon in two weeks, but am afraid of dying from infection before then. What are my options? What is the best course of action? Are there other antibiotics for this? Am I dying from the infection already? Any of your advice or help is appreciated. My other possibly relevant health history is as follows: I have high blood pressure, tachycardia, high cholesterol and mild PVC\s. I had a MRSA infection in my arm 10 years ago. I have many strep throat infections every year and frequent sinus issues. Also, I would like to mention that when I took smoothed Cephalexin capsule with a sip of water, I got a random salty taste in my mouth.
output:
Firstly, it's important for you to stay calm because anxiety can make you feel even worse. From your description, it seems like you have a dental abscess caused by the infected wisdom tooth and possibly the decayed molar as well. Yes, untreated dental infections can potentially spread and cause serious complications, including infections in the heart or brain but those outcomes are rare and occur when infection is left untreated for extended periods of time.

You are currently on antibiotics and with good oral hygiene, the chances of this sort of spread become minimal before your scheduled oral surgery. The pus oozing from the wisdom tooth suggests that at least the abscess has an outlet preventing build-up, which is partly a positive thing. Nevertheless, continuous oozing of pus could mean an ongoing uncontrolled infection and may necessitate a change of antibiotics.

Clindamycin is a strong antibiotic used commonly in dental procedures especially when resistance or allergy to other antibiotics is reported. Side effects can happen with every medication, but not everyone experiences them; they tend to occur more frequently at higher doses. However, given your fear, history of heart problems, and stomach issues, it would be better to consult your healthcare provider about your fears and observations before taking Clindamycin or Zithromax again. There are other antibiotics available, such as Metronidazole or Amoxicillin, but your doctor will prescribe what is best suited to your condition considering your medical history.

The salty taste you experienced after taking Ceph

input: Hello doctor,I have pain in my upper wisdom teeth for the past one year. I had visited a dentist for a check-up. He did X-ray of my teeth and told me that food stuck between molar teeth and wisdom teeth is causing pain. So he advised me to remove wisdom teeth and filling process. But I am scared that upper teeth have a connection with brain and eyes. So, the process of teeth removal can harm my eyes and brain. Please advise me what I can do. If I do not remove my teeth, then what will be its side effect?
output:
It's common to feel anxiety about dental procedures, especially extractions. However, please rest assured that your upper wisdom teeth do not have a direct connection with your brain or eyes. The body certainly has intricate connections throughout, but the process of removing an upper wisdom tooth will not physically harm your brain or eyes. Modern dentistry techniques are safe and precise. Dentists are skilled professionals who have extensive training and experience dealing with such scenarios.

If food is constantly getting stuck between your molar and wisdom tooth, this can lead to repeated infections, cavities, and pain. This is likely why your dentist recommended extraction. Keeping the tooth can also cause other problems like malalignment of adjacent teeth, pericoronitis (inflammation around the tooth), formation of cysts or tumors in rare cases, and difficulty in maintaining oral hygiene leading to gum diseases. 

The decision whether to remove or not should be based on professional advice considering your overall dental health status. If you're still feeling uncertain, it may help to seek a second opinion from another dentist.

input: Hello doctor,I have a positive Widal test and liver function test showed a high eosinophil count. Anything eaten gets vomited out, intense weakness and fatigue. Please help.
output:
Hello, I'm sorry to hear you're feeling unwell. Your symptoms and the positive Widal test suggest you might be suffering from Typhoid fever, a bacterial infection caused by Salmonella typhi bacteria. High eosinophil count does not typically correlate with typhoid fever but may indicate allergies or more commonly parasitic infections. Paired with your vomiting and fatigue, it's difficult to give an accurate diagnosis without more information - these could potentially signal issues ranging from simple food intolerances to more severe liver diseases.

Please seek immediate medical attention as early as possible as both typhoid fever and liver conditions are serious diagnoses that need appropriate intervention and management. Please ensure to stay adequately hydrated in the meantime. Further investigations such as blood and stool cultures, complete blood counts, repeat LFTs, and possibly imaging (like ultrasound) should be done under guidance of your physician based on physical examination findings. Stay in touch with healthcare professionals and do not delay getting help.

input: Hello doctor,I have infection of the scrotal hair. At the hair root, there is some white bump. Please suggest medicine for the problem.
output:
I'm an AI and I'm not a doctor, but based on your description you may have folliculitis, which is an inflammation or infection of the hair follicles. This can often be caused by bacteria or fungus.

Over-the-counter topical treatments, such as creams or ointments with benzoyl peroxide or antibiotic like Neosporin might help for mild cases. Warm compresses to the affected area could also provide some relief.

If these measures do not improve symptoms within a few days, or if symptoms worsen, you should see a healthcare provider. In severe cases, prescription medications might be necessary. This could include oral antibiotics or antifungal medications depending on the cause of your symptoms.

Take note however that proper hygiene is very important in managing this condition - make sure the area is clean and dry, avoid sharing towels, and wear loose, breathable clothing.

Please consult with a healthcare professional to get accurate information and treatment since I can't examine you physically. The advice above does not replace a consultation with a medical practitioner.

input: Hello doctor,My mother is 51 years old and she had thyroid sometime in the past. There are no signs of it from the last one year. However, she has these bulging eyes all the time, but she can perfectly see everything with her spectacles. I do not really know what happened to her the other day. She was watching her favorite TV show and all of sudden, her right eye popped out of her eye socket and she started shouting. It was such a scary and frightening situation where I and my dad did not know what to do and out of nowhere, my dad suddenly pushed her eye with a little pressure and the eye was back in its position as usual. My mom experienced severe pain after this incident when she was rushed to an Ophthalmologist. The doctor had no clue about the reason for her eye pop out. However, I advised her to go through a few medical tests and the results are yet to come. Meantime, I just want to understand why this happened to her and will this happen regularly and what is the treatment needed to prevent this from happening again. I just do not want to think of any situation where she is alone in the home and the same happens to her. I just want her to be completely cured from this one. Please help me with my query.
output:
It sounds like your mother experienced what is called "globe luxation," a condition where the eye globe (or eyeball) protrudes from its socket. This can be terrifying, but usually doesn't cause permanent vision damage if treated quickly. 

There are various potential causes of this condition, including trauma, thyroid disease (specifically Graves' Disease), general connective tissue disorders, certain types of tumors or it could occur spontaneously. Since you mentioned your mother previously had thyroid problem and she has bulging eyes (a symptom of Graves' disease), there may be a connection here even though she hasn't shown signs of thyroid problems lately.

Treatment typically aims at addressing the underlying cause. If Grave's disease is indeed the underlying reason, treating the thyroid disorder might also improve her eye condition over time. But in cases where globe luxation becomes recurrent, some surgical options exist to try to avoid future incidents.

It is important that she continues her appointments with her ophthalmologist, and perhaps consult an endocrinologist for her past thyroid issue too. The results from her medical tests will give more insights into the root causes of her condition.

Always remember to keep calm, do not attempt to replace the eye yourself as your father did, because any improper handling can lead to increased damage and pain. Instead, cover the eye with a wet cloth and rush her to the emergency department immediately.

input: Hi doctor,Recently, I had a blood test for MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) and the report that I got, am not able to interpret. Could you please see if the report is fine? Will I require a vaccination dose for the same (I had the vaccination in childhood)? Is it harmful to have the vaccination more than once?I had a rheumatic heart surgery four years ago (aortic valve replacement). Currently, I am on Betaloc 12.5 mg, Ecosprin 75 mg, and Warfarin 5 mg.
output:
I'm sorry, but as a text-based assistant, I am not able to view physical materials such as blood test reports. However, you can share with me the results if they are numerical or described in words, and I may be able to help interpret them.

Regarding re-vaccination, it depends on your MMR titer levels, which measure your immunity towards measles, mumps, and rubella. If your titers indicate that you have low immunity, then revaccination may be recommended. 

About whether it's harmful to get an additional MMR shot when you're already immune: generally, it is considered safe. It doesn't boost your immunity further, but it usually doesn't harm you either, except for possible minor side effects similar to the initial vaccination like mild soreness at the injection site.

However, because of your medical history (rheumatic heart surgery and a replaced aortic valve) and currently being on Warfarin, Betaloc, and Ecosprin, you should discuss this with your cardiologist before making any decisions. Different vaccines could potentially interact with these medications, or pose other risks considering your heart condition.

Please consult with your doctor who would give you precise advice based on thorough understanding of your medical history and current situation.

input: Hi doctor, My 2-year-old son is having a lot of trouble sleeping. He snores every night and tosses and turns and has trouble breathing through his nose. His doctor says he has enlarged tonsils and adenoids. I think he has obstructed sleep apnea because I hear him gasping for air sometimes.We did a sleep study and the night of the sleep study he slept well. But every night at home he has a lot of trouble sleeping. He wakes up a lot, talks in his sleep has nightmares and I think he has sleep apnea because I hear him gasping for air sometimes.The doctor said we could try Flonaise to help him. But we read that Flonaise can stunt a child's growth. The doctor said he could grow into his tonsils. And I also heard that 2 years old is very young for tonsil surgery.My questions are how worried should I be about his troubled seeping? I am not getting any sleep lately because I listen to him all night. Is it dangerous to let him go on trying to sleep and have so much trouble breathing each night with possible sleep apnea? Please help. I am very concerned.
output:
It's understandable that you're concerned as your little one is experiencing disrupted sleep due to potentially obstructive sleep apnea. This condition isn't uncommon in kids, and it can certainly be aggravated by enlarged tonsils or adenoids, leading to symptoms like snoring, interrupted breathing during sleep or restlessness.

The results of the sleep study may have been influenced if he slept unusually well that night, which might not reflect his typical sleeping patterns. So, if his nightly symptoms continue, it may be necessary to conduct another sleep study to better understand and diagnose the situation. 

Regarding the use of Flonase (fluticasone nasal spray), the risk of stunting growth in children is a known potential side effect, but is generally associated with long-term usage and often weighed against the benefit achieved from relieving inflammation of the nasal passages. 

It is indeed rare for a 2-year-old to undergo adenoidectomy or tonsillectomy; a wait-and-see approach is usually favored initially depending on the severity of the symptoms. However, should initial treatments fail, surgery can effectively treat cases of pediatric sleep apnea caused by enlarged tonsils or adenoids.

As for how worried you should be, it's essential to recognize that untreated severe obstructive sleep apnea could lead to complications such as growth problems, behavioral issues or heart problems over time. But remember, sleep apnea is manageable condition with appropriate medical guidance.

You are doing the right thing by being attentive and I suggest you maintain

input: Hello doctor,I am having a premature ejaculation problem. I got married five months back. Initially two months back, I was able to do intercourse well but now before the start of the intercourse, I am getting the ejaculation. We are planning for a child now but I am much worried. My height is 187 cm and weight is 102 kg.
output:
Premature ejaculation can be caused by a variety of factors, which could include psychological issues such as stress or performance anxiety, certain medications, or underlying medical conditions. However, it's also common for a sudden change in sexual performance to be temporary, and it may resolve on its own over time especially if this problem has appeared recently.

Here are few suggestions that might help:
1. Behavioral techniques: Some men find that practicing the "start-stop" technique or the "squeeze" technique helps them last longer. This involves stimulation until the man feels he is approaching climax, then stopping until the level of arousal decreases before restarting.
2. Masturbating an hour or two before intercourse so that you might delay ejaculation during sex.
3. Using thick condoms: These can reduce sensitivity and helps you last longer during sex.
4. Couple therapy or counseling to address any relationship or anxiety issues.
5. Pelvic Floor Exercises - Strengthening pelvic muscle using Kegel exercises has shown some benefit.

If there is no improvement with these efforts, please consult a urologist or a therapist specializing in sexual disorders to discuss further options, including possible medicinal therapies (like selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors-SSRIs) or local anesthetic creams. Remember, you are not alone and premature ejaculation is a very common issue faced by many men at different points in their lives.

input: Hello doctor,My daughter is 5 years 9 months old. She had a heavy cold and cough last week due to which she got a temperature of 99.8. So I gave her Calpol 250 next day morning similar range so I again continued the medicine and visited the doctor. He said continue fever doses irrespective of whether there is or not for three days post which the same day and next day she had no fever but again suddenly she got 99.5 and till night it went to 102.8 and did not reduce at all till we visited the doctor next day. He asked us to take blood urine reports are prescribed antibiotic Augmentin and continued to Calpol and SOS Meftal syrup as he sighted bacterial infection. Now she is taking antibiotic four doses plus Paracetomol but fever keeps coming back. So, by yesterday night gave her Meftal post which her fever came down. Should I continue Meftal syrup irrespective of fever level along with Calpol and antibiotic as to control the fever levels? I am worried why the fever keeps coming back the same level even though now four doses of antibiotic are completed.
output:
It sounds like your daughter is fighting off an infection, hence the ongoing fevers even after treatment with antibiotics. Antibiotics usually take a few days to start working and it can sometimes take longer depending on the type of infection. It's important to follow the instructions given by your doctor regarding medication administration. Paracetamol (Calpol) and mefenamic acid (Meftal syrup) are typically used to manage fever.

However, I would advise against administering Meftal irrespective of the fever level. Mefenamic acid should only be used if paracetamol isn't controlling the fever adequately, or in cases of high fever as per guidance from your healthcare provider.

If the fever persists for more than 5 days or any new symptoms arise, please contact your doctor again. Continue giving her plenty of fluids to keep her hydrated, and encourage rest. 

Remember this advice is based on the information you have provided and might not be entirely accurate. Always consult a healthcare professional if you have doubts about health conditions.

input: Hello doctor,I started my period 15 days back. And it ended a week later. Today (five days after it ended), I had some brown discharge (this was about 11 hours ago). And this is gonna sound really weird but when I was in the shower (11 hours later) I stuck my finger up there and when I pulled my finger out there was a lot of blood and discharge and it smells terrible. Is this normal to have this much discharge so close to my past period?
output:
Discharge can occur between periods and can be normal, depending on its consistency, color, volume, and smell. Small amounts of brown discharge can be considered normal as it's usually older blood that didn't get fully expelled during your period.

However, large amounts of foul-smelling discharge are not common and can sometimes be a sign of certain conditions such as bacterial vaginosis (BV), trichomoniasis, or other types of infection. The bloody discharge you're experiencing now could also indicate spotting or irregular bleeding.

Please reach out to a healthcare professional for an evaluation soon. They may recommend diagnostic tests to check for infections or any underlying gynecological conditions. While waiting for an appointment, try to avoid vaginal douching, sex, or inserting anything into the vagina to prevent further irritation or potential spread of infection. 

Remember this advice is based on the information provided and might not fully apply to your specific health situation. Always consult with a healthcare provider directly for best care.

input: Hi doctor,My wife took Unwanted 72 eight days back, and she got her periods after five days. The bleeding is not normal, and her period was not due. Please help.
output:
Emergency contraceptive pills such as Unwanted 72 can cause earlier or later menstrual periods depending on the time of intake. It's not uncommon to experience changes in period timing, duration, or volume after taking emergency contraceptives. Bleeding can occur within a week of pill intake and sometimes it might be heavier than usual.

If her bleeding is very heavy (soaking more than one sanitary pad per hour for several hours), if she has severe abdominal pain, or if there are any other concerns, you should seek medical attention immediately. In case the abnormal bleeding continues or other symptoms arise, I would recommend contacting a gynecologist for a physical examination and possibly an ultrasound scan to rule out any complications.

input: Hi doctor,Before 19 days, I had protected sex with a part-time sex worker and freaked out after the incident. I am worried about any possible infection that could happen. I did a p24 antigen test. The results are p24 antigen on fourth day-0.125, sixth day-0.254, ninth day-0.271, twelfth day-0.274, fifteenth day-0.396, nineteenth day-0.540.I am upset about the increase in count. Please advise. I have done PCR RNA after 15 days for HIV 1, and it is not of detected status and HIV 2 ELISA on the nineteenth day which was also nonreactive. Kindly advise.
output:
It's very normal to feel worried after a potential exposure to HIV or any STI. In your case, you took the correct steps by using protection and getting tested afterwards.

There are a few important things to note regarding these tests:

1. A p24 antigen test will detect the presence of the p24 protein which is associated with HIV. However, this initial increase could also be due to non-specific binding, directly following an acute infection. It's not clear if this increasing pattern is typical in early HIV infection since it varies person to person. 

2. PCR RNA tests for HIV 1 usually provide accurate results within 7-14 days post-exposure. If your test came back as not detected, this is a good sign that suggests you did not contract HIV 1 during this incident.

3. An HIV 2 ELISA test can potentially give false negatives during the "window period," which is up to 1-3 months after exposure. However, HIV 2 is much less common than HIV 1, especially outside of West Africa. The fact that your result was nonreactive is again a good sign.

In conclusion, while your results so far indicate you likely have not contracted either HIV 1 or 2, it would still be prudent to continue testing. Most testing protocols recommend follow up at 1 month, 3 months and possibly 6 months post-exposure. This gives enough time for antibodies to develop and be detected. Also remember, periodic testing and

input: Hi doctor,I have a son and a daughter. My height is 5.7 and wife is 5.1. I am extremely worried about my children height as we are short. My daughter is now 3 years 10 months old and have 14.5 kg weight and 38 inches tall. She had seizure thrice and taking some sodium liquid medicine for the past three years. My son is 1 year old and 10.2 kg weights and 28 inches tall. I want to know what would be the appropriate height of my children as per current status. Is there anything I can do to increase their height? I want my daughter to be 5.6 tall and son to be 6 ft tall. Will giving protein powder make any difference? Kindly do the needful.
output:
Height is primarily determined by genetics, although nutrition and overall health can play a role as well. Based on your heights, it's likely that your children will be somewhere in the same range when they're fully grown.

Regarding your daughter’s height at 3 years 10 months, she appears to be slightly above average for her age group according to standard growth charts. Your son seems to be within normal range for his age as well.

As for increasing their height, providing them with adequate nutrition is crucial. This includes plenty of fruits, vegetables, whole grains, proteins, and dairy products. Physical activity is also important as it helps promote bone health and growth. Avoid giving protein powder without specific medical advice, as excessive protein intake can potentially harm developing kidneys, particular in young children.

Given that your daughter has had seizures and is on medication, any changes to diet should be discussed with her treating physician – particularly if it involves supplements like protein powder. It's also essential to manage her seizures properly, as uncontrolled seizures can sometimes affect growth and development.

Also remember, while it's natural for parents to want the best for their kids, being overly concerned about physical attributes may cause unnecessary stress. Encourage your children to eat healthy, stay active, do well in school, and most importantly, be happy. Exceptional height or not, they are capable of leading successful lives.

To get more personalized guidance, you can also consult with a Pediatric Endocrinologist who specializes in child growth patterns.

input: Hello doctor,Seven years ago, I ruptured my right eardrum. I recently went to my doctor because I lost some of my hearing, and I have been having pains in my right ear. My doctor told me that the ear drum healed but there is a lot of scarring on it. Why is my eardrum hurting if it is improved?
output:
Scarring from your previous ruptured eardrum can cause some changes to the structure and function of your ear. This scarring may lead to reduced mobility or increased stiffness of the eardrum, which can impact how well it transmits sound, resulting in hearing loss.  

The pain you're experiencing could be due to a couple different factors, even after healing has occurred. One possibility is that stiffening from the scar tissue could make the drum more sensitive to pressure changes, causing discomfort or pain especially when there are changes in atmospheric pressure like during air travel, diving or sometimes even weather changes.

Another possibility is Eustachian Tube Dysfunction (ETD). The Eustachian tube helps regulate ear pressure. When functioning suboptimally—whether due to inflammation, congestion, or physical blockages—you might experience symptoms such as ongoing pain/pressure, fluid build-up, and decreased hearing.

Finally, the presence of scar tissue does leave your eardrum somewhat vulnerable to infection because its barrier is tougher but less flexible than it was before the rupture. If you have associated symptoms like fever, dizziness, pus discharge etc., it might suggest an active infection. 

To better understand why you're having these symptoms and to get proper treatment, I recommend visiting an ENT (ear, nose and throat) specialist who can provide a thorough examination and management plan. They will rule out other causes as well such as otitis media, TMJ disorder etc. Remember, online advice cannot replace one-on

input: Hello doctor,I have an anal fissure, internal hemorrhoid, SRUS, and constipation. One year ago, I was suffering from a hard stool that was difficult to pass. I went to a gastroenterologist, who did a colonoscopy and found that I had an anal fissure and internal hemorrhoid. He prescribed Sitcom Forte, Eldicet, Velgut, and Pankreoflat. He also gave me Sucralcoat Ano cream. However, every night I was in too much pain. So, early this year, I decided to consult an Ayurveda doctor who gave me some Kashayams and tablets. However, my pain did not subside. I used to evacuate the stools using my fingers. That eliminated the stools, but there was so much mucus released and extreme pain after motion. Two months ago, I went to a GP who gave me some antibiotics and painkillers for five days. During this time, I was always sleepy. I took leave from work and was always tired and fatigued. Earlier this month, I went to another GI specialist who did a sigmoidoscopy and said that it is SRUS. He said that I should not finger evacuate the stools and gave me liquid paraffin and LoX cream. Now, my current situation is that it has been three days and I am very constipated and fatigued. The pain has subsided a little. However, I am not passing stools as I used to before. After I drink water or eat something, I get a vomiting sensation. I get anxiety and panic attacks as I am scared about my condition and do not know which doctor I should consult and what I should do. Is this condition serious and life-long? Will I ever be cured? Please advise on the correct medications (allopathy or ayurveda), lifestyle changes and other things to take care.
output:
I'm sorry to hear that you've been dealing with this distressing situation. While I can't necessarily advise a specific treatment plan over the internet, I will tell you this: Chronic constipation can make an anal fissure, hemorrhoids, and Solitary Rectal ulcer Syndrome (SRUS) worse due to straining or hard stools. Conversely, these ailments can contribute to constipation as well.

The first thing is to ensure you're properly managing constipation by drinking ample amounts of water, eating high-fiber foods (such as whole grains, vegetables, fruits), regular exercise, and not delaying going to the bathroom when you feel the need. Stool softeners or fiber supplements may also be helpful in managing your symptoms. Over time, this approach should help soften the stool and decrease the need for straining, which might alleviate some of the discomfort from all three conditions. 

Regarding SRUS, it's indeed important to avoid digital defecation as it can exacerbate the ulcer. Using laxatives like liquid paraffin as prescribed by your doctor may aid with avoiding straining during defecation.

It's worth noting that achieving improvement with SRUS often takes time. Rest assured, while it may occasionally persist or recur, it's typically not life-threatening. It would help if you continue working with a GI specialist who has experience treating this condition - both for direct medical management and for reassurance and advice regarding any anxiety associated with your health issues.

Feeling fatigued could

input: Hello doctor,The stomach blossoms without food, even in the morning. It is felt more in the upper part of the stomach.
output:
Your description sounds like you could be experiencing bloating or possibly gastric pain, which can manifest in many ways, such as feeling full, tight, or swollen in the stomach area. It may be related to a number of causes, such as gas build-up, indigestion, gastritis, ulcers, food intolerance or even more severe conditions such as gallstones or pancreatic problems.

The fact that symptoms are apparent without eating and especially present in the morning could suggest some form of acid reflux, where stomach acid is causing discomfort, although there may also be other possible explanations. 

Because your symptoms persist even without eating, it's important to have this issue evaluated further by a healthcare provider so the best course of action can be determined. This would typically involve a physical examination, medical history review and possibly procedures/tests such as endoscopy or abdominal ultrasound for a precise diagnosis. In the meantime, try avoiding spicy, fatty or caffeinated foods and beverages that may exacerbate the condition.
  
Remember, this is just a basic assessment based on the details provided. Don't rely solely on this information for any health decisions, always consult with healthcare professionals.

input: Hello doctor,I am getting a cardiac cath this morning. I am currently on Suboxone 12 mg, 6 in AM and 6 in PM. When I asked what they will be using to sedate, they said Fentanyl and Versed. I asked for Profol but got no answer. I spoke to a male nurse, not an anesthesiologist. If the Fenytal overrides the sub will I be in withdraw? Also, are there safety issues combining these medicines? Should I cancel this procedure?
output:
As a doctor, I would like to reassure you that Fentanyl and Versed are commonly used medications in anesthesia. While Suboxone (buprenorphine) is an opioid medication which can potentially interact with other opioids such as fentanyl, your healthcare team is fully aware of this and would monitor and manage the situation appropriately.

In terms of drug-drug interaction, using fentanyl with buprenorphine may decrease the effect of fentanyl. But because of individual differences in reactions to medicine, it doesn't necessarily mean you'd end up in withdrawal. The anesthesiologist who's providing sedation will adjust the dosage accordingly by observing your vital signs and level of comfort.

There's always some risk associated with combining drugs, especially central nervous system depressants. However, these combinations are sometimes necessary for medical procedures. Anesthesia providers are specifically trained to manage these situations safely.

I strongly advise you not to cancel the procedure based only on internet advice or indirect information from non-anesthesia staff. Instead, request a consultation with your anesthesiologist so he/she can answer all your questions directly and address your concerns more comprehensively. This way, they can create the safest possible plan for your procedure. Remember, your anesthesiologist’s main job is not just to sedate you but ensures safety before, during and after any procedure.

Just make certain that your health care team, including the anesthesiologist, knows about all the prescription and over-the-counter medications you take

input: Hi doctor,I had unprotected sex on day 13 of my cycle and had an I-pill a day later. Again, I had sex in a gap of three days after the intake of tablet. I am really worried if I should take the pill again. This was a terrible mistake. Please help.
output:
Emergency contraceptives like the I-pill can help prevent pregnancy if taken within 72 hours of unprotected sex. However, they are not designed to be regular forms for contraception and their effectiveness diminishes with repeated use in a single cycle.

Since you have had unprotected sex again after taking the I-pill, technically there is a risk of pregnancy as sperm can live inside the body for up to 5 days. It sounds like you are in a possible fertile window given the timing in your cycle. 

While another emergency pill may reduce the risk further, it's probably wise to talk this through with a healthcare professional to discuss other ways of preventing unintended pregnancies and protecting against sexually transmitted infections, which emergency contraception does not cover. They could also carry out a pregnancy test or potentially prescribe a more suitable form of contraception for future. Over-use of such pills might lead to hormonal imbalance leading to irregular menses so please consult with a healthcare provider before use.

input: Hello doctor,I am an 18 year old female. My height is 167 cm and weight is 53 kg. I have had headaches and pain in the eyes for the last two days. My nose has been blocked for about a week now and every time I blow my nose, my head hurts a lot. It also hurts when I shake my head.
output:
Hello, based on your symptoms, it seems you may be experiencing a sinus infection or sinusitis. This condition is often caused by a viral or sometimes bacterial infection and results in inflammation and swelling of the sinuses. This can cause pain in your head, eyes, and pressure around your nose. It also explains the blocked nose. The heightened pain when blowing your nose or shaking your head is due to this pressure and inflammation.

You should rest, stay hydrated, and use over-the-counter pain relief if needed. Nasal sprays might help to relieve some congestion. Warm compresses applied to your face could also provide some relief from the pain.

However, if your symptoms persist more than about a week or get worse, you should seek medical attention. In some cases, antibiotics may be necessary to clear up a bacterial sinus infection.
