Regarding your cystocele repair, I'm sorry to hear that the initial surgery did not result in anticipated improvements. It would be valuable to discuss this with your gynaecologist. With regards to surgical options moving forward, a pessary could potentially help provide support for your bladder. In some cases, surgeons may recommend a second surgery, often referred to as a revision surgery, although this decision is typically made after careful consideration of potential benefits and risks.

If left untreated, it's possible that over time you may notice increased difficulties with bladder function, such as incontinence, or recurrent UTI's. There can also be discomfort during sexual intercourse, or pressure/discomfort in the vaginal area from the prolapse of the bladder. Every woman's body reacts differently though, so it varies per individual.

As always, please follow up directly with

input: Hi doctor,I have been with the same partner for 8 years now. During these all 8 years I have had several UTIs with some leading to severe kidney infections. Last week after almost two years of not having a UTI I felt the horrible symptoms again. When going to the doctors UTI urine test came back positive. The doctor prescribed me seven days Nitrofurantoin antibiotics which cleared the pain and seemed gone entirely. Unfortunately two days later, the symptoms came back (please note that I had sex with my partner the day before) with burning sensation when urinating and painful when standing with the need to go toilet every 2 to 3 minutes. I went back to the clinic the same day to get it checked and take more antibiotics.But to my surprise, the urine test came back clear for UTI, and my symptoms disappeared. Then the doctor advised me to get tested for Chlamydia as the symptoms can sometimes be mistaken to be UTI. I have been diagnosed with Chlamydia at the beginning of this same relationship and was treated for it. My partner was also tested, but his results came back negative. Is it possible that the treatment that I had for Chlamydia 8 years ago did not clear it entirely and this lead to several UTIs and kidney infections? And also, would the antibiotics for UTI clear Chlamydia? Thank you in advance for your help.
output:
Though it's possible to be re-infected with Chlamydia after treatment if exposed, the antibiotic you were prescribed for your UTIs, nitrofurantoin, is not typically effective against Chlamydia. The Chlamydia bacterium usually requires different antibiotics such as azithromycin or doxycycline.

If you were correctly treated for Chlamydia 8 years ago (assuming you took all of the medication as prescribed), you should have been cleared of the infection. However, a reinfection could have occurred if your partner was not effectively treated, even if his test came back negative later on. Chlamydia can sometimes present asymptomatically, meaning without symptoms, especially in men.

An unresolved Chlamydia infection could cause recurring urinary tract infections, but these cases are very rare. Most often, frequent UTIs are caused by issues such as an abnormal urinary tract structure, diabetes, or changes due to menopause in women.

It would be prudent to go ahead and get tested for Chlamydia given your previous history and current symptoms—even if only to rule out that potential diagnosis—and follow up with your physician regarding your recurrent UTIs. If they continue to occur frequently despite adequate treatment, you may need further assessment for any underlying conditions. Your doctor might also recommend prophylactic (preventive) antibiotics following sexual intercourse, as sex can sometimes introduce bacteria into the urethra and lead to UTIs.

input: Hello doctor,I am 42 years old and have been diagnosed with multiple uterine fibroids. Two of them are a little more than 3 cm at different places in the uterus. In the past, I have been operated for endometriosis level 4. As usual, the gynecologist is suggesting a hysterectomy. But since I am in my perimenopausal phase, can the fibroids shrink with medication? I have been suggested Fibroease.
output:
Fibroids are known to shrink and symptoms improve following menopause, due to declining levels of estrogen and progesterone. However, if your fibroids are causing significant symptoms, such as heavy or painful periods, discomfort, or anemia, then waiting may not be the best option for you.

The medication you mentioned, Fibroease, I am unfamiliar with (may not be FDA approved) and therefore cannot offer specific advice on its efficacy or safety. Generally however, medications used to treat fibroids, like Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone Agonists (GnRHa), work by lowering your estrogen levels and thereby could cause temporary relief from fibroid-related symptoms, but they typically do not remove them entirely.

If you really want to avoid surgery and your fibroids are not causing significant problems currently, I suggest looking into other management approaches.

Before making decision ask the opinion from 1-2 more doctors in order to ensure no stone is left unturned when considering all possible options. Also, every treatment option carries some side effects; knowing about those (related to fibroids treatment) before opting a method is crucial.
Always remember it's your body, so take time and choose what suits best for you and your lifestyle. And always talk with a qualified healthcare professional before making any decisions about your health.

input: Hello doctor,My daughter is 18 months of age. She was born at 38 weeks due to placenta failure and oxygen issues. She was 5 lbs 10 ounces at birth and was healthy (did not have to stay in the NICU). She hit all of her milestones in terms of rolling over, crawling and walking (walked at 14.5 months), but is a toe walker. Her left leg (to us) is weaker than her right and her left leg does not bend as much as her right leg. She began to speak around 10 months of age then her speech left. We came to find out she had chronic fluid and a month back she had tubes placed. I am hearing more vowel and consonants now but no true words yet. She makes fine eye contact. Her non-verbal communication is good. She responds to her name but not always. She is beginning to learn more of what we are saying, she plays with some toys, is not terribly social. We are thinking that she may be on the autism spectrum and we have an evaluation soon to determine that. But my question is, could this be cerebral palsy?
output:
While it's possible that your daughter's symptoms could indicate Cerebral Palsy (CP), the specific symptoms you've mentioned — toe walking, a weaker and less bendable left leg, loss of speech although now improving since getting tubes for chronic fluid, inconsistent response to her name — are seen in many conditions, including autism. 

However, an important point is, CP often involves some sort of issue at birth or shortly thereafter that indicates injury to the brain (such as low oxygen levels). It doesn't sound like any of those were present with your daughter if she was otherwise healthy after birth despite being born early due to placenta failure.

Diagnosis of CP would rely heavily on physical signs such as muscle stiffness, awkward movements, unsteady walking, favoring one side of the body more than the other. While she does have some delays like toe-walking and unequal leg ability, these alone aren't enough for a diagnosis. A pediatric neurologist can provide a definitive diagnosis based on clinical evaluation and possibly imaging studies.

Regarding suspecting Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD), it’s clear some development concerns are there, particularly social interaction & persistent speech issues. Ruling out ASD by means of thorough evaluation seems quite reasonable considering these symptoms.

In summary, while factors do exist indicating both CP & ASD, her symptoms are not clearly indicative of either one condition in particular. They warrant further evaluation by professionals who can observe your daughter directly, preferably a developmental pediatrician, pediatric neurologist and/or

input: Hi doctor,I sat on my testicle before two months, and I experienced an initial sharp pain for a few hours. I went to the ER and did a blood test, urine test and an ultrasound. Torsion, as well as infection, was ruled out.The exact incident occurred before few days. I did a urine test and another ultrasound. Torsion was ruled out once again. When the pain flared up again, I went to the doctor back. Again, I did an ultrasound, urine test, and blood test. Torsion and infection were ruled once again.The doctor pointed out a little bit of fluid around my testicle, and I had no pain. But, still, I have pain in my testicle. What was ruled out with these tests? From where does the pain arises?
output:
The tests that were done would have ruled out testicular torsion (a condition where the spermatic cord that provides blood flow to the testicle is twisted), infection, and likely any masses or tumors due to the ultrasound. It's good news those conditions were ruled out as they can be serious.

The fluid around your testicle you mentioned could be a hydrocele or possibly a varicocele, both of which are fairly common in men. Hydrocele is an accumulation of serous fluid in a body cavity while varicocele is an enlargement of the veins within the scrotum. Both can cause discomfort but are often not dangerous.

However, if your pain continues, it could also potentially be due to something like epididymitis (inflammation of the tube at the back of the testicle that carries sperm), or other non-testicular causes such as hernias or even referred pain from other locations like lower-back problems. 

Another possibility can be a condition called intermittent testicular torsion where the testicle twists and then untwists itself spontaneously. This can cause severe on-and-off type pain similar to what you're describing. 

Remember, persistent testicular pain should always be evaluated by a healthcare provider because it can be a symptom of serious conditions. You may need more specialized tests or visit a urologist for further consultation.

input: Hi doctor,I got an accident before a month. I got a right knee ACL ligament type 2 tear. Is it possible for the type 2 ligament to get cured by itself without operation and if so, how many days does it take to heal?
output:
The anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) has a limited ability to heal itself due to its location and lack of blood supply. A grade 2 sprain represents an incomplete tear of the ACL, which may cause instability of the knee, discomfort, and limitation in certain activities.

While conservative treatments such as physical therapy can sometimes manage these symptoms effectively, depending on your age, health condition, physical activities, and personal goals, a surgical route might be necessary to restore full function to your knee for high-intensity sports or strenuous labor.

Non-surgical treatment usually involves rehabilitation programs aimed at restoring joint movement and strength. This could take weeks to months, depending on how diligent you are with therapy and how your body responds.

Surgery often leads to more predictable outcomes regarding knee stability and is especially useful for active individuals. However, it also comes with potential risks including infection, bleeding, blood clots, and anesthesia complications.

Therefore, I would recommend discussing this with your orthopedic surgeon who can review your imaging studies, examine your knee, discuss your individual needs, and determine the best course of action for you. Always consult with your healthcare provider directly when making decisions regarding your health care.

input: Hi doctor,I am a 30 year old female. I have a minor issue. About a month and a half ago, there was an incident where the condom broke. About 36 hours later, my husband got me four of the morning-after pills, and I took them all at once. Three days later, I started experiencing nausea, soreness of the breasts, lower back as well as abdominal pain, frequent urination, and tiredness. This carried on for almost a week. I then noticed a light brown discharge. And, from the next day, I bled for six days. I usually bleed for seven days. After my periods, I still had the symptoms.Nearly a month later, I got my periods again, but on the first day I had severe cramps and used a tampon. On the third day, there was a slight discharge which was brown in color. On the fourth day, there was some bleeding, but not at night. Today would be day five, and I still do not see blood. My main concern is that my vagina feels different. It is more firm than usual and feels tight. I sometimes feel a pulling sensation. Could it be due to the morning-after pills? I did home pregnancy tests, and it came back negative. It has been a month and 18 days now, since the intercourse.
output:
Hi, I appreciate that dealing with these unfamiliar symptoms can be concerning. Firstly, the morning-after pill (also known as an emergency contraceptive) has many side effects which include nausea, breast tenderness, abdominal pain, fatigue, and changes in menstrual cycle - so what you might have experienced could very well have been due to it. The brown discharge you noticed is likely old blood being expelled from your body; this is also common after taking the morning-after pill.

The feelings of tightness and "pulling" sensation in your vagina may be related to a variety of factors—hormonal changes, stress, certain medications can all affect how your vagina feels. However, if these symptoms persist or worsen, you should definitely consult a healthcare provider who can properly evaluate you through a check-up and possibly further testing. 

Lastly, the negative result on your pregnancy test is encouraging, especially since it's been more than a month since possible conception. Home pregnancy tests are very accurate when taken correctly and at the right time. It's best to take them one week after missing your period. Since you have had two cycles now post the incident, the chances of you being pregnant are extremely low given the negative test results. 

Please make sure to get regular gynecological examinations and discuss any future plans for contraception to ensure safe sex practices henceforth.

input: Hello doctor,I am a 29-year-old female. I was just diagnosed with chronic urticaria. I went to an allergic specialist for skin testing because my skin was so sensitive I reacted to everything. They then did the RAST test on me. Everything came out class 0 except for egg white, wheat, and oats being class 2 and milk, and hazelnut being class 1. Can these cause anaphylaxis? How accurate are the RAST test? I was put on an elimination diet but the hives are still there. I occasionally get angioedema with it also. Can angiodema cause anaphylaxis? As you can see I am so scared for my throat to close up that I am scared to eat anything. I have only been eating a couple of things daily and live off that.
output:
I understand your concern. A RAST test (Radioallergosorbent Test) often has a good degree of accuracy, but it is not perfect. Results can be affected by certain factors like the amount of allergen exposure prior to testing and presence of other medical conditions.

Yes, the foods you've tested positive for could potentially cause anaphylaxis but the likelihood could vary greatly depending on how severe your reaction to these respective items is. Class 1 and 2 scores indicate a lower level of sensitivity compared with higher classes; that being said, even lower class scores should not be dismissed without caution as they still indicate an allergic reaction. 

Urticaria (hives) may persist despite dietary elimination if there are non-allergic causes at play such as physical stimulus (heat, cold, pressure), autoimmune disorder, infection etc. Angioedema can occur along with urticaria and although it can occasionally precede anaphylaxis, it doesn't always do so.

It's very important in your case to have medications like antihistamines on hand and also an epinephrine autoinjector for more severe reactions. 

Keeping a food diary can help to decipher additional food triggers as well. You might want to consult with a dietitian who specializes in food allergies to make sure you're getting adequate nutrition given your current food restrictions.

Remember, immediate medical attention is needed if anaphylactic symptoms such as difficulty breathing or swallowing develop. 

You ultimately need

input: Hello doctor,Since the last 10 months, my periods are very irregular. I get periods only once every three to four months. I am on treatment for abdominal TB since the last one and a half years. I take Sompraz D20 on an empty stomach in the morning. I take Duonase nasal spray (two puffs in each nostril) twice a day. I take Immunace Forte after lunch and Libotryp at bedtime. So, why are my periods not regular? Is this a side effect of my medicine or could it be due to a disease? Recently, I was also prescribed Uprise-D3 (60000) once a month for six months. My recent 25-OH vitamin D total is 21.1 ng/mL. I also have sudden weight gain. My weight in the last one and a half years increased from 57 kg to 81 kg. I also have a chronic nose block.
output:
Irregular periods can be caused by many factors, including significant weight gain and certain medical conditions like tuberculosis or hormonal imbalances. Particularly, abnormal levels of thyroid hormone or prolactin could lead to menstrual irregularities. The medicine you are taking (Libotryp) could also potentially cause changes in your menstruation as it affects levels of serotonin in the body.

Moreover, substantial weight gain over a short period of time, like what you experienced, can have a strong impact on your hormones which regulate menstruation cycles. It's common for women who are overweight to experience irregular periods due to increased production of estrogen by fat cells.

Turner's syndrome or Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) are some diseases that can also induce such symptoms. However, there isn't enough information here to make such diagnoses — further investigations would need to be done.

I strongly recommend discussing these symptoms with your healthcare provider as soon as possible for a thorough evaluation. This may involve blood tests to check hormone levels and likely an ultrasound to evaluate your ovaries and uterus. Also, keep tracking your menstrual cycles, noting any irregularities. Doing so can provide crucial information when you see a doctor. In the meantime, maintain balanced nutrition and regular exercise which could help manage the weight issue as well.

input: Hi doctor,I had a history of thyroid issue before pregnancy. Currently, I have an issue of hair fall and mild body aches.
output:
Hello, I'm sorry to hear about your symptoms. As a doctor, it's important for me to let you know that the symptoms you're experiencing can potentially be linked to your thyroid condition. Thyroid hormones are crucial for many body functions including hair growth. Hypothyroidism (low thyroid hormone levels) or changes in hormone levels during and after pregnancy can sometimes cause hair loss.

Also, thyroid disease is known to cause body aches and muscle pain in some people. However, those symptoms could also be due to other reasons too like lack of adequate rest, nutritional deficiencies, stress etc.

As you had a history of thyroid issues before pregnancy, postpartum thyroiditis, which occurs in 5-10% of women who have been pregnant, may happen. In this condition, the thyroid gets inflamed within the first year after childbirth and this inflammation can last up to 18 months.

You should contact your healthcare provider and relay these symptoms. They can adjust your treatment plan as needed. They may recommend testing your thyroid function with blood tests to guide the management. Take care.

input: Hi doctor,I have a generic query. Can we trust the NABL and CAP accreditation laboratories in terms of reliability and accuracy? And what does they mean? And all NABL and CAP labs are of same quality? Please explain in detail.
output:
Yes, laboratories accredited by NABL (National Accreditation Board for Testing and Calibration Laboratories) in India and CAP (College of American Pathologists) in the U.S. are generally trustworthy in terms of reliability and accuracy of their test results. These accreditations indicate that a laboratory meets certain internationally accepted standards of quality control, proficiency testing, personnel qualifications, and operational practices.

NABL is an internationally recognized accreditation body from India. It follows ISO 15189, which is specifically designed to ensure medical lab competence. Similarly, CAP is considered one of the global leaders in laboratory quality assurance, advocating high-quality patient care, and provides inter-laboratory comparisons to assist labs improve their diagnostic competencies.

However, it is important to understand that while these certifications mean a lab has met specific requirements at the time of inspection, that does not necessarily mean all NABL and/or CAP accredited labs offer the same exact level of service or accuracy and precision in every single case. Just like in any other area of healthcare, variability can exist; different labs might have different areas of expertise, use different methodologies, and even within these certified labs, human errors can occur.

Regular internal audits, periodic external assessments, necessary corrective actions based on audit findings, good inventory management, well trained staff, and appropriate supervision are few key factors that maintain and enhance quality over time.

Ultimately, these accreditations should be viewed as "minimum standards," and patients and healthcare providers alike should always consider other factors such as professional recommendations,

input: Hello doctor,How eating habits or certain foods impact sleep? How much should men be stretching at 25, 30, 35, 40, 45? Does the need to be flexible vary by age?
output:
Eating habits can significantly impact sleep. A balanced diet promotes good sleep while certain foods can disrupt it. High-sugar diets may make a person more alert and less likely to fall asleep easily, while too much caffeine will similarly keep you awake. Alcohol, although initially sedative, disturbs the second half of your sleep-cycle causing frequent wake-ups and non-restful sleep. Foods that are rich in magnesium, such as nuts and seeds, and tryptophan, found in dairy products, can help promote better sleep.

As for stretching and its frequency, it largely depends on your physical goals and overall health rather than age. However, maintaining flexibility becomes important as we age because our muscles naturally lose strength and size leading to issues with balance and susceptibility to injuries. Everyone, regardless of their age group, should aim to do some form of flexibility exercises like stretching or yoga every day. The American College of Sports Medicine recommends adults to stretch major muscle groups at least two times per week.

Men in their 20s and 30s generally have good muscular flexibility but sedentary lifestyles can lead to stiffness. Regular stretching helps prevent this. As men get into their 40's and beyond, muscle mass starts to reduce which could also affect flexibility. So taking time to maintain a good stretching routine is important during these years. Remember to always warm-up before stretching to avoid injuries, hold stretches for 15-60 seconds, and don't bounce or use jerky movements. 

Finally, note that

input: Hello doctor,My baby is 10 months old, and he is two months premature. If I feed him with solid food, he does vomiting. Is it not safe for him to feed with solid food?
output:
Your baby is just 10 months old and was born two months premature, so his development (including feeding skills) may be a little different when compared to full-term babies. It's generally recommended to start introducing solid foods between 4-6 months of age for term infants, but in the case of your preterm infant, you should discuss with their pediatrician before introducing solids. His doctor will take into account adjusted age, not actual age.

Also, some babies initially reject or have difficulty accepting new textures or types of food, including solids, which can occasionally lead to gagging or possibly vomiting if they're not quite ready for it.

However, regular vomiting after meals could be indicative of conditions like pneumonia, gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), allergies, pyloric stenosis, etc. If your child consistently vomits after eating, I recommend bringing this up with their doctor who can evaluate your son and ensure there isn't a more serious underlying condition causing this symptom.

input: Hello doctor,I am 23, 51 kg. I had unprotected sex a day before I got my period (on the 38th day of cycle). It lasted for four days (normal). Today is the 13th day from when my period started and I am getting bad backache, my breasts hurt (usually happens just before period) and sticky egg white discharge. Am I pregnant or is it ovulation? I had taken a pregnancy test before I got my period because I was late and it was negative. I have mild PCOS. So, my periods are never on time but happens every month. Is it possible to be pregnant after you get your period?
output:
Given your symptoms and the timing, it's more likely that what you're experiencing is related to ovulation rather than pregnancy. Around the time of ovulation, some women experience discomfort in the lower abdomen (ovulation pain or "mittelschmerz"), breast tenderness, increased sexual desire, bloating, and changes in cervical mucus – typically a clear, "egg-white" like consistency, which signals fertility.

As for your question about being pregnant after having a menstrual period, if the bleeding you experienced was a normal menstrual period, then it's unlikely that you would be pregnant from sex that occurred before that period. However, there can sometimes be confusion between an actual menstrual period and implantation bleeding (which can occur when a fertilized egg implants in the uterus), the latter usually is lighter and shorter than a typical period.

Still, since you have PCOS and infrequent periods, I would suggest taking another pregnancy test if you continue to experience early pregnancy symptoms (nausea, vomiting, fatigue) or if your next period is delayed. It is also important that you consider seeing a healthcare provider and discussing appropriate contraceptive options.

Remember: even though you might not be planning for a baby right now, if you still are sexually active without using contraception, there's always a chance you could become pregnant. It’s always better to take precautions if not planning for pregnancy.

input: Hi doctor,Nowadays, I am getting a migraine for every three days alternatively. Before few days, I usually get a migraine once in 20 days. Often, I have a visual problem and aura symptoms. It relieves after taking Zerodol. Please suggest.
output:
As a doctor, it is concerning to hear that your migraines are increasing in frequency and associated with aura symptoms. Zerodol is a medication that appears to have been providing some relief for you; however, it's mainly an analgesic and anti-inflammatory drug, not a specific treatment for migraines.

Migraine management typically involves two types of medications: acute treatments (for attacks as they happen) and preventive medications, which aim to reduce the number and severity of your migraines. It sounds like you may benefit from considering some preventive options given your increased frequency of migraines. 

Beta blockers, antidepressants, antiepileptic drugs, CGRP inhibitors, and even Botox injections are among potential preventative measures used based on how frequent and severe the migraines are, and whether or not the patient has aura symptoms. Also note that many preventive medications take time – even up to several months – before they begin to work effectively. 

Before any change to your treatment plan, I strongly recommend that you consult with a neurologist who can provide a comprehensive evaluation and discuss these possibilities. They may also want to investigate why the frequency of your migraines has increased suddenly. This could potentially involve imaging studies or other tests to rule out any underlying conditions. Lastly, always remember to mention any visual problems to your doctor, as this can be relevant in diagnosing and treating your condition.

input: Hello doctor,I am suffering from epididymitis problem. Sometimes I am having pain in testis while having a gastric issue as well. Kindly help me to get rid of this
output:
The symptoms you're describing are generally indicative of inflammation of the epididymis, but this needs to be confirmed with a clinical examination and tests by a healthcare professional. Epididymitis is often caused by bacteria and can be treated with antibiotics. It's important that you visit a urologist or your general practitioner who can confirm this diagnosis and then prescribe an appropriate course of treatment.

Regarding your gastric issues, understanding the nature of your symptoms would help in providing a better recommendation - whether it is bloating, discomfort, pain, heartburn etc. However, dietary changes like avoiding spicy foods, consuming smaller meals distributed throughout the day, increasing fiber intake can help ameliorate some common digestive issues. Over-the-counter antacids might provide temporary relief but it's advisable to see a doctor if these problems persist.

Remember, my advice does not substitute that of a physical consult. Please make sure to schedule an appointment with a medical expert.

input: Hello doctor,I am 32 years old and had an herinated disc and had surgery a few years back, it was a post delayed surgery. Due to the delay in surgery (18 days) I left with a foot drop and right leg weakness. I was bedridden for 4 months. Totally weak. But I gradually developed doing physiotheraphy and with some Ayurvedic treatment. I started waking now with out any help. But my foot drop is still there. But I can lift my toe and ankle little bit from last month. Can I come to my normal life, how long I need to wait to get cured from foot drop?
output:
I'm sorry to hear about your condition. It's difficult to give a precise timeline on when you might see improvement, as recovery from such conditions has a lot of variability and depends on many factors such as the extent of nerve damage, your individual health condition, response to therapy, etc.

Although late surgery for herniated disc can leave some residual deficits, like your foot drop, it is encouraging that you can lift your toe and ankle a bit now, showing early signs of possible recovery. The process of nerve regeneration is slow and could take several months or even up to a couple years in cases with significant nerve damage.

Physiotherapy is essential and should be continued diligently to encourage maximum functional recovery. With time and consistent therapy, there may further improve. An assistive device like an Ankle-Foot-Orthosis (AFO) can help compensate for the weakness in the meantime and allow you to walk more safely.

As recovery varies greatly between individuals, I would strongly advise you to follow-up regularly with a neurologist or physiatrist who can guide your rehabilitation plan based on your progress and symptoms. They can do regular check-ups and tests (like EMG - Electromyography) to keep track of how the nerves are recovering, discuss the need for anymore surgical interventions if required, and give you a better estimate of your prognosis.

Again, each case is different and it's always important to remember that patience and consistency with therapy is key in these situations. Don't get discouraged

input: Hello doctor,I was at the dentist yesterday and had a gum cleaning and now today there are 2 bumps in the back of my mouth on top and my gums right there also look red and there more looking like balls per say.
output:
It sounds like you might be experiencing inflammation or swelling in the area that was cleaned which can sometimes occur after dental procedures. This could be due to irritation from the cleaning process but can also indicate an infection.

However, it is important that we do not overlook any potential issues. For now, try rinsing your mouth with warm salt water several times a day (1/2 teaspoon of salt in 1 cup of warm water). You should also maintain good oral hygiene by brushing and flossing gently.

If these bumps continue to grow, persist for more than a few days, or are accompanied by severe pain, fever, or difficulty swallowing/breathing, you should contact your dentist right away as you may require additional treatment such as antibiotics if there's an underlying infection. Additionally, if these symptoms appear elsewhere in your body or if you begin to feel unwell generally make sure to consult your healthcare provider.

input: Hello doctor,I have a milky like white color on my tongue that is more noticeable in the back my tongue should I be worried? I am a non-drinker and smoker.
output:
The white coating on your tongue could be due to numerous reasons. The two most common causes are oral thrush and leukoplakia:

1. Oral Thrush: This is a yeast infection that develops inside the mouth. It appears as white patches that are often the consistency of cottage cheese. Oral thrush is known as candidiasis because it's caused by a group of yeasts called Candida.

2. Leukoplakia: This condition causes cells in the mouth to grow excessively. That, in turn, leads to the formation of white patches inside the mouth, including on the tongue.

Although both conditions aren't typically dangerous, they can lead to more serious problems if not addressed promptly. So, considering you don't have any risk factor like tobacco or alcohol use, it would nevertheless still be wise to see a healthcare provider just to rule out anything more serious. 

And remember, even though it might not seem like this could be related, overall health factors such as diet, hygiene, and stress can affect the health of your mouth. Therefore, ensure to maintain good oral hygiene practice daily - brushing twice and using a fluoride toothpaste.

input: Hello doctor,I am 29 years old . I am married from the last 1.5 years. My problem is that from the last two weeks I am am not getting proper erection during sex. Erection comes a bit and goes out instantly. It is just happeing from the last two weeks before that I was totally fine. I am taking some herbal medicines. Please suggest me why this happening to me. Right now I cat get any erection sex only a bit if I watch some porn or like that. I am having so much tension because of that. Yes one more thing, I used to take one penis size enlarge oil but very rarely. Might be because of that oil I am having this problem. Please suggest me best possible option to cure this.
output:
Erectile dysfunction (ED) is quite common and can result from a variety of factors. It could be due to psychological issues like stress, anxiety, or depression, or it could be caused by physical health problems such as heart disease, diabetes, hormonal imbalances, or side effects from medications (including some herbal remedies). Substance use might also contribute to these issues.

Regarding the penis enlargement oil you've been using, it's difficult to tell without knowing its specific ingredients if it's contributing to your problem. Several of these products have not been tested thoroughly for efficacy or safety, so it's possible they could have negative effects. 

Here are some suggestions:

1. Try to relax: Stress and anxiety about sexual performance can worsen ED. Deep breathing exercises, meditation, yoga, or talking to a mental health professional might help.

2. Check your lifestyle choices: Smoking, drinking too much alcohol, drug misuse and lack of exercise can lead to ED. Regular exercise, maintaining a healthy diet, limiting alcohol, and eliminating smoking if applicable could improve erectile function.

3. Consult a doctor: These symptoms require medical evaluation. Your doctor may recommend blood tests to check hormone levels and screen for conditions like high cholesterol or diabetes which may contribute to ED.

4. Medication or therapy: There are several effective treatments available for ED including medications like Sildenafil (Viagra), Tadalafil (Cialis), and others. Speak with your doctor to see if these could work for you. Psychological counseling may also

input: Hello doctor,I will be facing major surgery for stage three lung cancer contained in the left lobe. I am extremely allergic to Fentanyl, Propofol, and Versed. Are there any alternatives to these anesthetics? I am currently on Synthroid.
output:
Yes, alternatives to Fentanyl, Propofol, and Versed are available. Speak with your anesthesiologist about using anesthetic agents such as Sevoflurane or Isoflurane for maintenance of anesthesia. Remifentanil may be used as an alternative opioid to fentanyl. You might also discuss non-opiate adjuncts like Ketamine, Dexmedetomidine, or regional anesthesia techniques.

As for sedatives, Midazolam (Versed) can be replaced by other benzodiazepines such as Diazepam or newer non-benzodiazepine sedation agents like Etomidate or Barbiturates, however their use needs to be individualized based on the patient's condition and surgical requirements.

The use of Synthroid (Levothyroxine) indicates that you have a thyroid condition. It is crucial to let your surgeon and anesthesiologist know about this because thyroid conditions can significantly affect how you respond to surgery and anesthesia.

Please remember to discuss any allergies, medications, and medical conditions with your doctors prior to surgery so they can plan the best strategy for you.

input: Hello doctor,I have rheumatoid arthritis. There is a long waiting list to see a rheumatologist in my place. I am thinking of seeing a private doctor but I have limited funds. How often would I need to see a rheumatologist? I cannot afford it every week or maybe every few months. How often do you think I need a doctor visit? I am hoping to be prescribed a DMARD like Methotrexate. Then when my slot comes up with the NHS I will go there.I take Naproxen which is not enough and I had a cortisone injection in my knee a couple of months ago. The swelling did not go down completely but I walked better. It has worn off now, and I have pain in more joints and a feeling of lumps under my feet. I am on a special diet and my CRP, ESR and high rheumatoid factor have gone down by half. But lately, I feel unwell. I would like to know the frequency of visits needed.
output:
The frequency of visits to a rheumatologist can vary greatly depending on the severity of your arthritis and how well you are responding to treatment. However, typically patients with rheumatoid arthritis should see their rheumatologist every three to six months. If you're having a severe flare or if you're not responding to medication, more frequent visits may be necessary at least initially.

Given your situation with limited funds and long waiting time for NHS availability, you could consider seeing a private practitioner initially until your slot comes up with the NHS. It may also be worth checking in with your general practitioner (GP) who might help bridge this gap and potentially prescribe methotrexate, assuming they feel it's appropriate. This should always be done under the supervision of a clinician familiar with DMARDs as there are risks associated with these medications that need thorough discussion and monitoring.

It is encouraging that you have seen some improvement from measures such as diet and anti-inflammatory drugs so far, but considering the evolving nature of your symptoms, initiation of disease-modifying therapy like Methotrexate sounds prudent. Always remember to discuss all these options thoroughly with your healthcare provider to ensure you're making the best decision under your circumstances.

input: Hello doctor,Due to the use of Skinlite, I have sunburn on my face and now it looks like the dark spot. But I am using Kojivit gel for a dark spot. Is Kojivit gel good for the dark spot?
output:
Yes, Kojivit gel can be effective for reducing dark spots as it contains active ingredients like Kojic acid and Glycolic acid that are known to reduce pigmentation and improve skin tone. However, in case of sunburn or any kind of irritation, first you should allow your skin to heal before applying any other topical agents.

Additionally, while using products like Kojivit gel, which affect melanin production, it is crucial to protect your skin from the sun since your skin can become more sensitive to sunlight and burn more easily. Always use a good sunscreen with an SPF of at least 30.

Remember, everyone's skin responds differently to different treatments, so if you don't see improvements or if the condition worsens, please consult a dermatologist. The doctor may recommend a different treatment based on your specific skin type and condition.

input: Hello doctor,My son has a persistent headache since last 15 days. It started with headache. Consulted various neurologist. Got MRI and CT done, all clear. He gave various medicines, even Noxdorm 250, but no response.
output:
I'm sorry to hear that your son is going through this. Persistent headaches can be overwhelming and debilitating.

It's good news that his MRI and CT scans are clear, which means there's no hint of serious issues like tumors or abnormalities in his brain. However, it still doesn't provide the root cause of these persistent headaches.

The headaches could be a primary headache disorder such as migraines, tension-type headaches or cluster headaches, but they may also be secondary to another medical condition. Other problems - related to vision, sinuses, teeth/jaw misalignment, or neck/spine alignment - might not show up on an MRI or CT scan yet they can trigger consistent headaches. Equally significant are emotional factors such as stress and anxiety which often contribute to chronic daily headaches.

It would be important to monitor if he experiences other symptoms associated with headaches - such as light sensitivity, nausea, visual changes or neck stiffness etc., these additional details will help diagnose the particular type of headache.

Considering that the medication given by his neurologist isn't alleviating his symptoms, it may be worthwhile seeking consultation from other specialties such as ENT specialists, eye doctors, paediatric dentist/orthodontist (in case your son is a minor), and/or physical therapist who can assess for musculature triggers. Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (CBT) has also been shown to be very effective for those suffering from recurrent headaches and can be considered.

And lastly, keep ensuring that he maintains a healthy lifestyle – balanced

input: Hello doctor,My wife and I had some argument about my past. I had lied to her about the number of sex partners I had. That hurts her because she explained that her perception of me was built on the fact that she knew that I only had a few sex partners.We have been discussing this for months, but now after having these discussions and arguments, I realize that when we are to have sex, I get anxious. I will get an erection, but when its time to enter, it falls. I want to know, how to get my mind to a place of not over thinking so that I am not distracted. Kindly help.
output:
It sounds like you are experiencing performance anxiety, which is a common issue many people face. It's not unusual for stress and anxiety from other areas of life to carry over into the bedroom, particularly when it involves intimacy and vulnerability.

Here are a few tips that may help with this situation:

1. Communication: Start with talking openly and honestly about your feelings with your wife. This can relieve some pressure, making it easier to maintain an erection when the time comes.

2. Therapy or counseling: If open conversation doesn't resolve the issue, consider seeking professional help through therapy or counseling. This could be individually or as a couple. A professional might offer helpful insights and coping mechanisms.

3. Relaxation techniques: Try deep breathing exercises, meditation, yoga, or any activity that you find relaxing before getting intimate. 

4. Lots of foreplay: Spend extra time on foreplay. This will help both of you get more aroused and ready for penetration, thus reducing the possibility of erectile dysfunction due to anxiety or nervousness.

5. Healthy Lifestyle: Maintain a healthy lifestyle by eating balanced meals, exercising regularly, getting good sleep and limiting use of alcohol and avoiding illicit substances. These can all have significant impacts on sexual health.
   
6. Medical checkup: Underlying medical issues can contribute towards erectile problems. Therefore if the problem persists consider seeing a healthcare provider for a full examination.

Lastly, remember it's completely okay to seek help. Emotions and tensions can play a big role in one's

input: Hi doctor,I feel a strange glitch in my vision. It is quite big and takes up a large portion of my central vision. It is neither a shadow nor a flash, it looks like a greasy fingerprint smudge in my vision which disappears quickly. It happens when I blink, but mostly occurs when my eyes move quickly. I have had it for the past few days and I do not know if it is anything to be concerned about. Please help.
output:
This can possibly be a symptom of a retinal issue such as a vitreous detachment, where the jelly-like substance inside your eyes (vitreous humour) shrinks and may partly detach from the retina. It could also be indicative of other issues like an ocular migraine, macula edema or retinal tear/detachment - all of which need immediate consultation.

An occasional floater is usually not concerning and could simply be due to ageing, inflammation, nearsightedness etc. But if it persists, increases in number or size, or is associated with symptoms like flashing lights/shadows or loss of peripheral vision, you should seek immediate help as this poses a threat to vision. 

Please visit an ophthalmologist for a comprehensive eye examination including a dilated fundus examination. The doctor will be able to thoroughly assess your retina and advise accordingly.

input: Hello doctor,My tooth hurts anytime I eat or drink. It feels hot. I feel hot, it is sharp pain that does not go away. My gums are swollen.
output: Based on your description, it sounds like you might have a tooth infection or abscess. Your symptoms of pain when eating or drinking, particularly to hot temperatures, coupled with the persistent nature of the pain and the swollen gums, are typical signs of this condition. It could also be a serious dental cavity. Either way, you need to see a dentist as soon as possible because untreated infections can spread, cause further damage, and become life-threatening. Over-the-counter pain relievers may help reduce pain temporarily, but this is not a permanent solution. Antibiotics or other treatments may also be necessary.

input: Hello doctor,I have had permanent cramps and a constant ache in both buttocks. I have pain down the back of the legs in the calf and when I walk it feels like it is about to cramp and I get pain in front of the thigh. I have a constant aching feel. When I press my skin on both thighs it feels sore. I had it for over two months. I have pain on both sides of my thighs and legs regardless of if I am sitting or resting.I got admitted to the hospital for two weeks and they did an MRI scan on my spine and found nothing. They did a lumbar puncture and found nothing. They also did a nerve examination and nothing was found. I am currently on Gabapentin, Codeine, and Paracetamol.
output:
Your symptoms suggest that you may be experiencing a condition known as sciatica, which is characterized by pain affecting the back, hip, and outer side of the leg, caused by compression of a spinal nerve root in the lower back. Though your MRI did not show any abnormalities, sometimes conditions like these can still occur due to soft tissue involvement.

However, bilateral involvement (both sides affected) is rare for sciatica, and it’s also unusual that nothing showed up on the spine MRI or nerve examinations if this was the case.

It's also possible that you are suffering from a peripheral neuropathy, which is a result of damage to your peripheral nerves. This might have been missed if only your spine was being investigated. Neuropathies often manifest with the kind of distal (more towards the feet), symmetrical symptoms you're describing.

One other possibility could be a muscular issue. Conditions such as polymyalgia rheumatica can cause muscle pain and stiffness in various parts of the body, particularly the hips and thighs, although it would usually also affect other areas (like the neck, shoulders).

Given your complex symptom picture and lack of clear findings so far, I think it might be worth seeking another opinion. Consider seeing a neurologist who specializes in peripheral neuropathy or an experienced physiatrist. A comprehensive review of all your past medical records, additional targeted investigations (nerve conduction studies, EMG, specific blood tests), and possibly trials of different therapies might help get to the

input: Hello doctor,I have small boils (red and white) on the head of my penis and also inside the skin and itching also. I regularly clean with warm water and sometimes, put some vaseline gel but nowadays, it increases very much. I think it is a fungal infection. Please suggest a good medicine and precautions to be taken to clear this infection. ASAP. This happened for the first time.
output:
I'm an AI, not a doctor, but it's important to consult a healthcare professional about this. What you're describing could suggest different conditions such as balanitis, genital herpes or other STIs which are usually diagnosed through physical examination and laboratory tests. Please see a health provider immediately for appropriate advice. Over the counter products may help manage symptoms, but they might not address the cause of your problem.

If it is indeed a fungal infection, then antifungal medications would be recommended (like clotrimazole or miconazole), but these should only be used after seeing a doctor. Remember, never attempt to self-medicate without medical advice. Furthermore, maintaining good hygiene can help prevent future infections.

input: Hello doctor, I have observed a white smegma on my penis head. There were irritation and red bumps on it before, but I oiled it so now I do not have any pain or irritation. But in the morning the white smegma is still there and my foreskin is hard and rough. What should I do? Please help.
output:
It seems like you might be experiencing symptoms of a common condition in males known as balanitis. This can be caused by several factors such as poor hygiene, bacterial or yeast infections, or certain skin conditions. It's important to improve personal hygiene, especially washing under the foreskin daily with mild soap and warm water. Avoid any harsh or scented soaps which could cause irritation.

The use of oil you mentioned might worsen the situation if it is not suitable for sensitive areas or is used without proper cleaning of the area first. The roughness you have noticed on your foreskin may be due to scarring from irritation or infection.

I would strongly advise that you see a healthcare professional to give an accurate diagnosis and treatment plan. They may recommend antifungal creams or antibiotics, depending on the underlying cause of your condition.

It's always important to seek medical advice when you notice changes to the penis, such as lumps, rashes, or discharge to rule out sexually transmitted diseases or other serious conditions. Try to avoid self diagnosing or self treating as this sometimes leads to more harm than good. 

Remember, if you're sexually active always practice safe sex, including using condoms, to prevent potential sexually transmitted infections (STIs).

input: Hello doctor,My 2-year-old put my mascara wand in his mouth. His teeth and all around his mouth were black. I used a toothbrush and water to get all the black out. What else should I do? I am not sure how much he swallowed. Can it harm him?
output:
While mascara isn't designed to be ingested, a one-time, small amount likely won't have severe effects. However, it can potentially cause irritation or an allergic reaction in some cases. The best initial course of action is exactly what you did: do your best to clean his mouth out with water.

If he shows any signs of discomfort such as excessive drooling, vomiting, difficulty breathing, or acting strangely, it's important to seek immediate medical attention. If your child seems fine, just monitor him for these symptoms over the next 24 hours, making sure he continues to eat and drink normally. 

For further peace of mind, or if you notice any alarming symptoms, you might want to call Poison Control at (800) 222-1222 (if you're in the United States) or Healthcare provider immediately. They can provide expert advice in case of potential poisoning emergencies.

input: Hello doctor,Last night and today I have been experiencing a sharp pain just left of the sternum which is not deep, seemingly on top of the rib where it joins the sternum. It lasts a second or two but may repeat several times before stopping in five minutes or so. I went out in the garden today to dig a bit and wearing my HR monitor (I have got health anxiety, anxiety disorder as well as depression). As I was digging, the pain started hurting with each heartbeat. I looked at my monitor and it read 138 bpm. I am 70 years old and have been on medication (Benzodiazepines) for over 50 years for panic attacks and general anxiety. Two years ago I felt similar pain but not to this extent. I went to ER but nothing was found (the doctor said it could be costochondritis but definitely not my heart). I get bloodwork quarterly and everything was fine except cholesterol which was 235. I tried a statin but the muscle pain was too great. In my EKG I have RBBB or LAFB which 14 years back after a stress test I was told that I was probably born with it. I had gone to see the cardiologist then because of getting skipped beats and GERD he told me to ignore them. Last time I had an EKG was in the ER for six months when I had a weird pain in back and side. They checked out heart anyway and said it was fine. Probably just a colicky gallbladder. I have had stones for more than 20 years and had no surgery. So I hesitate to go to the ER again. My local doctor just closed. HR is still 88 while lying down right now. Usually, my resting heart rate is under 67. Currently, I am on Lorazepam 2 mg, Prevacid 15 mg and baby Aspirin.
output:
Based on the symptoms you described, it could be a recurrence of your costochondritis. It is inflammation of the cartilage that connects a rib to the breastbone (sternum) which often causes chest pain that can be mistaken for a heart condition like angina or a heart attack. Physical activity, such as heavy lifting or gardening may trigger or worsen it.

However, I want to stress out the importance of seeking immediate medical attention whenever you experience new or unexplained chest pain. Despite previous episodes being attributed to costochondritis, the symptoms you describe can also be due to heart disease. Especially since you have raised cholesterol levels and a faster heart rate than normal (might be due your anxiety), these factors should not be dismissed lightly. Although your EKG has been fine in the past, sometimes underlying cardiac problems can go undetected between tests but show up later.

Finally, don't forget about your gallbladder stones. If they move and cause a blockage it can potentially lead to symptoms such as severe right side or center abdominal pain, back pain, and increases in heart rate.

To conclude, although this could be costochondritis or related to your GERD (which can be aggravated by digging/gardening work especially if you bend over frequently - causing stomach acid to flow into your esophagus leading to pain/discomfort), I strongly advise you to seek medical attention to rule out any serious causes like coronary heart disease or gallbladder issues. Even though the ER

input: Hi doctor,I am in my late 6th month pregnancy. Recently I went for a scan named targeted imaging for fetal anomalies (TIFFA). All the reports were normal except hypoplastic nasal bone and higher normal values of amniotic fluid. I am approaching you for second consultation now. My questions are, what if we go for genetic amniocentesis and results were positive for Down\s syndrome? Can I terminate the pregnancy in my 28th week of pregnancy? How much safe it is to go for amniocentesis test? Is there any alternate test to get better results? I decided not to have a baby who is mentally retarded. Please suggest me your valuable advice.
output:
I understand your concerns and I'll do my best to provide you with an appropriate guidance.

Firstly, a hypoplastic nasal bone is one of several markers that can increase the suspicion for Down's syndrome but it in itself does not confirm this diagnosis. Higher amounts of amniotic fluid (Polyhydramnios) can also be associated with fetal anomalies, but again isn’t typically definitive for Down Syndrome.

An amniocentesis would help get clear information about chromosomal abnormalities, including Down's syndrome. The safety of this procedure has greatly increased over the years and under expert hands, the risk of complications such as miscarriage has been reported to be less than 1%. However, still there are minor risks which include harm to the baby or mother, infection, premature labour or leaking amniotic fluid.

In terms of termination, the laws vary depending on where you live: some countries permit termination beyond 24 weeks only if there's a substantial risk to woman's life or serious fetal anomaly. In others, termination at this stage may not be legal at all without these grounds. Therefore, you should consult with a local medical professional on this issue who's familiar with the laws in your area.

Alternatively, you could consider non-invasive methods like cell-free DNA screening (cfDNA). This test analyses DNA from the mother and baby that circulates in the mother’s bloodstream. Whilst not diagnostic, cfDNA testing has a higher accuracy rate (around 99%) in predicting the

input: Hello doctor,My mother is 75 years old. She is suffering from head spinning and heaviness problem since the last six months. Her BP, sugar, thyroid and other blood test reports are normal. After getting a suggestion from a doctor (Medicine) she had gone on an MRI test. The MRI test (non-contrast) of brain report was given with a doubt of evidence of blooming in GRE in the left parietal lobe and right basifrontal lobe without evidence of perilesional edema and advised for further evaluation with contrast to rule out calcified granulomas and other etiologies. Also, MRI report findings include:Small vessel white matter ischemic changes.Chronic lacunar infarct in the right external capsule.Mild cerebral atrophic changes.The Doctor of medicine gave medicines for the treatment of vertigo and nerve but suggested to show immediately to a neurologist. My mother does not know the brain problem and she refuses to go to a doctor for further checking due to her fear. So, I need your help.
output:
Your mother's MRI scan reveals some concerning findings. 

1. Small vessel white matter ischemic changes and a chronic lacunar infarct are signs of a lack of blood flow in certain areas of the brain, possibly due to small strokes. This could certainly be causing her dizziness. It often lurks without symptoms until it has caused significant damage, so it is imperative that she is treated properly to prevent more serious consequences like a major stroke.

2. The findings of blooming in the GRE (a type of MRI sequence) suggest there might be deposits or lesions within these regions of the brain which may need further evaluation. While these might not be causing her immediate symptoms, it is important to seek specialist advice to ascertain their nature. 

3. As per mild cerebral atrophic changes, this typically refers to shrinkage or loss of brain volume, which tends to occur with aging. However, it can sometimes be related to neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer's disease. 

The consultation with a neurologist would help guide further investigations into the cause of your mother's symptoms, including potential neurological issues. Vertigo and heavy-headedness, along with her radiological findings, definitely warrant a neurology follow up. You'll probably have to talk to your mother about the seriousness of the situation and gently persuade her to see a neurologist. Her fear is understandable, but untreated health problems can lead to far scarier outcomes than going to the doctor.

input: Hi doctor,I have a small white scar on the lower lip for seven months. It was not white at first. But now it just stays there and does not show any change.
output:
The change in color of the scar over time is relatively common. Over time, scars often lose their pigmentation and become white or lighter than the surrounding skin. It can also be an outcome of exposure to sunlight. If there are no other symptoms such as pain, itchiness, expansion of the scar size, etc., it's probably not something to worry about, but consistent monitoring would be beneficial.

However, remember that without physically examining you, it's hard to make a definitive diagnosis. You should consider getting checked by your primary care doctor or a dermatologist if you're concerned, especially if there's any chance this could be from sun damage (as some forms of skin cancer can present as persistent small spots).

input: Hi doctor,I am struggling to get up early in the morning. I sleep for eight hours every day. I press the snooze button many times, but still, I cannot wake up early. I became irregular to the work which became a barrier to my career. Currently, I am taking tablet Fluvoxin 100 mg in the afternoon for OCD and depression, tablet Oxetol 450 mg in the evening for gelastic seizure, tablet Quetiapine 100 mg at night for delusions.
output:
Based on the medications you're taking, it seems like you have multiple neurological and psychiatric conditions that could influence your sleep patterns or get impacted by alterations in drowsiness or fatigue. Firstly, you could be feeling drowsy due to the effect of certain drugs; Quetiapine can often cause sedation and Fluvoxin may contribute as well.

Before making any modifications to your current treatment regime, it would be recommended to discuss these symptoms extensively with your consulting psychiatrist. Try maintaining regular sleep hygiene practices like going to bed at a particular time daily, reducing screen-time before sleeping, avoiding caffeine intake in the evening, keeping the room dark when sleeping, etc. You may also consider seeing a sleep specialist if these measures do not help to improve your morning wakefulness. They might suggest performing a sleep study to look for any underlying sleep disorders like sleep apnea which might be contributing to your excessive daytime sleepiness.

Also note, abruptly stopping or altering the dosage of these medications can lead to unwanted effects so they should only be done under strict medical supervision. Please consult with your prescribing doctor regarding this.

input: Hello doctor,I had unprotected sex on 1st of last month and missed my period on 20th. I did a urine pregnancy test on 3rd of this month, it came negative and then I took Regestrone 10 mg for five days one tablet each day from 3rd to 7th. Then on 8th, I did a bhCG which came negative and today I got a slight spotting and when wiping a little brownish kinda discharge came. Am I pregnant?
output: If both your urine pregnancy test and blood bhCG test are negative, it is unlikely that you are pregnant. Slight spotting and brownish discharge can be due to numerous factors including hormonal shifts (possibly induced by the Regestrone you've taken), stress, changes in weight, or other health issues. However, if you continue to miss your periods or experience abnormal bleeding or other symptoms such as pain, please consult with your healthcare provider for further evaluation. It's also important to remember to always use protection during intercourse unless you are planning a pregnancy, not only to prevent unwanted pregnancies but also to protect against sexually transmitted diseases.

input: Hello doctor,I was running, and I fell into a pit. My ankle got twisted, and I could feel some cracking sound. I had a swollen ankle immediately. I have been icing for 2 days and now the swelling has reduced. I am unable to walk. I have pain when I try to move or walk. I had a fracture fibula of the same ankle 5 years back. Please help.
output: I'm sorry to hear about your accident. It seems like you might have sprained or possibly fractured your ankle, especially considering the history of a prior fibula fracture. It's not a good sign that you're unable to walk and still experiencing pain even after 2 days with ice treatment. I would strongly advise you to visit an ER as soon as possible. They can do an X-ray to determine if there is a fracture or severe ligament injury. In the meantime, continue to apply ice, elevate the leg, and avoid putting weight on it until you can be seen by a healthcare professional.

input: Hello doctor,The semen analysis report is in my hand, but I cannot understand it.Liquefaction time- 30 minutes.Duration of abstinence- four days.Appearance- creamy white.Volume 4.0 ml.Ph 8Fructose- Present.Motility- 100.Spermatozoa- rapid 20%, slow 10%, non-progressive motility 5%, immotile 83%.Vitality count- 15 million.Morphology- normal 20%, abnormal 80%.
output:
Hello,

Your semen analysis report is important in checking the health of your sperm and evaluating their potential for fertility. Here's an understanding based on what you provided:

1. **Liquefaction time:** This refers to how long it takes your semen to change from a thick gel-like substance into a liquid. Normal liquefaction time is usually within 20-30 minutes. So, your result is considered normal.

2. **Duration of abstinence:** It indicates the number of days before collecting the semen sample without sexual activity. Four days is generally appropriate as typically, doctors suggest abstaining from ejaculation between 2-7 days before testing.

3. **Appearance & Volume:** A creamy white appearance is standard for semen, so that's normal. And a volume of 4.0 ml is also within the acceptable range (normal volumes are between 1.5ml and 6.5ml). 

4. **pH level:** Your pH value of 8 falls into the typical pH range (7.2 -7.8), indicating no infection or blockage in the seminal vesicles.

5. **Fructose presence:** Its presence indicates healthy functioning of the seminal vesicles, which produce fructose in semen.

6. **Sperm motility and vitality count:** The overall motility seems to be 100%, but there might be a typo since immotile sperm percentage is 83%. Normal range for total motility (which includes all sperms moving regardless of being

input: Hello doctor,I was seen in the ER for a possible kidney stone. I did have blood in my urine. No stone was found. The only thing noted on my CT scan reads \x80\x9ccircumferential urinary bladder wall thickening versus under distension\x80\x9d. What does this mean? Is this a sign of bladder cancer? What follow-up is needed?
output:
"Circumferential urinary bladder wall thickening versus under distension" means that the entire (circumferential) wall of your bladder appears to be thicker than normal on the CT scan. This could be due to a number of reasons:
1. "Underdistention" - Your bladder was not full enough during the CT scan, and this can sometimes make the bladder wall appear thicker than it actually is.
2. An inflammation/infection of the bladder also known as cystitis.
3. Less commonly, bladder cancer could cause bladder wall thickening.

However, this does not automatically mean you have bladder cancer. Many cancers will present with other symptoms like painless hematuria (blood in urine) which may or may not be visible, frequent urination, painful urination, etc.

As for your follow-up, you might need an ultrasound or possibly another form of imaging study to eliminate any doubt regarding underdistention. Also, ruling out bladder infection would potentially involve taking a urine culture test. If these do not show any abnormalities and if you continue to show symptoms, your healthcare provider might perform a cystoscopy, which is a procedure to visually inspect the inside of your bladder using a specialized piece of equipment called a cystoscope. 

Please keep up continuous communication with your healthcare provider about all your concerns and symptoms. They will guide you best according to their clinical judgement and your health status.

input: Hello doctor,I am a 50-year-old male. I had genital warts five years ago, had them removed via cauterization and received three injections of HPV vaccine Gardasil. The doctor said the vaccine would cure the virus, but after a year, warts reappeared and until now they are still in my scrotum, and they are itchy but not painful. My question is that can I have sex with my partner given my current condition? Have I got cured by HPV vaccine?
output:
The HPV vaccine is designed to prevent certain types of HPV infections, but it does not cure an existing infection. It's also important to know that while the HPV vaccine protects against many strains of virus, it does not cover all types of HPV.

As for your current condition - genital warts are caused by some types of human papilloma virus (HPV). They can be spread even when you have no symptoms, since HPV may still be present on the skin. This means you could potentially transmit the virus to a sex partner.

Wart recurrence suggests there might be continued presence or re-infection with wart-causing HPV strains. Talk to your healthcare provider about effective ways to manage your symptoms and to understand how to protect others. Condoms can lower the risk of transmitting the virus but they do not completely eliminate it because HPV can infect areas not covered by a condom. 

Please remember that although this information was given by a doctor, online advice should never replace direct medical consultation.

input: Hello doctor,I am a male, 23 years old, weight is 65 kg, height is 5\9". My penis is not getting hard for sex. The penis is getting erect but not getting hard enough. Due to this, I am not able to put my penis inside the vagina. Also, I ejaculate within 10 to 15 seconds (3 to 4 stock). And now I am avoiding sex because of this problem and getting less interest day by day. I do smoke regularly and drink occasionally also. I used to watch porn in excess and masturbate regularly. Please help me out. I am very much tensed about my future sex life. Please consult me what to do I want to get rid of this major issue. I cannot tell this issue to my family or friends also. I do not have enough money to consult a doctor privately. Please look into the matter.
output:
Your symptoms sound like a combination of erectile dysfunction (ED) and premature ejaculation, both common yet treatable conditions.

Here are some suggestions:

1. Lifestyle changes: Smoking has been linked to ED. Consider quitting smoking and limiting your alcohol intake, as these can worsen sexual health problems. Work on maintaining a healthy lifestyle with regular exercise and a balanced diet. Reducing stress where possible will also help.

2. Limit porn consumption & masturbation: Excess watching of porn and chronic masturbation may condition arousal to certain stimuli that aren't replicated in real-world experiences, leading to difficulties.

3. Sexual techniques: Techniques like the "start-stop" and "squeeze" methods can help manage premature ejaculation. These involve stimulating the penis and stopping before feeling like orgasm is near. 

4. Medication: While you mentioned financial constraints, but it's worth knowing there are medications available for treating these issues. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) have been used to treat premature ejaculation and phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE-5) inhibitors are used for treating erectile dysfunction.

However, I would strongly advise seeking professional medical advice even if finances are an issue. There could be underlying medical conditions causing your symptoms that need to be addressed. Discuss your situation with local clinics or health centers - many offer services on a sliding scale. It's important to remember your health should be top priority.

input: Hello doctor,One week ago, I had intercourse on my third day of the period and after approximately 30 hours of that, I have taken an i-pill. From the next day of taking the pill, I had severe back pain and lower abdomen pain which continues for one week. And after one week, I started bleeding and right now do not know why I am still bleeding? Is it my period that came again?
output:
The bleeding you're experiencing is likely due to the emergency contraceptive (i-pill) you took. These pills work primarily by preventing or delaying ovulation, and they can also cause changes in the uterus that discourage implantation of a fertilized egg. One common side effect of these pills is unexpected vaginal bleeding.

This type of bleeding is not menstrual blood but breakthrough bleeding, which might occur after taking an i-pill. It usually starts 5-7 days after taking the pill and may continue until your next expected period. The lower abdomen pain and back pain could be other side effects of the medicine as well.

However, if bleeding becomes severe or lasts more than a week, or if abdominal and back pain persists or increases, you should seek immediate medical attention. These symptoms could be indicative of other conditions such as an ectopic pregnancy or infection. 

Remember, emergency contraceptive pills are not intended for regular use. They are for emergencies only and efficacy decreases with repeated use. Long-term birth control methods are much more effective at preventing pregnancies. Consult your healthcare provider about what method is best for you.

input: Hello doctor,I am seeking experts to comment on low-carb diets.What is the complete macronutrient breakdown for a typical low-carb diet? How much fat should you eat on a low-carb diet? How much protein should you eat on a low-carb diet?We are looking for suggestions on vegan foods for energy. Name the foods you are recommending and set description as to why you are suggesting this food.
output:
A typical low-carb diet restricts the percentage of calories derived from carbohydrates, and emphasizes consumption of proteins & fats. While there is no strict standard, commonly people limit their daily carb intake to 50-150 grams. The macronutrient breakdown can vary according to individual requirements, but a general estimation would be as follows:

1. Carbohydrates: 5-10% of total daily calories 
2. Protein: 20-30% of total daily calories
3. Fat: 60-75% of total daily calories

Though the exact amount depends on your specific daily calorie needs, in a 2000-calorie-a-day diet this translates into carbohydrate intake below 100g, protein around 100-150g and quite high fat-intake could be between 133 -166g.

For vegan foods that may help with energy boosts I recommend the following:

1. Quinoa: It is a complete plant-based protein source and it has a great balance of carbs, protein and fiber which keeps you energetic throughout the day.
  
2. Blueberries: These fruits are packed with antioxidants. They've also got a good amount of soluble fiber, which slows down the absorption of sugar, providing long-lasting energy.
   
3. Avocado: High in healthy fats attracting more sustained levels of energy without spiking blood sugar levels.

4. Lentils: Rich in complex carbohydrates and fibers, lentils can give a slow and steady energy release, combined with being an excellent

input: Hello doctor, I think I am bipolar. Just a couple of weeks ago, I felt and was told by my friends that I was more energetic and crazy than usual. Now, I feel like there is no hope, and nobody really cares. But there is also that little bit of me that is telling me that I am faking this and that all I want is attention. I just want to know what the heck is up with my head.
output:
While I'm an AI and can't diagnose conditions, it sounds like you're going through a tough time. Your description suggests you might be experiencing high mood swings, which can indeed be symptoms of bipolar disorder - episodes of mania (feeling very high or overactive) followed by periods of depression (feeling low and lacking in energy). However, bear in mind that several other conditions may present similar symptoms. The feeling that you're "faking it" could actually be related to the depressive phase and feelings of worthlessness associated with it.

Please don't try to self-diagnose based on information found online; it's important to reach out to a healthcare professional to discuss these feelings. Mental health is just as essential as physical health, so please get the support you need. A mental health professional will be able to provide a proper diagnosis and treatment plan after performing a thorough evaluation. You're not alone, and it's crucial to ask for help when you need it. Remember, it's okay not to be okay.

input: Hi doctor,I am 29 years of age. I had unprotected sex and I am having sex with the same partner for more than a year and a half. Suddenly, I got itching sensation and found that I have got itchy bumps on my penis which started clustering together. Later, it healed automatically. I also found when I run or walk a long distance and feel sweaty, I feel the sensation and I get the bumps again. These bumps are small and shiny at the tip and often get clustered and gets healed. It does not give me a problem but I really feel demoralized and unfit. I do not have these problems regularly. Also for a long time, I have itchy inner thighs because of which my skin turned blackish white and is still itchy. I am not sure whether I am infected. Please suggest me the solution to get diagnosed. I can provide pictures if required.
output:
Based on your description, it's possible that you might be dealing with a recurrent infection or an allergic reaction. However, a few conditions come to mind based on your symptoms:

1. Genital warts which are caused by human papillomavirus (HPV). They usually appear as small flesh-colored bumps and since you mentioned unprotected sex, there could be some risk of sexually transmitted infections.

2. Molluscum contagiosum, a viral skin infection that results in round, smooth, painless bumps, often with a tiny dot or indention at the center.

3. Balanitis, inflammation due to allergies or irritations from products such as soaps, detergents etc.
