Since more than ten years two cyst was there and of late it merged intoone.May be in the second week of last month, I started getting an itching sensation andthe place becoming red and after a few days it burst. Since then regularly it is being dressedwith the removal of pus. It has created a deep hole. Please help.
output:
Although you're trying to avoid surgery, it's important to know that in many cases it's the best option for preventing a recurrent sebaceous cyst infection. Continual draining and antibiotics may not completely eliminate the disease if the sac of the cyst is still present under the skin.

However, since you currently prefer non-surgical options, here's what we can do:

1. Continue local care: Keep the area clean and maintain regular dressing changes. This will help limit further infections and promote healing.

2. Antibiotics: If there's ongoing drainage and inflammation even after completing the antibiotic's course, you might need another round or a different medication, based on sensitivity patterns of the exuded pus (if culture and sensitivity tests were done).

3. Topical Treatment: Some studies suggest certain medical-grade honey dressings or other topical treatments can aid wound healing. 

But remember, these approaches will just manage your current situation, and likely won't prevent future cyst flair-ups as effectively as surgical removal. So should there be no improvements or if it worsens weeks or months from now, I highly recommend getting in touch with a surgeon to discuss options relevant to your individual case. Also, please coordinate with your healthcare provider for any decision you make regarding your treatment.

input: Hello doctor,I suppose to get the sleeve bariatric surgery and I was taking Adepix and I stopped it a week ago. My surgeon told me he thinks I have to be off Adepix for three months before surgery. I only took it for three weeks. Is this true? He said it may interfere with anesthesia?
output:
Adipex-P (Phentermine) is a medication used for weight loss and it's important that you discontinue taking it prior to your bariatric surgery for a few reasons. First, Phentermine can increase heart rate and blood pressure, which may cause issues during anesthesia and surgery.

Second, there are concerns with possible interactions between this medication and certain anesthetics. It has the potential to interact adversely with other medications given during surgery, potentially leading to serious complications such as pulmonary hypertension or heart problems.

The specific time frame to stop using Phentermine prior to surgery can vary, but a common guideline is to stop at least two weeks before surgery. However, your surgeon might have more stringent guidelines based on their experiences or any particular risk factors you may have.

It's vital that you follow your surgeon's instructions regarding when to cease taking this medication prior to your procedure. If you have any further questions or concerns, they should be directed to your surgeon or the anesthesiologist who will be involved in your care.

input: Hello doctor,About four weeks ago, my right testicle started moving in an uncomfortable (not painful) way. I had a torsion and surgery to stitch down (both) 2.5 years ago. I went to the first doctor and he tried me on muscle relaxants, nothing changed so he referred me to a specialist. The specialist had a quick feel and then told me it was normal, that I should not worry and that I would have to get used to it. He also implied it has been happening since the operation and I just did not notice.There is still no pain, only discomfort (it varies) normally when I walk. I think that my right testicle is a tiny bit swollen and slightly squishier than my left and while I could live with this, I really do not want to. Though I have suffered no injuries to my testicles recently, I actually think that one of my stitches has come loose as I can feel the end on the stitch lump where I could not before. I am 88 kilos and have lost 12 kg over the last nine months. I have have been running more frequently for about eight weeks. I am 24 years old.
output:
Your change in physical activity (running more frequently) with weight loss could very well relate to the discomfort you're feeling, as high-impact activities often cause 'jostling' of the testicles and this is pronounced with individuals having had prior surgery or issues. The sensation of a loose stitch may indicate that one of the sutures used during your operation has worked its way toward the surface, which is not uncommon.

However, noticeable swelling on one side should be investigated. Epididymitis, inflammation of the tube at the back of the testicle, can sometimes account for changes in size/consistency, although it's usually associated with pain. 

While your specialist’s advice cannot be dismissed, if you are uncomfortable with his conclusion, please consider getting a second opinion. Using an ultrasound will provide definitive imagery about the state of the testicle, stitches, blood supply etc., making it much easier to diagnose and treat any potential problem. It's also important to ensure self-exam regularly and report any changes promptly. If the discomfort persists or get worse, make sure to consult another urologist soon.

input: Hello doctor,I weaned off of 40 mg of Paroxetine very slowly but my sleep was impacted and as of two months, I have been suffering from extreme insomnia. I have gone back to medication and I am currently on 20 mg of Paroxetine and 10 mg of Fluoxetine, but my insomnia has continued. I was prescribed Ativan (0.5 mg) for sleep, and it sometimes helps, but not always. Even if I take a bit more (I have taken up to .75 total), it does not always help me sleep. My psychiatrist prescribed Trazodone (she suggested I start at 25 mg and if I feel no effect, to take another 25 mg/ go up to 50 mg in one night (but I am concerned about serotonin syndrome from taking another medication that messes with Serotonin). Can you advise if I should be concerned about serotonin syndrome if I take the 25 (or 50) mg of Trazodone? Additionally, should I be concerned about anything else in terms of taking these three medications together?
output:
Serotonin syndrome can occur when you increase the dose of certain types of medications, or add a new drug to your current regimen. Symptoms usually occur within several hours of taking the new medication and can range from mild (shivering and diarrhea) to severe (muscle rigidity, fever and seizures).

In rare cases serotonin syndrome has been reported when SSRIs/SNRIs (like Paroxetine and Fluoxetine) are taken in combination with Trazodone. The risk might be higher with higher doses. Therefore it is important that if Trazodone is added as an adjunct treatment then it should be started at a lower dose initially.

However, keep in mind that while the risk does exist, overall it's quite low, and most people do not develop serotonin syndrome when combining these medicines under medical supervision.

The primary purpose of Trazodone is antidepressant but because of its sedative effects, it is also used by some individuals for insomnia.

Ativan which is a benzodiazepine can sometimes cause dependence or tolerance over time, meaning you may feel like you need to gradually increase your dose to get the same effect. It's meant for short term use and ideally shouldn't be relied upon long term.

Overall these medications have different mechanisms of action and can potentially interact so it is important that your doctor closely monitors you whilst you're on them. They'll weigh up all the potential benefits, risks and side effects, including things other than serotonin syndrome, like withdrawal symptoms, adverse effects

input: Hi doctor,I am 24 and having an active sexual life. I have two questions. First I have noticed that my performance is erratic as in there are times when I can last 5-6 minutes and then the very next day it can go to 30-35 minutes. It is different with different partners. Second and more alarming is that I have been experiencing a stinging pain in my scrotum on the left side it usually happens when I stand up while sitting or laying and sometimes while walking. I tried finding the source of the pain by pressing in different regions but could not find one. Also, it happens at the back side of the scrotum. It is limited to the left side and has been increasing with each passing day. I thought of UTI, but my pee does not burn. Can I have some suggestions for my problems? Thank you.
output:
Sexual stamina can vary greatly based on various factors, such as anxiety, stress, fatigue, or arousal level. Therefore, the variation in your performance is not necessarily abnormal. If it's causing significant distress, consider consulting a mental health specialist experienced in sexual health for further evaluation and possible treatment options.

The pain in your left scrota could be due to various causes including epididymitis (inflammation of the tube at the back of testicle that stores and carries sperm), varicocele (enlargement of the veins within the loose bag of skin that holds your testicles), or other conditions. Some of these can be serious and must be evaluated promptly by a healthcare professional. It could also be referred pain, meaning it originates from a different area. 

I would strongly advise you to schedule an appointment with your primary care doctor or a urologist as soon as possible. This will allow them to do a physical examination, possibly order some imaging or lab tests, and provide a more accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment. In case of severe worsening pain or associated symptoms like blood in your urine, swelling in your scrotum or fever, seek immediate medical care.

input: Hello doctor,The gums where my wisdom tooth is present is in pain.
output:
Hello, it sounds like you might be experiencing pericoronitis. This is an inflammation of the soft tissue surrounding the crown of a partially erupted tooth, usually the wisdom tooth. Symptoms can include pain, swelling, and sometimes an infection.

However, to form a concrete diagnosis, I would recommend visiting your dentist as soon as you can. They might take an X-ray or conduct a clinical exam to ascertain the state of your wisdom teeth. Treatment may range from cleaning the infected area, prescribing antibiotics, to potentially removing the problematic wisdom tooth if necessary.

It's important for you to get professional help because complications can arise if infections from the gum are left untreated. Painkillers over the counter can assist in managing the pain temporarily but please make sure to seek dental treatment immediately. Remember this advice does not replace a thorough clinical examination and delivery of healthcare.

input: Hi doctor,I had unprotected sex with my partner without any penetration. I rubbed my penis over her vagina. I might have a little semen present in it. She usually has a periods cycle of 33 to 35 days. But her periods got delayed this month. Is she pregnant? Why is there a delay in her periods? Is there any typical food available to bring her periods on time?
output:
Although the chance is considerably smaller, pregnancy can happen from pre-ejaculate fluids (precum) as they can occasionally contain viable sperm. The risk increases if any semen was present on your penis as you describe. It's also worth mentioning that periods can often be delayed due to a variety of reasons: hormonal imbalance, stress, sudden weight loss or gain, and certain medical conditions. Pregnancy is only one of many possible explanations for a missed period.

If her period is late and there's a possibility of pregnancy, it might be wise to take a home pregnancy test. These are usually accurate around the time of an expected period or a few days afterwards.

There's no credible evidence to suggest that any particular food would induce menstruation. If she continues to have irregular cycles, it may be a good idea for her to speak with her healthcare provider. 

It's extremely important to remember only condoms can reduce the risk of sexually transmitted diseases. If you're not ready to conceive a child, consider using more reliable methods of contraception.

input: Hi doctor,I am a 20 year old girl and have a small vaginal opening. My husband and I hardly have sex because it hurts me so badly. What can I do to stop it from being so painful?
output:
Painful intercourse (dyspareunia) can be caused by several different conditions, so it's important to seek medical advice for a proper diagnosis and treatment plan. Your small vaginal opening could be due to a condition called Vaginismus, which involves involuntary muscle spasms in the pelvic floor muscles that can make sexual intercourse difficult or impossible.

To manage this discomfort, here are some options:

1. Pelvic floor exercises: These can help improve control over your pelvic region and reduce painful sensitivity.

2. Use of lubricants: Dryness is another factor that can contribute to pain during intercourse. High-quality water or silicone-based lubricants may help.

3. Gradual Desensitization: This often includes vaginal dilators that come in a range of sizes. Starting with the smallest size, you're encouraged to insert these into your vagina on your own or under professional guidance.

4. Psychosexual counseling: This can be beneficial if psychological factors are contributing to the issue.

5. Consultation with your healthcare provider: They can provide potential medicines or other therapies like local anesthetics to numb the sensitive area or muscle relaxants for painful spasms.

Remember, every woman is unique and what works for one woman might not work for another. It’s essential to consult with a gynecologist who can evaluate your specific circumstances and suggest treatments based on their assessments.

input: Hello doctor,A throbbing and recurring headache, nausea, and dizziness. I am an 18-year-old female.
output:
The symptoms you've described could indicate a number of things, including migraines, dehydration, anaemia, or even something like an infection or virus. However, without knowing more details and your medical history, it's impossible to determine the exact cause.

To better understand these symptoms:

1. How long have you been experiencing this headache?
2. Could you locate where exactly the pain is?
3. Have there been any changes in your daily routine or diet recently?
4. Are there any specific triggers that seem to bring on the headaches?
5. Do you have any other symptoms like fever, visual disturbances, sensitivity to light, or strong smells?

It would also be helpful for you to seek a medical evaluation in person with a healthcare professional. If the headache becomes severe, you should seek immediate medical attention.

input: Hi doctor,My mother is 65 years old (height 4\11", weight 64 kg), and has been doing all the household chores since she was 20 years. She has no problems except diabetes. Since one week, she started getting lower back pain. The symptoms are if she is in a sleeping position and gets up and starts walking, there is no problem. But if she is in a sitting position and gets up to walk, there is sharp lower back pain. Can you please let me know what could be the reason? How can the pain be relieved? Any special exercises or chair or vitamin supplements, etc.?
output:
Your mom's back pain could be due to several factors, which include:

1. Sciatica: This is when pressure or damage to the sciatic nerve causes pain in the lower back that can radiate down one of the legs.
2. Lumbar spinal stenosis: This typically occurs as the result of natural age-related changes. It happens when there’s a narrowing of the spaces within your spine, which puts pressure on the nerves.
3. Disc diseases, like a herniated disc or degenerative disc disease: Constant doing house chores might placed repeated stresses on her spine over the years
4. Musculoskeletal strain or sprain from lifting heavy things.

To properly diagnose this condition a physical examination followed by diagnostic imaging (eg. X-ray, MRI) might be necessary after appropriate consultation with your family physician or orthopedic doctor.

For relief of symptoms following steps could be beneficial:

1. Over-the-counter medications like acetaminophen (Tylenol), ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve).
2. Moving around without overstressing the particular region: Encourage your mother to continue light activity such as walking at her own pace. Inactivity might make her stiffness and pain worse.
3. Physical therapy 
   
Following exercises might help :

i. Leg lifts while lying flat on floor: This strengthens the hip and abdominal muscles.

ii. Wall squats: For strengthening lower back and leg muscles.

iii.

input: Hi doctor,I am having some allergy on the head part and the inner skin of my penis. I have some white bubble like spots. Please help.
output:
Your condition could be balanitis, a form of dermatitis affecting the penis, often associated with yeast or bacterial infection. However, diagnoses can not be solely done based on the description provided as many conditions may present similar symptoms like Pearly Penile Papules, Fordyce's spots, or sexually transmitted diseases.

It's important to remember not to self-diagnose or self-treat these symptoms, especially since they are in a sensitive area. I would strongly recommend you seek medical attention from a healthcare provider or a urologist for physical evaluation. They may suggest tests or swabs to find out the exact cause, then treatment will depend on that result. Meanwhile, maintain good hygiene, avoid any sexual activity until diagnosed and treated completely.

input: Hello doctor,I am not able to conceive after trying for almost one year. I was diagnosed with pituitary microadenoma and I am on medication. My prolactin levels have now reached normal levels after two months taking medication.I suffer from hypothyroidism and on medication. I have had this for five years now and it is well within the limits as per my endocrinologist now. This is due to an autoimmune disease where my TPO (thyroid peroxidase) antibodies were high during the diagnosis five years ago. My husband and I would like to know how should we best prepare for pregnancy and what to look out for. We would have preferred to visit the clinic. Unfortunately, I am not in a position to visit the doctor due to travel restrictions. It would be great to get in touch with a specialist.I am currently on Euthrox 100 mcg, Cabergoline 0.25 mg once a week, and Folic acid 450 mg daily.
output:
Firstly, I am glad to know that your prolactin and thyroid levels are well controlled with medication. It's really important for both of these hormones to be within the normal limits before trying for a pregnancy as they can affect fertility and baby's health. Now let's move on how best you can prepare.

1. Continue taking medicines: Do not stop taking any of the three medications (Euthrox, Cabergoline, Folic acid) until your doctor asks you to. They help in maintaining proper hormonal balance for conception.
 
2. Preconception Checkup: If possible, it is highly recommended to get a preconception checkup done. This helps the doctor assess your overall health status and change any medication or doses if required.

3. Prenatal Vitamins: You're already taking folic acid which is great. Apart from this, there are other essential vitamins like Vitamin D, B12, etc which are also crucial for healthy development of fetus and for avoiding any complications during pregnancy. Get them checked and take supplements if needed.

4. Ovulation Period: Try having intercourse during the fertile window i.e., days when you are most likely to conceive (usually day 12 - day 16 of menstrual cycle).

5. Healthy Lifestyle: Eat a balanced diet filled with fruits, vegetables, lean protein, and whole grains. Regular exercise will also assist in maintaining a healthy body weight which bring about easier conception.

6. Limit Stress: High stress levels can

input: Hi doctor,I am a 45 year old male. I had an accident before 10 years. At that time, my knee x-ray was done and I was reported to have osteoarthritis. I have been suffering from pain for few years. I have lower back pain and pain in some of the joints. For the past few weeks, I have pain in my left palm, particularly in my finger joints and more on left middle finger joint. Also, on my foot joints. I also feel very fatigued and tired. My blood pressure (BP) was 110/70 mmHg a week back. I am enclosing a comprehensive blood test report, which was done very recently and I have advised to take tablet Nusam 400 for six months. I have been taking for the past two months. Please suggest me the remedy and preventive measures.
output:
Based on the symptoms and history you've given, it seems like your osteoarthritis is progressing. Osteoarthritis can affect multiple joints including the knees, fingers, back, and foot as you've mentioned. 

The medication Nusam 400 contains S-Adenosyl Methionine which is often used to improve pain and swelling in arthritis but everyone's response might differ.

For managing your condition, I would suggest:

1. Physical Activity: Regular, moderate exercise that doesn't cause further joint pain or injury can help with stiffness and overall health. A mix of cardiovascular exercises (like walking or swimming) and strength-building ones can be beneficial.

2. Weight Control: If you are overweight, weight loss can reduce pressure on weight-bearing joints and limit progression of arthritis.

3. Pain Management: Nonprescription NSAIDs (nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs) may relieve pain. Topical medications (creams, rubs) applied over the joint can provide temporary relief.

4. Diet: Although there's no definitive arthritis diet, some foods seem to bring a degree of inflammation reduction such as those rich in Omega-3 fatty acids (like fish), antioxidants (fruits, vegetables, nuts). Drinking plenty of water also helps keep cartilage healthy.

5. Joint Care: Certain activities and movements should be avoided to prevent stressing your affected joints. Some mobility aids and simple devices you can use day-to-day can make tasks less painful.

6. Fatigue Management: Ade

input: Hello doctor,My right side jaw is paining while having food. On consultation, I was advised for physiotherapy. What could be the reason for it?
output:
It sounds like you might be suffering from temporomandibular joint disorder (TMJ). The Temporomandibular Joint is the connection between your jawbone and skull. When there's a problem or dysfunction with this joint, it can cause pain in your jaw area especially when chewing or talking, headaches, earaches, and even difficulty to fully open or close your mouth.

Physiotherapy could be advised in your case as it helps in managing pain and rehabilitating the jaw function by exercises aimed at improving flexibility and strength around the TMJ area. Other treatments options for TMJ disorders include pain relievers and anti-inflammatories, moist heat and cold packs, oral splints or mouth guards, behavioural therapies and in some severe cases surgery can be required.

But remember, only a healthcare professional who has examined you could identify the exact reason for your jaw pain. So, follow their advice diligently.

input: Hi doctor,I have developed a small white dot on my thigh a few months back. Now, the size has increased. Is this any sign of leucoderma?
output:
Without a physical examination, it's difficult to conclusively diagnose your condition. However, your description could certainly align with symptoms of leucoderma (also known as vitiligo), which often appears as white patches on the skin that increase in size over time.

Keep in mind there are other conditions with similar symptoms, such as tinea versicolor or pityriasis alba, among others. 

You should set up an appointment with a dermatologist for a definite diagnosis. The doctor may use tools like a Wood’s lamp to look at your skin closely, and potentially take a small sample of your skin for testing. Early recognition and treatment can help manage the symptoms better.

input: Hi doctor,I was attacked by mumps around three years back and now my testicle sizes are different. So, I wanted to know about the treatment. Will I get rejected in visa medical test? I am a petroleum engineer. Please help.
output:
Mumps can sometimes lead to a condition called orchitis, which is an inflammation of one or both testicles. This could potentially be the reason for the differing size in your testicles. However, it's crucial that you consult with a urologist who can perform a proper medical evaluation. They could suggest treatments such as anti-inflammatory medications if appropriate.

As for the visa medical examination part, each country has its unique health requirements and conducts tests accordingly. In general terms, most countries primarily focus on contagious diseases such as TB, HIV/AIDS which pose a public health threat, not conditions like testicle size discrepancies. Nonetheless, policies may vary; thus, it's recommended to check with the specific immigration service of the country you are planning to move to.

In short, living with different sized testicles does not usually present significant health risks, but considering you have a history of mumps-associated orchitis, it's essential to get regular follow-ups with your healthcare provider.

input: Hello doctor,I have stretch marks on my whole body, and I want to remove them as they are white. Please suggest me some medicine to remove them in a year as after a year I have my marriage. And I get these stretch marks at the time of puberty, and I had mentally suffered because of the stretch marks, and I cannot wear sleeveless clothes.
output:
I can understand the distress you must be feeling due to stretch marks. Here are a few strategies that might help:

1. Topical treatments: Using creams, oils and lotions designed specifically for stretch marks may accelerate fading process. For instance, Tretinoin cream or Retin-A has been shown to improve the appearance of early stretch marks. Please consult a dermatologist before using any prescription creams.

2. Microdermabrasion: This is a procedure where tiny crystals are spread onto the skin and then vacuumed up. This method removes a fine layer of skin, and with it, some of the stretch marks. Multiple sessions may be needed for significant improvement.

3. Laser therapy: Different types of laser treatment could either stimulate collagen and elastin production or affect the color of your stretch marks. But these can be costly and require multiple sittings.

4. Microneedling: This procedure involves pricking your skin with tiny needles. It aims to stimulate collagen and heal the skin which may reduce stretch marks over time.

Remember, all these methods may not fully remove stretch marks but can make them less noticeable. Also, response to treatment vary from person to person. Please consider seeing a dermatologist who can recommend a personalized approach based on your specific condition and medical history. 

Most importantly, know that having stretch marks is normal, particularly after puberty, pregnancy, or weight changes. It does not impact your health and should never lead to personal distress or discomfort. If this is affecting

input: Hello doctor,My mother was not having her periods from the past five years, but from yesterday, she started bleeding again. In these five years, she has not even bled for a single day. Why is she bleeding all of a sudden? What can be the cause?
output:
Your mother's sudden bleeding needs immediate medical evaluation. Considering your mother hasn't had her periods for five years, it seems like she is likely postmenopausal. Postmenopausal bleeding can be a sign of several conditions, some of which are serious. 

The most common causes include polyps (benign growths) from the cervix or uterus, endometrial atrophy (thinning of the uterine lining), and endometrial hyperplasia (thickening of the uterine lining). The latter two are due to hormonal imbalances.

In rarer cases, it can also be associated with more serious conditions such as pelvic organ prolapse or postmenopausal cancers like cervical cancer or endometrial cancer. While many of these causes aren't necessarily severe or dangerous, others require prompt treatment. Therefore, this isn't something to ignore - I advise you to arrange a Gynecological examination for her promptly.

input: Good day, please i was diagnose with hep b positive 18months ago, my consulting tild me my condition i\xc5\x9f inactive and need no medication. some month back i was feeling hurt at my chest i was later diagnose with ulcer. some some weeks now have been having pains around my chest and most especially middle of my check. please what is happening to me?
output: I'm sorry to hear that you're not feeling well. The chest pain could be related to your ulcer, especially if it's a gastric (stomach) ulcer which can sometimes cause pain or discomfort in the mid-chest area. An inactive status of hepatitis B doesn't mean it cannot flare up and cause symptoms, but these are typically fatigue, joint pains, loss of appetite rather than chest pain. However, chest pain should always be taken seriously because it can also be an indication of heart conditions, lung conditions, and other serious illness. It would be best for you to seek immediate medical attention to rule out any life-threatening conditions such as a heart disease. They may conduct further tests such as EKGs, blood test, endoscopy, X-rays, etc. to evaluate your condition more thoroughly. Please don't delay getting this checked.

input: Hello doctor,I got bitten by what I am thinking a spider a week back. I figured since it seemed to have a little white and liquid coming out. So, I squeezed it. It has been four days and the bite is painful. Now I have a white circle where it once was just red and oozing. I have tried Cortisone but I do not see it getting better.
output:
Based on your description, it sounds like you may have an infection or an abscess from the spider bite that needs treatment. Squeezing a spider bite can force bacteria deeper into the skin, leading to infections such as cellulitis (a common bacterial skin infection). The white circle could potentially be pus under the skin, which is another sign of an infection.

It's also important to mention that certain spiders (like brown recluse and black widow) are poisonous and their bites can cause severe reactions. 

Topical cortisone often does not help much with infections. You should immediately contact a healthcare professional for evaluation. Depending on severity, you might need antibiotics or even minor surgery to drain the infected area. It's advisable not repeat squeezing a spider bite again in future.

In addition, look out for systemic symptoms like fever, chills, or increasing pain--these would be reasons to seek urgent medical help. Please remember this is not a substitute for qualified medical advice and you should seek care promptly.

input: Hello doctor,I am having pain shooting down from my neck (just behind my right ear) down into my fingers. Also, on my right side near my breast with a slight headache as well. What it could be?
output:
I'm an AI, but based on your symptoms, this could be representative of several conditions. The pain shooting down from your neck to your fingers could possibly represent a pinched nerve in your neck (cervical radiculopathy) or another nerve-related condition. This kind of pain can also suggest issues with your peripheral nervous system. 

As for the pain near your breast area, it could be related to a number of things, ranging from muscular issues to potential problems with organs or tissues in that area. 

The slight headache could be associated with tension or stress, or even potentially tied to the same neurological issue causing your neck and arm pain.

Please be reminded that these are only possible explanations. It's crucial you get evaluated by a healthcare provider as soon as possible who can take a thorough history, perform physical examination, and decide if any diagnostic tests are needed to confirm the cause of your discomfort and guide treatment. Delaying medical attention especially if symptoms persist or worsen may lead to complications.

input: Hello doctor,I had an umbilical hernia repair 11 days ago. It went fine, but 10 days later when I laid down my belly button pup out one inch then went back down. The next morning my belly button is out half an inch. My surgeon said just wait for a couple of days to see if it goes back down. I need to know if I should wait or get in right away. The belly button is a little tender.
output:
As an AI doctor, I can tell you that this could potentially be a small recurrence of your hernia or post-surgical swelling but it could also be purely cosmetic due to changes in the umbilical contour after the surgery. If it is tender and starts to cause considerable pain, or you notice other symptoms like fever, nausea, vomiting, or if the bulge does not reduce on lying down, then these could be signs of complications and you should seek immediate medical attention.

The usual practice would be to follow your surgeon's advice as they are most familiar with your case. If you're uncomfortable with waiting, there is no harm seeking a second opinion right away just to remain safe.

input: Hello doctor,My baby is 36 days old. He is passing stool very frequently like 15 times with little or more motion but not very heavy in the last 48 hours. The stool was curdy yellowish color, not like runny or watery, no greenish, no blood, no bubbles. He had the same issue when he was 18 days old, and in between, he was healthy but again he kept going motion and redness spotted in anus area with small spots of skin peel.Baby sleeps well, does not cry, passes urine usually in a good number of times, and only mother breastfeeding every two hours. Please request your advice on how to stop this frequent motion and reason for this happening and is this normal? He also makes a noise like sounding from inside especially more during night time, having trouble while breathing due to a chest cold, so am giving Rinoclear saline drops three to six hours once depending on his nose block. Please advise why baby makes such noise, is it normal?I was feeding breast milk via bottle for four to five days when he was two weeks old since he was unable to suck through mother\s nipple. I stopped bottle when I encountered this frequent motion and with my doctor\s advice.
output:
Based on your baby's symptoms, it sounds like he could be having lactose overload or overactive letdown. This is quite common in exclusively breastfed babies and may cause them to have frequent bowel movements due to insufficient digestion of the lactose in the milk. The curdy yellowish color stools are a typical sign of exclusive breastfeeding and generally normal unless there is mucus or blood present.

Regarding his skin condition around the anus, it could be from the frequent wetness from stooling so often. It’s important to keep the area clean after each bowel movement and use an appropriate barrier cream to protect against irritation.

The sounds your infant is making might be related to his nasal congestion which you're treating with saline drops. Clearing his nasal passages will help him breathe easier. However, if you ever notice any signs of difficulty breathing, such as quickening breaths, flaring nostrils or cyanosis (bluish lips), seek immediate medical attention.

As you mentioned that you had issues with breastfeeding initially, in addition to addressing your baby's frequency of stools, I recommend reaching out to a lactation consultant who can address any concerns about feeding techniques, positioning, and overall breastfeeding management.

However, given the recurring issues it would be best to consult with your pediatrician just to ensure all is fine. They would be able to more directly examine your baby and make accurate evaluations.

input: Hello doctor,If I get my wisdom teeth extracted, do my second molars shift in that empty spot?
output:
After wisdom teeth extraction, there is no specific tendency for your second molars to shift into the empty spot by themselves. However, it's not uncommon to observe some sort of minor tooth movement after extraction,which might result in minor alterations in bite and alignment. Usually a gap left by an extracted tooth can potentially cause surrounding teeth to move to fill in the space over time, which can impact the overall balance of your bite.

The chance of such shifting is less likely as you age due to increased rigidity in the periodontal ligament fibers. Consulting with your dentist or oral surgeon is crucial since each patient's case is unique and they can go on to provide more accurate individualized advice post-removal care.

input: Hello doctor,I am in love with my relative. We both have each other in someplace in our mind and I know it. She is a high achiever in her career, and I work hard to achieve stuff and good at studies but not as high as her. I faced real kind of depression earlier and often get it. So, I find happiness in everything. What I find difficult is to commit to her in some way as I see she may get a better person who will be supportive to her achievement. I do not underestimate myself, but there is a dilemma which is hurting me in my mind. Please advice.
output:
As a doctor, I would like to say that mental health is just as important as physical health. The feelings you describe could lead to anxiety or worsened depression if they're not handled properly, so it's essential to address them.

Firstly, understand that everyone has their strengths and weaknesses. It sounds like you admire her for her achievements but remember that she may also admire you for qualities you have which she may not possess necessarily. 

About commitment, being supportive isn't only about matching someone’s achievements, it's more about emotional availability, understanding, respect, love, and being there in good times and bad. Nobody is perfect, we all are humans with flaws. But we can always strive to become better versions of ourselves.

You are not alone in feeling like this, many people experience similar sentiments when considering commitment. It's important to open up honest and respectful communication about your insecurities with each other. This doesn’t mean that one person is better than the other, or deserves more or less. It might help both of you understand each other's perspectives, expectations, and bond better.

Also, if you find yourself struggling with these thoughts frequently, consider seeking professional mental health support such as a psychologist or psychiatrist who can provide guidance tailored specifically to your situation. Finally, if your feelings of depression escalate or return, again reach out to a healthcare professional who can help you manage them effectively.

input: Hello doctor,I suspect I may have tapeworms. How can I be sure and what can I do to get rid of them?
output:
Hello, tapeworm infection can sometimes be hard to diagnose as the symptoms may vary and are often mild. However, some symptoms may include abdominal pain, diarrhea, fatigue, loss of appetite or weight loss. In more severe cases, it might cause changes in behavior or seizures. 

To confirm if you have a tapeworm, your doctor can order tests like a blood test or stool specimen analysis. The organism could show up under microscopic examination of your stool.

If testing confirms a tapeworm infection, anti-parasitic medication is usually the next course of treatment. These medicines are designed to paralyze the tapeworm, causing it to release its hold on your intestines. It will then be expelled from your body with a bowel movement. 

However, keep in mind that while these drugs eliminate adult tapeworms, they aren't always effective against tapeworm eggs or larvae. That's why prevention - ensuring proper food and water safety practices - is an important part of addressing tapeworm infections.

This advice is purely informational and does not replace a visit to your healthcare provider. Please consult with them to address your concerns fully.

input: Hi doctor,My periods started 14 days before and I had sex eight days back. Should I take pills after unsafe sex? If yes, what is the procedure to take I-pill?
output:
Emergency contraception (like the I-pill) is most effective when taken as soon as possible after unprotected sex but still has some effect for up to three days afterwards. Unfortunately, eight days have passed since your risky sexual encounter which exceeds the recommended time frame for using most emergency contraceptives.

However, you should consult with a healthcare professional who can guide you appropriately based on your specific circumstances and needs. For instance, there are other forms of emergency contraception such as the Copper IUD that can be inserted up to five days after unprotected sex.

If you take an I-pill or another form of "morning after" pill in the future, you must follow the manufacturer's instructions carefully. Generally, these types of pills should be taken as one single dose as soon as possible after unprotected sex.

In addition, remember that emergency contraception is not meant to replace regular contraceptive methods and does not protect against sexually transmitted infections. Regularly using another method of contraception (like birth control pills, IUDs, condoms, etc.) is the best way to prevent unwanted pregnancies. It's also important to get tested for STIs if you've had unsafe sex.

input: Hello doctor, I am suffering from a cold sore type infection in my mouth especially at lips. Same was occurred last year and again it repeated this year. And as on today it is the third time it is coming and curing within a period of 10 to 20 days. I want to add photographs but do not know how. Further, currently it is on my lips and additional sores are there inside the upper part of my mouth. There is no pain. Please advise so that this can be permanently cured.I am currently taking Acivir 800.
output:
Based on your description, it sounds like you're experiencing recurrent episodes of herpes simplex virus-1 (HSV1) infection. This is the most common cause of cold sores around and inside the mouth. Unfortunately, this is a viral infection, meaning there's not currently a way to completely eliminate the virus from your body. However, there are treatments available to control outbreaks.

You're already using Acivir 800 (Acyclovir), which is an antiviral medication used in treating infections caused by HSV. It can help speeding up healing of sores and decrease symptoms when used as directed by the physician during an outbreak. 

To prevent frequent recurrences, maintain good oral hygiene practices such as regularly brushing and flossing your teeth. Avoid stress as much as possible because it can also trigger cold sores. Limit sun exposure to your lips, eating a balanced diet, getting enough sleep, and keeping yourself well hydrated may help reduce outbreaks.

My advice would be to continue the use of the prescribed medicine but also consult your doctor about suppressive therapy. This means taking antiviral medication daily to prevent outbreaks. This strategy might be helpful if you have frequent cold sore episodes. 

Photographs obviously make diagnosis more clear. To provide pictures, typically you would upload them through the patient portal of the clinic or hospital you attend.

Lastly, remember that HSV1 can be contagious even without visible symptoms, so avoid sharing objects that come into contact with your mouth during active infection periods, especially

input: Hello doctor,I had an X-ray last Thursday and I got the result today. It says I have fibrosis in my right upper lobe. I had a history of pulmonary tuberculosis two years back and I took a six months medication and I am done with it. I just want to ask if fibrosis can be cured if I take medication and do exercise daily and eat healthy foods?
output:
Fibrosis refers to scar tissue that develops in the lung as a result of damage, such as from an infection like tuberculosis (TB). Once fibrosis has formed, it's generally permanent. It does not typically reverse even with medications or lifestyle changes such as diet and exercise. However, progression of fibrosis can often be halted or at least slowed down, particularly when the underlying cause, in this case tuberculosis, has been treated and is under control.

Maintenance of good health through balanced nutrition, regular exercise, avoiding smoke and other respiratory irritants, staying up-to-date with vaccinations, and managing chronic conditions can all help your overall lung health and limit any additional lung damage.

In some severe cases, oxygen therapy or a lung transplant might be options, but these are usually last-resort treatments for serious lung diseases.

You should discuss with your doctor about the severity of your condition and what specific actions you should take. Always consult a healthcare provider before starting any new treatment or medication regimen.

input: Hi doctor,I am 9 months pregnant, and I have some doubts with my recent free T3, T4, and TSH levels. My Triiodothyronine total (T3) is 208.57. What is it? Is it something to worry or is it normal? My TSH is under control, and it is 2.63 now.
output:
Triiodothyronine (T3) and thyroxine (T4) are thyroid hormones, which play key roles in our bodies' metabolism. The pituitary gland, located at the base of the brain, controls their production by releasing Thyroid Stimulating Hormone (TSH).

The normal range for Total T3 levels can vary depending on the laboratory but generally it will fall within a range of 80-200 ng/dL. With your value of 208.57 ng/dL, your level is slightly elevated.

However, interpreting these values needs to be done along with symptoms, clinical conditions (like pregnancy), and other thyroid tests like Free T4, Free T3, and TSH. Each lab has a different reference range based on the population they serve and the techniques they use and it is best to interpret the results with reference to those ranges.

In pregnancy, hormonal changes can cause slight fluctuation in the thyroid hormone levels, but if you do not have any symptoms suggestive of hyperthyroidism (e.g., palpitations, weight loss, anxiety, tremors), this slight variation might not be clinical meaningful.

Your TSH levels are normal and healthy. A TSH result between 0.2 and 2.5 mIU/L is generally considered optimal for pregnant women during all trimesters.
 
Regardless, you should contact your doctor or healthcare provider who ordered these tests for more specific information and the course of action. They will be able to interpret

input: Hello doctor,I have a bump on the right backside of the roof of my mouth. It is right next to the tooth that is farther back. It has pain when I brush my tongue over it. Also giving me a slight headache and earache. I recently went to the dentist for a cleaning, and they said my wisdom teeth were not even showing so what could this be?
output:
Based on the symptoms you've described, this could be related to several issues such as an oral ulcer, torus palatinus (a hard bony growth in the roof of your mouth), or pericoronitis (which is an infection occurring when wisdom teeth don't have enough room to surface — even if they aren't showing yet). The headache and earache may indicate that there may be some sort of infection or inflammation. It is also possible this bump is a reaction to any potential trauma or irritation that occurred during your dental cleaning.

However - and very importantly - these are only possibilities. You should definitely consult with a healthcare provider to rule out other more serious causes like oral cancer. A healthcare professional who can physically examine you will be more suited to diagnosing your condition accurately.

input: Hello doctor,My friend started vomiting last night and I noticed that his eyelids were red and bruised. Is there something else besides the vomiting that could have caused the bruised eyelids?
output:
Hello! It's indeed unusual for vomiting to cause bruised eyelids. While forceful vomiting may lead to petechial hemorrhages in some cases, bruising under the eyes is not often seen in this situation. 

His bruised eyelids might be related to trauma (e.g., hitting or rubbing his eye), a bleeding disorder, or as a side effect of certain medications like blood thinners. Since the symptom appears serious and abnormal, it would be best if your friend consults with a healthcare provider as soon as possible to identify what's truly going on. Make sure he mentions any related symptoms, medical history, and list of medications taken. This will help them find the right diagnosis and treatment approach.

Remember that this advice is given based on limited information and does not replace a thorough consultation and examination from a health care professional.

input: Hello doctor,I had a chest x-ray and chest ct scan done. And they both came back normal. If I had emphysema would it have shown up on one of those two tests?
output: Yes, both a chest X-ray and chest CT scan are commonly used to help diagnose emphysema. They allow doctors to see changes in the lungs such as damage to the air sacs (alveoli), which often occurs if you have emphysema. If neither of these tests showed any abnormalities, it's less likely that you have emphysema. However, these results do not completely rule out lung diseases or conditions, including early stage emphysema, so if you're still experiencing symptoms, further testing may be necessary. You should continue discussing your symptoms with your healthcare provider.

input: Hi doctor,My daughter is 9 years old. She gets nose bleeding once in few months and also gum bleeding. She complains about occasional back pain, stomach burning, and hip pain too. My family physician has written down a series of tests and asked me to get opinions from a hematologist, gastroenterologist, and an orthopedic doctor respectively.
output:
Based on the symptoms you've described like nose and gum bleeding, occasional back pain, stomach burning, and hip pain in your 9-year-old daughter, it seems like several different systems in her body might be affected. That could explain why your family physician has suggested opinions from a hematologist, gastroenterologist, and an orthopedic doctor.

1) Hematologist: The symptom of frequent Nosebleeds (Epistaxis) and gum bleeding could suggest a blood clotting disorder (such as hemophilia or von Willebrand disease), platelet disorders or even some vitamin deficiencies (like C, K). A hematologist specializes in such conditions and would provide necessary care for diagnosis and treatment.

2) Gastroenterologist: Stomach burning might indicate gastritis which is inflammation of the stomach lining, acid reflux disease, or possibly peptic ulcer disease. These conditions are commonly evaluated by a Gastroenterologist, who can perform further tests like an endoscopy to establish a diagnosis and plan treatment.

3) Orthopedic Doctor: Complaints of back pain and hip pain in children needs assessment from an orthopedic doctor who can rule out any abnormalities of the bone structure, posture issues, growth related changes or inflammatory conditions by doing necessary examinations, imaging techniques and provide appropriate treatment plans.

Please proceed as advised by your primary doctor and consult these specialists. Remember that these are possibilities based on symptoms. Only a proper evaluation with necessary tests can confirm the actual issue affecting your daughter

input: Hello doctor,I am facing erectile dysfunction for the last three to four years and also early ejaculation. Presently, I am using medicines for BP - Tenormin 50 mg and also for depression - Aplog 2 mg, Pethidine 50 mg and Mirtaz 15 mg for the past 10 years. My problem of ED and EE is from past five years. For this, I have used Suhagra tablet 50 to 100 mg and some sprays and Tantex capsules but there is no use. I am facing an embarrassing situation. Kindly give me an instant solution to this problem.
output:
I'm sorry to hear you're going through this but unfortunately, as an AI, I can only provide some general advice based on your message. However, I strongly recommend you talking about these issues with your healthcare provider or a urologist in person. 

Impotence (Erectile Dysfunction) and early ejaculation could possibly be side effects of the medications you are using, mainly those for hypertension and depression, but also they can be linked to stress, anxiety, hormonal issues among others.

As for instant solutions, it may depend on the roots of your conditions. Techniques like stop-start or squeeze techniques can work on premature ejaculation but are unlikely to have an overnight effect; likewise, medication changes might take some time to influence erectile functioning. Many patients find success with PDE5 inhibitors like Sildenafil or Tadalafil for ED, but these would need to be used under the guidance of your doctor, considering other health conditions and medications. Psychological treatments such as self-awareness, mindfulness exercises, sex therapy or counseling might help you if there is any psychological component to your symptoms.

Remember, seek out professional medical advice from your healthcare provider. This will allow them to evaluate your specific case, make adjustments to your medications and discuss options that could potentially improve your situation.

input: Hi doctor,I am a 19-year-old female. I lost my virginity about 10 months ago with my boyfriend. Now after 10 months has passed I found out that I have two warts inside my vagina. It is white color although, the one on the top started to have a slight pink color. But the second one on the bottom which is much smaller still has completely white color and around the vagina blades, I have a little while dots. Also, there are very tiny warts line along the blades. So, when I went to see the GP near my house he had a look and said that there is nothing to worry it is still small. But in my opinion, I think it is quite big. So the doctor gave me a prescription for Condyline paint which he told me to use for three days only per week and I have to keep using it for three weeks and if it does not get better he told me to see him again. Now I have a few questions. Is this mean I have an HPV virus inside my body? How can I make the virus go away permanently? Will Gardasil injection make it go away? If it does not go away permanently, how can I make sure that I have no HPV viruses and so these warts will not come back again? Is this mean that I have this HPV from my boyfriend? How to use Condyline paint correctly? I wash my vagina blades and use the cotton pads to dry it, then I use start to use the Condyline paint. I only dip the swab once into the reagent and then I open my vagina blades so that I am able to paint the two warts inside my vagina as much as I can. Then I paint it all over the very tiny warts in the vagina blades area. Am I doing it correctly?Now I have been using the Condyline for two days, but the very tiny warts that are around the vagina blades started to grow more. Is this mean anything? Can condoms prevent these HPV viruses? If I break up with my boyfriend, will this help my symptoms and health to become better? I am very scared of whether this can leads to cancer? I do not want this to ever happen to me again, how can I prevent this to happen again?If my warts are gone can I have sex with my boyfriend? Will these symptoms comeback again? If I decided to buy the Gardasil injection and injected it now, then the next after two months, then next after six months, but during this time can I have sex with my boy friend? Will the vaccine still work?
output:
It does sound like you are likely infected with Human Papillomavirus (HPV), which can create warts in the genital area. Here are some important things to know:

1. HPV is a viral infection: There currently is no cure for the actual virus itself, but there are treatments available for the symptoms (like the genital warts).

2. Condyline Paint could help reduce/eliminate the warts, but you should follow your doctor’s instructions on usage carefully. If you were prescribed to use it only three times a week for three weeks, then you need to stick to that regimen.

3. It's good if you use cotton pads to dry the area before applying Condyline paint as it can cause significant pain and irritation if applied on wet or damp skin. However, you may want to double-check with your healthcare provider regarding painting all over the very tiny warts area method, and also about increasing wart sizes after starting the treatment.

4. The Gardasil vaccine will not treat an existing HPV infection or its symptoms. Its purpose is preventive — it stops certain strains of HPV from infecting your body in the future. 

5. Regarding HPV transmission, yes, these types of viruses are usually transmitted through sexual contact. That doesn't necessarily mean your boyfriend gave it to you, but it's possible. Similarly, breaking up with your boyfriend won't cure you of HPV – you'll still want to seek appropriate medical treatment and prevention measures to manage your health.

input: Hello doctor,I am a 25-year-old male and I have never been able to fully retract my penis. I have severe phimosis. I know phimosis can be treated, but my biggest concern is that I now have blue-looking veins from the shaft of my penis to the actual penis head that is supposed to be exposed. Is it serious? I have an appointment with a urologist in two weeks but the suspense is really killing me. Is it common? or can it be treated? Will I be able to successfully retract the penis head? I also feel pain sensation when I touch the hole at the tip of the penis. Please help. Of note, I smoke marijuana. I have attached photos for your reference.
output:
I'm sorry, but as an AI, I can't examine images of your condition. However, I still want to help out with some general advice.

Severe phimosis often causes difficulty in retracting the penile foreskin and may require treatment. Treatments could include steroid creams, preputioplasty (a surgical procedure that widens the foreskin), or circumcision, a more definitive measure for severe cases that don't respond to conservative treatments. 

Regarding the bluish veins you mentioned, it's quite normal to have visible veins on the penis, they might appear blue or purple in color depending on skin tone and blood oxygen levels. Sometimes these veins become more prominent under certain conditions such as heightened sexual arousal or if there is increased pressure forcing the veins to enlarge. Certain vascular conditions can cause this like varicocele or thrombophlebitis; however, these are usually less common. 

The pain sensation on touching the penis tip could be related to the phimosis or could indicate an infection, inflammation, or trauma at that site which needs medical attention.  

Marijuana use doesn't directly contribute towards phimosis but remember, smoking can lead to systemic circulatory issues that over time can affect overall health including genital health.

Always consult a urologist as planned! Despite my suggestions, only face-to-face physical examination could provide correct diagnosis and recommendations.

input: Hi doctor,I was diagnosed with TID 14 years back. I will run out of Lantus before the next shipment arrives, but I have plenty of Novolog on hand. My daily dose is 32.5 units Lantus at 10 AM and 12.5 units at 8 PM, with a sliding scale for Novolog (typically 0 to 6 units). What dosage or schedule would you recommend for temporarily relying on Novolog only?
output:
Given the limitations of this text-based communication, it's important to stress that any insulin change should be made under close supervision of a healthcare provider. Generally speaking, fast-acting insulin like Novolog is not an ideal substitute for a long acting one like Lantus as they have different time action profiles.

However, theoretically, in emergencies when no other options are available, you would need to take smaller doses of Novolog spread throughout the day to try and mimic Lantus' longer coverage. This should be done via multiple daily injections to attempt to provide background insulin -- but keep in mind that this is not ideal. 

It's essential to closely monitor your blood sugar during this period, because adjusting to the short-action insulin can increase the risk of hypoglycemia (low blood glucose level). The dosing amount may also vary significantly from what you're used to with Lantus.

Ultimately, reach out to your healthcare provider as soon as possible for guidance tailored to your specific needs. You could also try to get help obtaining some Lantus temporarily from your local pharmacy or diabetes clinic if available.

input: Hello doctor,I am a 57-year-old female. Here is my question constant heart palpitations and fluttering, continuous feeling of adrenaline rushing along with palpitations very bad at night but also during the day when sitting in doing nothing palpitations often make you feel nauseous on a 1 to 10 scale they are about an eight. All labs are normal ECG, echo, and Holter monitor are all normal.Doctor cannot figure it out and prescribed Propranolol 10 mg, told me to try these once a day. Yesterday after doctor visits heart palpitations for four hours got fed up and took one tablet one hour later, all palpitations and adrenaline rush was gone. Slept for the first time without being woke up having to cough to stop the palpitations. Had angio done approximately two years ago due to suspected heart attack or arrhythmia at home with all classic signs crushing chest pain jaw neck left arm down to the floor nauseated?Even with that lab test came back good the next day. Had carotid artery surgery two years ago to remove a piece of plaque in right carotid artery none found anywhere else no stent needed. Again all labs are good cholesterol not high on statins and warfarin. I must be perplexing to all doctors because they cannot figure it out. Was put on warfarin approximately 15 years ago due to DVTs as a result of a surgery, always therapeutic. So I had a heart attack or arrhythmia a few years back the angio came out the great doctor said everything looked fine now I have these crazy heart palpitations that would not stop. They go away as soon as I take the beta-blocker. I am told that beta-blockers even though anti-arrhythmic can also be pro arithmetic as well should I take this every day or should I only take this when I start to feel palpitations.
output:
Based on your description, it sounds like you suffer from frequent heart palpitations that are causing significant discomfort (rated 8/10). It's reassuring that your ECG, echo and Holter monitor tests have come back normal - suggesting no structural or rhythm abnormalities in your heart. Nevertheless, the symptoms you describe can indeed be perplexing and distressing.

Propranolol is a beta-blocker medication often used to treat conditions such as high blood pressure, angina, certain types of arrhythmia, and it is also used to reduce anxiety-driven symptoms. It appears Propranolol has been effective at calming your symptoms based on your description.

To address your question regarding whether you should take this daily or only when experiencing symptoms, I would recommend discussing this further with your cardiologist. They are familiar with your full medical history and can provide the most appropriate recommendation tailored for you. 

While it is true that in rare cases, beta blockers can induce an arrhythmia, these incidents are usually in people who already have specific existing heart conditions. Since your cardiac tests were reported normal, it would seem your risk is likely low, but again, discuss these concerns with your doctor.

Also, symptoms not responding to normal treatment protocols might benefit from being reviewed by a specialist center with expert Doctors if possible. If palpitations continue despite negative test results, further tests including psychiatric evaluation may be warranted to rule out anxiety-related disorders that may present similarly. As always, please communicate any new symptoms or changes

input: Hi doctor,I am a 49-year-old woman and last month I was hospitalized with a necrotizing soft tissue infection on my thigh. I had two debridement surgeries and was discharged after 5 days. I was treated with about 4 IV antibiotics. I do not remember them all, I recall seeing Vancomycin and Penicillin. I was told that the infection was not MRSA, but a "slower moving bacteria" they did not tell me what it was. I was swabbed for MRSA in my nose and butt before both surgeries and was told I did not have it. For the last day of my stay, I had a roommate who had a bad MRSA infection on her butt and sometimes had diarrhea incontinence during dressing changes. I had no physical contact with her, but we had the same nurse. I was discharged with a five day course of Augmentin.The wound has been healing very well and has not gotten infected, but three weeks after discharge I got an abscess under my arm. I went to an urgent care and was prescribed Clindamycin and told to return in three days for drainage. The abscess did not improve or get worse over the three days. I got it drained and was prescribed Augmentin and told to also continue the clindamycin. That was a week ago and the wound is healing well. They called today and said cultures show it was MRSA and they prescribed Bactrim and told me to stop the other antibiotics.I am feeling devastated by this and wanting to understand why it happened. Could I have gotten it in the hospital? I am concerned that it will not go away. Are those swabs at the hospital conclusive and mean for sure I did not have MRSA a month ago? I have never had any medical problems before and these experiences have been very frightening. Is there anything else I can do to prevent recurrence? I have read about everything from bleach baths and hibiclens to antibiotics in the nose.
output:
I understand your concerns, and it's certainly a distressing situation. Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) is a bacterium that causes infections in different parts of the body and is tougher to treat than most strains of staphylococcus aureus because it's resistant to many commonly used antibiotics.

It's possible you acquired MRSA from the hospital, as hospitals are common places where these bacteria can be found; this is known as hospital-acquired or nosocomial infection. However, we cannot definitely discern how or where you got the bacteria. Health care providers always take extra measures to prevent MRSA spread including strict hand hygiene protocols.

In terms of your swabs at the hospital, they were likely accurate at that time, but doesn't necessarily mean you couldn't have been infected with MRSA afterwards.

The good news is the Bactrim you've been prescribed is proven effective for treating MRSA. To help prevent future recurrences:

1. Practice good hygiene: Wash your hands often with soap and water or use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer.
2. Keep wounds covered: Bandages can help protect others from MRSA, and help you avoid spreading it to different parts of your own body.
3. Don't share personal items: Items like towels, razors, clothing, and athletic equipment can be a source of MRSA transmission.
4. Regularly clean frequently touched surfaces.
5. Follow the prescription: Complete your full course of antibiotics even

input: Hello doctor,I am a sufferer of hemiplegic migraine. However, I had unusual collapses three months back. The first one was 40 minutes; I could not recall the whole of that period. I came back with an injured knee and felt dazed. I was fine after around two hours. The next day, I felt pressure in my head and as though I was about to die. I then could not recall getting home or the rest of the night. I was fine in the morning. Two days later, I felt horrendous pain in my head, felt like I was swimming, then tried to go home and again could not recall from deciding to go home to around two hours later and I was foggy for the rest of the night. I have had constant pain in the left side of my head above the temple for four years. It does not go. However, In the past two weeks, I have felt like it is throbbing and at times about to burst out. I was meant to see my neurologist three months back, but his receptionist did not follow the recommendation, and now I am unsure whether to have the tests done. I feel like we are playing with my life. Usually, I am pretty relaxed about the possibilities and know it is a migraine. But this feels different. This feels like intense throbbing above my ear from the temple along towards the back of my head, with a pain in my ear to just behind my jaw under my ear. My instinct says that an aneurysm needs ruling out. I do not know if I am just upset because it feels so different and this pressure is intense. It is a weird feeling. I currently take Sumatriptan as needed.Please, can you advise what to do? As it stands the next neuro appointment is after four months, added complication is that I have been breathless and unable to climb stairs without stopping and panting for past four months. I am having heart tests on the weekend. But, what do I do about my brain?
output:
I'm sorry to hear you're going through this tough time. The symptoms you've described, particularly the unfamiliar and intense pressure in your head along with periods of lost memory are quite concerning. While it could be an extension or severe form of hemiplegic migraine, conditions such as transient ischemic attacks (mini-strokes), seizures, or indeed aneurysms should also be ruled out. Given the intensity and persistent nature of your symptoms, it is best not to wait for four months until the next scheduled appointment. 

Here's what I recommend:

- You should seek immediate medical attention at an urgent care or local ER, given the severity, recurrence, and change in your symptoms.
- Explain all of these symptoms to the attending physician including any changes in the characteristics of the pain and any other accompanying symptoms.
- Try to ensure that a CT scan or MRI of your brain gets done urgently as these can pick up signs of an aneurysm or stroke.

As for the breathlessness and inability to climb stairs without stopping, this could potentially be related to a cardiac condition, pulmonary issue or even an aftereffect of severe migraines which can occasionally cause nonspecific systemic symptoms. However, these need to be properly evaluated with relevant tests. Don't hesitate to increase the urgency considering the wide range of significant symptoms you're experiencing. It is absolutely your right to do so if you feel something is not right with your health.

input: Hello doctor,I have been tested for HIV 1 and 2 many times. My tests are 10 weeks card test negative. 12 weeks Elisa serum test negative. 14 weeks Elisa serum and p24 test negative. 16 weeks Elisa serum test negative. 23 weeks Elisa serum and p24 test negative. Is HIV is still my risk? But from few days I am having lots of pimple on my back and shoulders and they sometimes itch, are they because of HIV or something else?
output:
From the HIV test results you provided, these tests are quite reliable at detecting HIV beyond 3 months post-exposure. Therefore, if your potential exposure to HIV was more than 23 weeks ago and all of these tests came back negative, it is likely you do not have HIV. 

However, symptoms like pimples on your back and shoulders could be due to numerous causes other than HIV, such as bacterial or fungal skin infections, allergy, stress, poor diet, or hormonal imbalances. If there has been recent risky behaviour since your last test (unprotected sex or sharing needles for example), then re-testing would be wise, but if there has not been a new exposure event, HIV from an exposure before your testing is very unlikely based on the information provided.

Please consult with a dermatologist or your primary care physician to properly diagnose the cause of these breakouts.

input: Hi doctor,I am 32 years old married male. Since two years I am suffering from premature ejaculation. I tried to control it, but did not get better result. My wife is very much unsatisfied. How to cure this issue?
output:
Premature ejaculation (PE) is a complex medical issue that can be caused by various factors, both physical and psychological. Therefore, managing it can often involve several steps:

1. Behavioral techniques: Some techniques like the 'start-stop' method or the ‘squeeze’ method may help you to delay ejaculation.

2. Topical anesthetics: Anesthetic creams and sprays that contain a numbing agent, such as lidocaine, numb the penis to delay ejaculation.

3. Counseling: Speak with a mental health professional about your experiences. Factors such as stress, depression, and anxiety can lead to premature ejaculation.

4. Medicinal therapy: Certain medications such as antidepressants (like selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors - SSRIs) might help delay ejaculation.

5. Pelvic Floor Exercises: Strengthening pelvic muscles using certain exercises could help you gain better control over your ejaculatory reflexes.

It's important that you see a healthcare provider in person for an examination and consultation. They could carry out necessary tests and then give advice suited to your personal needs for managing premature ejaculation.

In severe cases, take advantage of combined treatment plans. This could mean taking medication whilst attending sexual counseling. Additionally, maintaining a healthy lifestyle, such as exercising regularly, getting enough sleep, and having a balanced diet, can have positive effects on sexual health.

Remember that there's wide variability in what is considered normal ejaculatory latency, and satisfaction levels differ from couple to couple. Communication with your partner about these issues

input: Hello doctor,I slept with color contacts in my eyes and now I woke and took them out and there is a white cloud blocking my vision.
output: It sounds like you may have damaged your cornea by leaving in your contact lenses overnight. This damage can cause swelling or inflammation, which can lead to a white cloud appearing in your field of vision. It is crucial that you go and see an eye doctor immediately. Also, avoid wearing any type of contact lens until the issue is resolved and instructed by your healthcare provider, because further irritation could potentially worsen your condition. Try over-the-counter pain relief if necessary but remember that this does not replace the need for medical attention.

input: Hello doctor,I am 32 years old and unmarried. I am a patient of PCOD. I also have a family history of breast cancer. My father\s sister had breast cancer recently. I am in a very big financial crisis. So, one of my friends suggested me to donate eggs. Will it be risky if I donate my eggs only once? As I am a patient of PCOD, will I be able to conceive in the future? Will I be given some hormonal treatment to conceive later? Please advise me whether I should proceed with the idea of egg donation. Is there any chance of developing breast or ovarian cancer if I donate eggs? Please guide me. I just want to know about its long term consequences as I am afraid of breast and ovarian cancer.
output:
If you have Polycystic Ovarian Disease (PCOD), it's important to know that this condition can indeed affect your fertility. Women with PCOD often have an imbalance in their reproductive hormones, which can prevent the ovaries from releasing eggs regularly. However, many women with PCOD are still able to conceive with the help of certain treatments.

Regarding egg donation, there is a need for hormone stimulation to increase the number of mature eggs in one cycle. These hormones can possibly stimulate cysts already existing because of PCOD, and leads to Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS) which could be a potential complication.

As far as links between egg donation and breast or ovarian cancer, most research done so far does not suggest any increased risk. Nevertheless, we must note that long-term studies on egg donors are limited and it is always best to consult with a healthcare professional regarding these concerns.

However, since you mentioned a family history of breast cancer, you should discuss this with a genetic counselor or cancer specialist too. Some families carry gene mutations that increase risk for both breast and ovarian cancers.

Also consider long consultation with your gynaecologist about the process of egg donation, its benefits, risks and how it may impact your PCOD as well as future implications on overall reproduction. Don't make the decision without having all the information and thinking carefully about the psychological aspects as well.
  
Remember donating your eggs doesn't deplete your own supply significantly or cause infertility. Infertility

input: Hello doctor, I am having too many health issues for the last three weeks. I feel sleepy all the time even I sleep eight hours already. I am feeling weak, tiredness, dizziness, and headache on the right side of my head (pressure and dullness). My bowel habit changed to three to four times a day. I have attached my blood work. Do you think I have any abnormality in blood? Do you think I am having a stroke or heart attack? Do I have too much thickness in blood as high hemoglobin and hematocrit? Do I have any kind of blood cancer like polycythemia or polycythemia vera? In spite of having too much hemoglobin and platelets, why am I having weakness? Do I need to take blood thinner medicine?
output:
I'm an AI and can't look at lab results or perform physical exams. Still, I'll attempt to provide some general advice based on the symptoms you shared.

Feeling weak, tired, dizzy, and experiencing frequent headaches might indicate several conditions, ranging from less serious situations like dehydration or nutrient deficiencies to more severe ones like hormonal imbalances, infections, neurological disorders, etc. Increased bowel movements also hint towards a possible issue with digestion or absorption of nutrients.

Abnormally high levels of hemoglobin or hematocrit could suggest Polycythemia Vera (a kind of blood cancer), though it's just one potential cause amongst others. Not all such cases point to a stroke, heart attack, or even polycythemia - these are more complex conditions requiring comprehensive diagnostic inputs.

High hemoglobin, per se doesn't grant immunity to feeling weak or tiredness; instead, other factors like less efficient oxygenation, low iron levels or nutritional deficiencies may still produce such feelings. Whether or not you need a blood thinner depends on various factors which only your doctor, after detailed examination, could conclusively decide.

It's very important that you consult a healthcare professional promptly for appropriate tests, diagnosis and treatment considering your symptoms persisting for three weeks now. I urge you not to self-diagnose or self-medicate based on assumptions or limited information.
