input: Hello doctor,I had fever two days ago. Then one day ago started frequent urination and I could not hold it every time it happened. And there was pain during urination. Then started pain in the stomach. Today the urination is not that much but I have severe pain in both sides of my abdomen. I am not able to walk because of pain.
output:
Based on your symptoms, it seems like you are potentially suffering from a urinary tract infection (UTI) or kidney stones. Both conditions can cause fever, pain during urination, increased frequency of urination and abdominal pain. Kidney infections may also present similar symptoms and can occur as a progression from UTIs.

However, please note that the above is just an educated assumption. For more accurate diagnosis, I advise you to see a doctor immediately for evaluation. You might need to undergo some tests like urine analysis, ultrasonography, CT scan, etc., depending on what your attending physician will deem necessary.

If indeed you have UTI or kidney stones, these are highly treatable diseases but they can cause complications if not treated properly or promptly. So, immediate attention is very much recommended. If you're experiencing severe pain, consider going to the emergency room.

input: I am 30 Years old, Missed period for 8 days now. Since my 24 day of menstrual cycle was starting using duphaston drug once daily and finish the prescribed dose yesterday. And my menstrual cycle is between 26-28 days, this month on the days of my periods I got cramps but nothing come out. Could this be side effects of duphaston or?
output:
Duphaston (Dydrogesterone) is a progestin hormone commonly used to treat conditions like irregular menstrual cycles, premenstrual syndrome, endometriosis, and as part of hormone replacement therapy. It can also be prescribed to encourage the return of menstruation in women whose periods have stopped.

One side effect of taking Duphaston could potentially include a delay in your period, although this doesn't happen to everyone. However, there are other factors that could result in delayed menstruation too such as stress, sudden weight loss or gain, exercise, certain medical conditions, and of course, pregnancy.

It's important not to jump to conclusions. Taking a home pregnancy test might give you answers if you're sexually active and there's a chance you could be pregnant. If the test turns out negative, it would be a good idea to follow up with your doctor to discuss your symptoms and rule out any potential issues. Try not to worry - delayed menstruation is quite common and often resolves on its own.

input: Hi doctor,I am 50 years old female, went through menopause but otherwise I am healthy. There is a problem with my nails. Out of 10 nails, six nails have one-third of the nails separated from the nail beds, with a v shape, looking white underneath, rest of the nails are looking pinkish pale. The nails are painless unless I press them hard. All the nails have some ridges. I kept my nails short with no polish for over five weeks. My fingers felt dry with mild skin peeling after a travel. Currently, I have a mild skin eczema. I also had seborrheic dermatitis in my scalp a few years ago. But it is under control with special shampoo treatment. I had one fingernail with a similar problem but it was in a milder condition. I thought it was nail fungal. I used Mometasone furoate 0.1 % cream for my skin eczema. It cleared up when my nails grew. I have an allergy to pollen.
output:
From your description, it seems like you may be dealing with a condition called onycholysis. This is the painless separation of the nail from the nail bed, often resulting in a white or yellowish discoloration. Many factors can cause this condition including trauma (too much pressure on the nails), fungal infections, reactions to chemicals/products used on the nails or underlying conditions like psoriasis.

Given that you have a history of eczema and seborrheic dermatitis, skin issues could be contributing to your nail condition. Furthermore, ridges are normal for many people while others may find them as a sign of aging. 

Keeping the nails short and avoiding nail polish or artificial nails can be helpful. You should avoid picking at the nails or using them as tools to prevent further damage. Protecting your hands by wearing gloves when doing chores or anything that will expose your hands to water and harsh chemicals can also help. 

However, I would strongly suggest that you visit a dermatologist who can perform appropriate tests to rule out possible causes such as nail fungus or psoriasis and guide you through specific treatments based upon the root cause of your onycholysis.

input: Hello doctor,I have a 0.2 cm endobronchial nodule in the right lower lobe. I was a smoker for 20 years. I had a CT scan for cough and now new nodule. Is this cancer?
output: As a doctor, I can't diagnose over the internet and it's important for you to follow up with your healthcare provider. However, I can tell you generally about endobronchial nodules. This type of nodule could be due to a variety of factors. It could be related to an infection or inflammation; however, in someone with a smoking history, there is definitely an increased risk of lung cancer. The size (0.2 cm) is quite small which may be reassuring, but an appropriate evaluation usually involves comparing this scan to prior scans (if available) to look for growth or changes, as well as potentially additional types of imaging or procedures. In some cases, physicians might adopt a 'wait and see' approach with regular monitoring scanning to assess if the nodule grows over time - a characteristic of cancers. Remember, please consult your own physician as soon as possible to address your concerns directly.

input: Hello doctor,I am a 26 year old female. I am worried after reading about the effects of radiation from a CT scan. I had two separate scans within a month. Both the scans were for the chest, abdomen, and pelvis. The doctors were looking for a potential lymphoma, but nothing conclusive was found. I am worried about the future cancer risk. Please help.
output:
It's completely understandable to be concerned about your health. It's true that CT scans do emit radiation, and high levels of radiation exposure can increase the risk of cancer over time. However, it's important to remember that the relative risks are generally quite small compared to the benefits gained from accurate diagnosis and treatment. 

The amount of radiation you get from a single CT scan varies depending on the exact type of test you're having, but two chest, abdomen and pelvis scans would typically equate to an approximate additional lifetime risk of future cancer of less than 1 in 1000. 

However, this estimate is based on the assumption that probability of developing cancer because of radiation exposure is proportional to the dose received, there's ongoing debate if such lower levels of radiation exposure significantly increase your risk.

Also, one must consider the reality that if doctors were investigating potential lymphoma, the information obtained from those CT scans was crucial. In other words, the benefit of being able to diagnose and potentially treat any serious condition far outweighs the relatively small increased risk of cancer due to radiation. 

Remember that medicine is all about balancing potential risks with clear benefits, and diagnostic imaging like CT scans allow physicians to see what's happening inside body noninvasively, which makes them invaluable tools for modern medicine. 

Maintain follow-up with your regular doctor, live a health-conscious lifestyle, and make sure to always share any concerns you have regarding treatments or testing. You should discuss the necessity of repeated scans in

input: Hi doctor,I have serious constipation problems and Dulcolax is the only thing that works in my body. I take a lot of fruits, tea, and fiber supplements. What can I do?
output:
Maintaining regular bowel movements can sometimes be a challenge. It's good you've incorporated fiber-rich foods and hydration into your lifestyle. Apart from Dulcolax, here are some additional steps to consider:

1) Hydrate: Increase water intake, dehydration often exacerbates constipation.

2) Exercise regime: Regular physical activity can stimulate the muscles in your gut, helping them push contents along.

3) Review medications: Some medicines contribute to constipation. If you're on any other medication, please let me know so we can review their side effects.

4) Limit Foods That Cause Constipation: These may include cheese, red meat, fried foods etc.

5) Probiotics: Consider including probiotics like yogurt or probiotic supplements in your diet.

6) Scheduled Bowel Movements : Try setting aside a specific time each day for using the bathroom even if you don't feel the need to go then. This will help train your body for regular bowel movements.

7) Avoid overuse of laxatives: While Dulcolax can provide temporary relief, frequent use can cause your body to become dependent on them.

Make sure to consult with your healthcare provider before making any drastic changes. He/she might recommend more specialized treatments like biofeedback therapy or surgical interventions in severe cases.

input: Hi doctor,I am suffering from stomach pain. I am taking Sucramal syrup and A-Spas tablet. I have an increase in stomach pain when the acidity condition increases. I have done a scanning. But nothing was shown.
output:
The symptoms you describe could be consistent with gastritis or a peptic ulcer, both of which can cause stomach pain that worsens with increasing acidity. Keep in mind that these conditions may not always show up on general abdominal scans.

If the Sucramal syrup is not providing enough relief and you're experiencing elevated pain levels, it might be beneficial to re-evaluate your medication. There are other stronger acid-suppressing medications such as proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) available which might help reduce your symptoms.

Additionally, lifestyle modifications like avoiding spicy and fatty food, caffeine, alcohol, smoking, and taking meals in smaller quantity but at regular intervals could assist in reducing the symptoms.

Please note that while we can suggest possible causes and treatments for your symptoms based on the information provided, this does not replace an actual medical examination. I highly recommend you to consult with a gastroenterologist so they can evaluate your condition more accurately.

input: Hello doctor, My question is, when can I drink more than two glasses of wine a day or a whole bottle without it hindering the healing process after my dermapen session of micro needling? And also, because I was occasionally drinking a few bottles of beer after I had gotten it done, does that mean my healing time has to be longer than six weeks? By the way, I did my acne scar regions with 2.00 mm needles.
output:
Alcohol can dehydrate the body and skin which could potentially delay your healing process, as good hydration is important for skin repair. Normally, it's ideal to avoid alcohol consumption for about 48-72 hours after a dermapen session. However, everything depends on the individual reaction of the organism, so it may vary.

If you drank few bottles of beer after the procedure it doesn't necessarily mean that your healing time will be longer than six weeks. However, it might have compromised the results slightly or caused more inflammation or prolonged redness after the treatment.

Since you had acne scar regions treated with 2mm needles, this does involve deeper penetration into the dermis and the recovery period may be slightly longer than with shallow treatments. With significant treatments like this, I'd suggest waiting at least one week before consuming any significant amounts of alcohol. While complete healing should be achieved in six weeks, maintaining healthy habits such as adequate water intake and minimum alcohol consumption would be beneficial for overall skin health. 

Remember to always follow your skincare professional's advice when it comes to aftercare following procedures like micro needling.

input: Hello doctor,I am hepatitis B patient. My current status is as follows. HBeAg - negative (0.010), HBV E antibody or Ag - positive (0.031) and HBV DNA quantitative (PCR) less than 17.1 IU/mL. Please advise whether this can be cured to become negative as it is affecting my career.
output:
Hepatitis B is a viral infection that attacks the liver and can cause both acute and chronic disease. In your case, it appears to be chronic Hepatitis B as the virus has not completely cleared from your body.

Your test results indicate that you have an inactive form of the virus (HBeAg negative). This usually means that the virus is not currently replicating, and hence less likely to cause damage to the liver. Your HBV DNA levels are quite low which also indicates minimal viral replication.

There's no complete cure for chronic hepatitis B. The goal of treatment is to reduce the risk of complications, including cirrhosis and liver cancer. Antiviral medications can help slow down the damage on your liver and prolong life by slowing down or stopping the virus from reactivating. 

It's important that you continue to have regular monitoring so that any changes in your condition can be identified early and managed appropriately. Make sure to keep up with healthy habits such as avoiding alcohol, maintaining a balanced diet, exercising regularly, and preventing transmission to others.

In terms of your career, it’s tough but important to remember this diagnosis doesn’t define your value or abilities. Some countries might have restrictions related to Hepatitis B positive healthcare workers or other specific occupations. It's best to discuss these further with a legal expert or your employer while maintaining your privacy.

Always consult a hepato-gastroenterologist or a liver specialist for your queries regarding Hepatitis B management.

input: Hello doctor,I recently got my CBC done as a part of a routine check-up in which my Hgb, RBC, platelets, WBC counts was entirely within the range except for monocytes. My monocytes were 5.28x10^9/L. I feel healthy otherwise and except for PCOS have no other known medical condition. My GP said that monocytes were nothing to worry about as TLC is fine and I am fine. So can you tell me if it is nothing to worry?
output:
In a Complete Blood Count (CBC) test, the monocytes count is usually expressed as a percentage of total white blood cell count. Normal range for monocytes is typically around 2-8%. However, you've mentioned an absolute number (5.28x10^9/L), and without a reference range it's difficult to say whether this is elevated or not.

Monocytes are a type of white blood cell that fight certain infections and help other white blood cells remove dead or damaged tissues, destroy cancer cells, and regulate immune response. A high monocyte count, known as monocytosis, can be a sign of inflammation in the body due to various reasons including chronic infections or autoimmune diseases, among others.

However, a one-time slight increase in monocytes alone without symptoms does not necessarily indicate a serious problem, especially if your other blood counts are within normal range. This could sometimes be due to minor transient causes such as stress or following a recent illness.

Your GP seems to have used clinical judgment based on your overall health condition and test reports. But if you still have concerns, do raise them with your doctor once more. It would also be beneficial to monitor it over time to rule out any ongoing conditions, particularly if you start experiencing any new relevant symptoms. 

If you notice any changes in health or develop any new symptoms, make sure to reach out to your healthcare provider right away.

input: Hi, doctor I am 13 weeks pregnant last week I undergone for NT scan the report was normal and the same time I gave double marker blood test. Yesterday from the hospital they called me for blood test because the first report shows abnormal. I am so scared whether second time double marker test shows normal. They didn\t give the report of first test but simply told first test was abnormal so we sending for second time. I am confused. Please tell me whether second time test shows normal result. If it is abnormal is there is any early treatment to protect the baby from down syndrome.
output:
I understand your concerns and it's natural to feel anxious in this situation. However, without knowing the specific results of your first double marker test, it is impossible for anyone to predict what a second test might show.

The double marker test is a screening test carried out to detect certain genetic abnormalities in a fetus like Down Syndrome and Edward’s Syndrome. It basically determines the chances or risk of your baby having these conditions but isn't diagnostic. This means that even if the test comes back as 'abnormal', it doesn't necessarily mean your child will have one of these conditions, simply that they may be at higher risk. If the second test also shows an abnormal result, your doctor might recommend you to go for invasive tests such as Amniocentesis or Chorionic Villus Sampling (CVS) which are more definitive.

Early treatment for Down syndrome isn't black and white. Management begins after birth and includes support services, therapies, and early intervention programs that can help the baby and family adjust, learn, and grow. The focus is typically on ensuring that the child reaches his or her physical, mental, and social potential. There's currently no cure for this condition, however, early detection and intervention can significantly improve quality of life. 

Stay hopeful and wait for the second set of results. The need for a retest could be due to multiple reasons including issues related to sample collection. So try not to worry too much, there's still possibility that your second test returns normal or

input: Hi doctor,I had a frenuloplasty of the penis ten days back. It all seemed fine at first, and I had very little pain. I have to say the actual incision and stitches were a lot larger than what I was previously led to believe. I have been washing gently with salt water and rinsing twice daily. I took a good look a few days ago, and it seems that the stitches have come apart. To be honest, and I am not a urologist, but it does not look like a good job, though I may be wrong. I went to see the doctor yesterday, and she took a look and said that it all looks fine, the stitches may have come apart slightly. She told me to leave it for two weeks, and if I am still concerned, they will refer me back to the specialist. I was hoping to get a second opinion, this being my penis, I am obviously concerned that it is not going to heal properly and I will end up worse than before the operation. I am primarily looking for reassurance.
output:
While I can't physically examine your wound, it's good to know you’ve been in regular contact with health professionals who can. Frenuloplasty is a relatively minor procedure and complications are rare, but they can occur. Sutures coming apart or not holding the incision closed as expected is possible depending upon various factors like type of suture material used, tension on the wounds etc.

Your doctor's advice to observe for two more weeks seems reasonable -- healing from this kind of procedure typically takes a few weeks and everyone heals at different rates. As long as there aren't any signs of infection (like increased redness, swelling, pus discharge, fever) or you're not having any substantial increase in pain, waiting and monitoring appears prudent.

Meanwhile, continue to keep the area clean, avoid unnecessary manipulation, maintain a healthy diet to facilitate wound healing and minimize activities that could potentially disrupt the wound (like intense physical activity). If you notice new, concerning symptoms, reach out to your healthcare provider immediately.

In case if you have concerns about the cosmetic appearance after healing due to stitches coming apart, a urologist should be able to help assess this as well. The ultimate decision will depend both on how much functional or cosmetic issue this creates for you. 

Remember, digital advice cannot replace an in-person examination. It will always be best to follow up directly with your specialist who has examined you and knows your medical history.

input: I\m having ache in lower jaw.Last time i visited dentist...i had a root canal same sideAfter a month i started experiencing pain in that jaw sometimes...Doctor said root canal is fine and that i have impacted wisdom tooth after a quick x ray.I am having pain now again in that jaw after 3 months.What should i do?Due to covid 19 I\m not sure i should visit a dentist
output:
You're already aware that you have an impacted wisdom tooth, which is a common cause of jaw pain. If your tooth is impacted, it's possible that the surrounding gum may be inflamed and infected. This can lead to pain just like what you are experiencing right now.

However, since physical visits pose a risk due to COVID 19, there are a few things you can do at home for temporary relief:

1. Rinse your mouth with warm salt water.
2. Use over-the-counter pain relievers, such as ibuprofen or paracetamol (only if not allergic).
3. Apply a cold pack on the area where you're feeling the discomfort.


Despite these measures, I strongly recommend you arrange a telehealth appointment with your dentist or healthcare provider. They might help guide you regarding further management based on your symptoms. It's important not to ignore this, especially if the pain recurs or worsens. In some cases, surgical removal of the wisdom tooth might become necessary.

input: Hello doctor,I have a hiatal hernia, I am wondering if protein shake hurt my hernia. The pain is usually mild and comes and goes. Recently, I have been not feeling too well, and my hiatal hernia pain become moderate and doest really go away. I am currently on Rabeprazole and Motilium.
output:
Protein shakes in themselves do not specifically cause harm to a hiatal hernia, unless they are causing symptoms like indigestion or acid reflux which partly can be due to high fat content. You should avoid heavy and fatty protein shakes if you notice such issues.

Your recent discomfort may not necessarily be related to the protein shake but could just mean your hiatal hernia condition is getting worse. Stress, certain foods, alcohol, smoking, obesity, and even some medicines for other conditions can exacerbate the symptoms of hiatal hernia.

The medications you're on (Rabeprazole - a proton pump inhibitor that reduces stomach acid production; Motilium - for relief from nausea, vomiting, bloating) are appropriate to manage common symptoms linked to hiatal hernia.

However, if there's an increase in the intensity of pain and it doesn't go away, I'd recommend seeking immediate medical attention. It’s important to rule out complications like strangulation where the blood supply to herniated stomach gets cut off.
  
Remember to take small meals more frequently, avoid lying down or bending over soon after eating, maintain a healthy weight, avoid smoking and limit alcohol. These steps might help alleviate the symptoms. Also, consider speaking with a dietitian who understands gastrointestinal disorders to give accurate advice about your diet including protein shakes.

input: Hi doctor,I have bleeding after sex. I have pain while having sex. I have vaginal discharge and irritation while peeing and itching. Is this an infection or something else? I took an Unwanted 72 before three days.
output:
It sounds like you may be dealing with an issue such as a vaginal infection or sexually transmitted disease (STD), possibly even something like cervical inflammation or polyps. These can cause pain during intercourse, bleeding after sex, and the associated discharge, irritation, and itching. However, this is just speculation based on the symptoms you provided. It's also important to note that Unwanted 72, an emergency contraceptive pill, shouldn't have these side effects.

I strongly suggest you make an immediate appointment with your gynecologist or other healthcare provider for a full examination and possible STD testing. Only a healthcare professional can diagnose your specific issue properly. Please do not engage in sexual activity until you have seen a doctor and received treatment if necessary. Don't panic and remember that many infections are treatable.

Additionally, while Unwanted 72 is effective at preventing pregnancy, it does not protect against STDs. If you're sexually active, consider using condoms for protection against both pregnancy and STDs.

input: Hi doctor,I have a lot of stress going on right now and most of my anxiety is coming back on having oral intercourse with a guy but he did not ejaculate, there was precum though. I am on birth control but after doing the oral intercourse two days later I started my period that was a week early and lasted 14 days. Can I get pregnant?
output:
Based on your question, if the oral intercourse you mentioned refers to oral sex - involving mouth and genitals - you cannot become pregnant from that activity, regardless of ejaculation or precum. Fertilization typically occurs in the female reproductive system when sperm comes into direct contact with an egg during vaginal intercourse.

The occurrence of pregnancy requires sperm to fertilize an egg inside the female reproductive system, specifically within the fallopian tubes after ovulation, and this cannot occur through oral intercourse. 

As for your period coming a week early and lasting 14 days, there are several reasons why menstrual cycles might change, including stress and anxiety which you mentioned you've recently been experiencing. Changes could also be caused by changes in weight, certain medical conditions, etc. But birth control should help regulate your cycle.

However, it's always best to reach out directly to your healthcare provider if you have questions about your birth control, cycle changes, or potential risk of pregnancy. Severe/lengthy bleeding can also be a symptom of other underlying health issues so discussing this with your healthcare provider would be recommended.

input: Hello doctor,I often have elbow pain due to spending more time with computer and using a mouse or keyboard. I work 7 to 8 hours daily in computer and pain is gradually increasing. The pain earlier used to reduce by taking Voveran tablet and using Voveran gel. The pain has become frequent now and I am taking Tendoshot capsule for the last few days. I also use tennis elbow strap in both hands while working and that gives some comfort. I do a few elbow exercise but that seems not sufficient in reducing pain. What is the treatment for elbow pain due to computer use?Whether should I take Voveran 50 or Tendoshot for pain relief?Is there any other medicine to use for pain relief?Whether tennis elbow strap or sleeve will be appropriate for this purpose?How to prevent elbow pain while using the computer?How serious can be this elbow pain in future?
output:
Based on your description, it sounds like you could be suffering from a repetitive strain injury (RSI), possibly 'tennis elbow' or 'computer elbow', which is common in those who spend long periods using a computer.

1. Treatment for Elbow Pain Due to Computer Use: 

   - Rest: Taking breaks from your computer can provide some relief. Aim to take frequent short breaks rather than less frequent longer ones.
   - Ergonomics: Make sure your workstation is set up properly. Your chair and desk should be at the right height, and your keyboard and mouse should be within easy reach.
   - Physical Therapy: Exercises that strengthen the muscles in your arms can help reduce pain. A physiotherapist can provide a suitable exercise regimen.
   - Medication: Over-the-counter pain relievers may help. However, they must not be relied on long term without discussion with a healthcare provider.

2. Choosing between Voveran 50 and Tendoshot:
   
    - Both medicines work in different ways. Voveran is a Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that reduces inflammation and pain, while Tendoshot is mainly used to aid tendon repair. As such, they might both be helpful depending on the specifics of your case. Please consult with a doctor who knows your history before making this decision.

3. Alternative Pain Relief:
   
   - Topical creams containing NSAIDs can be applied directly to the area causing pain.

input: Hello doctor,I am 32 years old. I am suffering from stress chest pain for the past one year. 2D echo and ECG are also normal. Is it related to heart or GERD or chest wall?I am taking Cita-S 10 mg and Pantosec.
output:
Chest pain may originate from the heart, lungs, esophagus, muscles, ribs, or nerves, among others. Heart problems related chest pain usually comes on with exercise (angina) and improves with rest. If your ECG and 2D echo are normal and there's no improvement or worsening of symptoms with physical activity, it's less likely to be heart-related.

GERD (gastroesophageal reflux disease), which is a digestive disorder that affects the ring of muscle between your esophagus and your stomach can also cause chest pain. This type of chest pain tends to exacerbate after eating or at night, and can improve by taking antacids.

The fact that you're experiencing chest pain due to stress and it did not respond to Cita-S (SSRI used for reducing anxiety and depression) suggests another possible diagnosis, which could include musculoskeletal pain or even conditions like Costochondritis (inflammation of the cartilage in the rib cage).

Given your symptoms last more than one year, I'd suggest you consult with a gastroenterologist to consider GERD or other gastrointestinal causes,
also involving a psychiatrist considering a longer acting anti-anxiety medication or cognitive behavioral therapy might help if stress is the main issue causing these symptoms.

Remember that online advice is never a substitute for professional medical advice from your local healthcare provider since they have access to your full history and clinical examination findings.

input: Hello doctor,My wife was previously diagnosed with bipolar II and was taking 100 mg Lamotrigine daily for depression maintenance. She was on that dosage for nine years. She recently suffered a more chronic depressive episode and went out of town for ketamine infusion therapy. The infusions were very successful, and the psychiatrist who was assessing her for the infusions suggested that she did not need the Lamotrigine, that it was ineffective for treating depression in bipolar II. She tapered off the Lamotrigine, which was very difficult.It has been three to four weeks since her last dose of Lamotrigine, and nine weeks since her infusions. She is feeling very moody and depressed, irritability, fatigue, loss of focus. The question is, do you think she needs to go back on the Lamotrigine? Or does she need to get a booster shot of Ketamine? Both are difficult solutions. Getting off the Lamotrigine was awful, and getting Ketamine requires out of town travel, etc. Kindly advice.
output:
It's important to remember that I am relying only on the information given and cannot make a direct medical diagnosis or recommend specific treatments. However, your wife's symptoms indicate the presence of lingering depressive symptoms, which could be due to her bipolar II disorder. It sounds like both Lamotrigine and ketamine have been beneficial for her in the past.

Each option has its own set of considerations: restarting Lamotrigine can take weeks to months to reach full effectiveness again, and it may potentially produce similar side effects she experienced while tapering off. On the other hand, getting another round of ketamine infusions involves travel but might work faster to alleviate her symptoms.

Before making any decision, it is essential to discuss these options with her current psychiatrist who can evaluate her current condition, review her history, and weigh pros and cons based on exact details. It is also necessary to explore whether there are additional treatment modalities—such as psychotherapy—that could help manage her mood swings alongside medication. Sometimes a combination of approaches tends to work best for managing symptoms of bipolar disorder.

Please consult her mental health provider before making any changes to her medication regimen. Also remember to monitor for signs of acute mood changes or suicidality, as these should prompt urgent professional attention.

input: Hello doctor,I had all four wisdom teeth pulled nine days ago. Only the one on the bottom right tooth is very painful and when I push near it all this foul smelling yellow stuff comes out. What is wrong? Also, having headaches.
output:
It sounds like you might have a condition called dry socket, or alveolar osteitis. This happens when the blood clot that normally forms after an extraction is dislodged or dissolves. That leaves the bone and nerves exposed to everything in your mouth, resulting in pain and bad odor. It can also lead to an infection if not properly treated. 

The headaches could be related to the inflammation or infection at the site or possibly from referred pain due to the issue with your tooth.

I would recommend making an immediate appointment with your dentist or oral surgeon for evaluation. They will likely clean the area and may place a medicated gauze into the socket to help promote healing and reduce symptoms. Depending on the situation, they may prescribe antibiotics as well.

In the meantime, rinse your mouth gently with warm salt water every 2 hours and after eating to keep it clean. Also, avoid smoking, using straws, and anything else that might cause a suction motion in your mouth. Keep hydrated and eat soft foods. Analgesics such as ibuprofen (unless contraindicated) can help manage the pain. You should seek immediate professional attention to prevent potential complications.

input: Hi doctor,My father is 56 years old. He is having negative thoughts and talks about deaths, has a vivid dream with severe sleepiness. He is not enjoying anything which he enjoyed before. He has short-term memory loss. He has fatigue with increased appetite. He has little issue in breathing during sleeping. He can identify people. But, he is unable to remember what happened before five minutes. He is completely confused by his dreams and reality.These problems have started in my father after a traumatic event in which my father has lost his brother and two sons of his brother in an accident that happened before three months. He has a previous history of Bell\s palsy, a little hearing loss, and was also diagnosed with a small lesion in the hypothalamus which is not cancerous. I want to know whether these traumatic events have played a part in these symptoms or its due to the lesion. The MRI of the brain shows the possibility of glioma. Please suggest.
output:
I'm sorry to hear about your father's situation. It seems like he is dealing with quite a lot right now. From the symptoms described, it appears your father may be suffering from a severe condition known as Major Depressive Disorder (MDD), or clinical depression, which could have been triggered by the traumatic loss he encountered.

Additionally, his short-term memory loss, disorientation, and confusion between dreams and reality might suggest potential neurological issues beyond depression. Given that he has a history of Bell's Palsy, has had vascular changes in the brain due to aging and has a small lesion in the hypothalamus, these might contribute to the symptoms. 

The possibility of glioma shown in the MRI scan could also manifest similar symptoms of cognitive impairment, including problems with memory. This will certainly need further investigation.

In summary, while the recent traumatic events likely play a role, all other factors mentioned should be considered too. I'd strongly recommend you to consult with a psychiatrist for his depressive symptoms and a neurologist for further evaluation regarding the possible glioma and existing brain lesion. It's crucial to manage both his mental and physical health at this point. The earlier the intervention, the better chances there are for improvement and preservation of his functionality and quality of life.

input: Hello doctor,Before two weeks, I have undergone I and D for breast abscess, from that day I have stopped feeding my baby. On 21st of March doctor checked and said no need of dressing and there is a small lump still present keep warm compress it will go and told me not to feed the baby. I am keeping warm compress daily once but no result. Yesterday, the wound completely healed and there was no leakage of milk from the wound. So I started feeding my baby.In the night I fed my baby on the wounded breast but in the morning I observed swelling again on the breast. So I kept hot compress and started pumping. Then I observed a very thick pus on my nipple just a drop. After that, I am trying to hand express and pumping but the pus is not coming out. Now I am very afraid that my gynecologist may again suggest I and D. In the present scenario it is very tough for me to go hospital every day for dressing carrying a small baby. Please tell me whether it can be healed by antibiotics? Can I feed my baby? If I feed baby will that pus affect my baby?
output:
I'm sorry to hear that you've been experiencing discomfort and anxiety after your I and D (Incision and Drainage) procedure for the breast abscess.

It appears that you might have experienced re-infection or perhaps an incomplete resolution of the initial infection, especially if you noticed thick pus. At this point, it is crucial to contact your doctor and/or gynecologist again as soon as possible. They will be able to evaluate your current condition accurately, potentially order diagnostic tests, and make a decision about additional treatments such as antibiotics.

Feeding your baby in these conditions evokes valid concerns. If there is indeed an active infection with pus, it might pose a risk to your baby's health because infectious particles could possibly contaminate the milk. For now, until you can get further guidance from your healthcare provider, consider expressing and discarding milk which may feel painful due to blocked milk ducts and engorgement but is necessary to maintain milk production for when you're able to resume breastfeeding safely.

This advice is based on general medical practice; specific management might change depending upon clinical findings by your local healthcare provider.

input: Hi doctor,What is the difference between IntraLasik and Contoura Lasik?
output:
IntraLASIK and Contoura LASIK are both types of laser eye surgery performed to correct vision, but they offer different technologies and procedures:

1. IntraLASIK: This technique makes use of a femtosecond laser to create the corneal flap instead of a blade. The laser results in a precise flap that fits back perfectly during recovery. It's less likely to cause complications compared to a bladed procedure.

2. Contoura Lasik: Also known as Topography-Guided LASIK, this is an advanced form of customizable LASIK that uses topographical mapping of your eye to guide treatment. This allows surgeons to perform highly individualized vision corrections based on the unique shape of your eye's surface. It has been shown to improve visual acuity beyond what regular glasses or contact lenses can provide.

So the main difference is how the surgeon prepares your eye for the treatment (i.e., how the corneal flap is created) and how the actual correction is carried out (standard corrections vs highly personalized ones). Both procedures serve similar purposes, i.e., to help patients get rid of eyeglasses or contact lenses and improve their eyesight significantly.

It's important to discuss these options with your doctor, considering factors like your overall health, eye condition, lifestyle, and personal preferences before deciding which option is best for you.

input: Hello doctor,For almost a week now I have had recurring random pain just behind both of my ear lobes. It has been almost three weeks since I stopped Lyrica, Pregabalin completely for back pain. For the last week I have been experiencing something different which can be best described as random pressure or light pain almost behind both the ear lobes, sometimes the feeling is localized just there other times it travels towards the neck, occasionally towards the mastoid bone or it extends towards the lower jawline. I have been crazily searching to see if this is a result of any swollen lymph node fearing cancer but I could not find anything out of the ordinary on the body. Very rarely I feel this pressure going upwards to the ear and even more rarely a sudden pain arises inside the ear too but I hear no ringing or sounds. The weirdest thing is today I woke up with this sensation and I could feel heaviness behind my ears.This has come after an acute sinus infection, cough, night sweats (for which I had to take antibiotics) that hit me when I started tapering off Lyrica last month. I have had chronic sinus issues in the past too but this one was different, never had it progress to this level. I have uploaded an image of where exactly the pain or pressure originates but right now the pain or pressure is pretty spread out randomly across the neck. Can you please tell me what is going on and what could be the cause of this pain or pressure? Medicines: Although the sinus problem seems to be resolved now I am still taking Loratadine D, Xynosine nasal spray and Librax for IBS related issues.
output:
It sounds like you have been through a lot recently. Stopping Lyrica, having a sinus infection and dealing with chronic health conditions can all take a toll on your body. The symptoms you are describing could be due to many causes like TMJ disorders, infections, neck muscle stress or even Masotiditis.

But given your recent headcold/sinusitis and the location specifics of your pain, two things come to mind:

1) It's possible that this could be related to your sinuses as they drain into the areas near your ears and neck which could create pressure and discomfort. The residual inflammation from your last bout of acute sinusitis might still be causing a certain degree of obstruction in your sinus outflow tracts leading to these congestive symptoms.
 
2) You may also be feeling the effects of lymph node swelling (lymphadenopathy). If your lymph nodes are reacting to a past/present infection, it is more likely for them to cause pain and give a 'heavy' sensation rather than being linked to a cancer, especially if these symptoms appeared following an infectious episode.

The medicines you're taking (especially Loratadine D for allergies and ongoing Xynosine nasal spray use) support the notion of unresolved sinus issues. However, because there are so many potential reasons for your symptoms, we cannot make any conclusions until further investigations have been performed.

For the next steps, I would recommend:
- Having face-to-face clinical evaluation by your healthcare provider
- ENT specialist referral

input: Hi doctor,I started with the gym last week. I trained myself at home for a few weeks. After going to the gym, I began to have pain in the knees. It hurts me a lot. I am unable to do squats for a week. I tried to fix it, and nothing helped me. I do not know what to do. Please help.
output:
It sounds like you might have a common condition known as patellofemoral pain syndrome, often called "runner's knee" or "jumper's knee". This happens when the kneecap doesn't track properly along the groove in the femur causing inflammation and pain. It's often due to muscle imbalances or weakness--particularly in the glute muscles and quadriceps.

In the meanwhile, give yourself enough time to heal - that means slowing down with workouts especially ones putting load on your knees such as squats or jogging. Focus on non-weight bearing exercises for now.

Physical therapy is typically highly beneficial for this type of problem. Visiting a physical therapist can provide a tailored program of stretches and strengthening exercises that should offer relief and prevent future problems.

Over-the-counter anti-inflammatory medications like ibuprofen near the affected area may help with initial pain management.

Most importantly, it would be best to schedule an appointment with an orthopedic specialist who can confirm the diagnosis and rule out other potential problems. They may also want to get imaging done such as an X-Ray or MRI based on what they find in their clinical exam.

input: Hello doctor,I am 30 years old and married for 2.4 years. Now we are planning for a child. On 14th of this month, I experienced periods with very little stomach pain and pain in legs. The next day on 15th there was no bleeding at all, 16th I had spotting of light red colored blood flow, 17th the same thing happened and then the flow stopped. Again on 23rd night I had bleeding light red coloured blood flow, on 24th no bleeding at all, 25th I had fresh pink colored spotting. Then 26th pinkish brownish spotting occurred, 27th morning I did pregnancy test by urine, it came negative, and at 8 AM had brownish spotting, 28th had brownish spotting too. Please help me to know whether it is implantation bleeding or anything else.
output:
It's not entirely clear from your description, however the bleeding you experienced could be implantation bleeding, which some women experience as a fertilized egg implants into the uterine wall, typically around the time of expected menstruation. Implantation bleeding is typically lighter and shorter in duration than a normal period, often brownish or light pink, which seems consistent with what you're describing.

However, it can also be a result of other factors such as changes in hormonal levels, stress, weight fluctuations, use of oral contraceptives etc.

Unfortunately, home pregnancy tests may not always be accurate this early on due to low levels of the pregnancy hormone hCG. It's recommended that women wait until at least one week after a missed period to take a home pregnancy test for most accurate results.

If your irregular bleeding persists, if you experience severe pain, or other symptoms like nausea/vomiting, dizziness, fatigue, please seek medical attention. If unsure, it's always best to consult with your healthcare provider for further advice and potentially more sensitive testing options.

input: Hi doctor,I pee very often (even though I am young and I do not have diabetes or anything), and I get horn whenever my bladder is full. I do not think it as a healthy habit, and it disturbs me. Please help me.
output:
I understand your concerns. Frequent urination can be a symptom of various conditions, including but not limited to urinary tract infection, overactive bladder syndrome, interstitial cystitis, or even due to intake of certain types of food and drinks. There are also psychological factors that could lead to perceived frequent urination.

The arousal you're experiencing when having a full bladder might be related to the pressure exerted on certain parts of your body, which can sometimes trigger such responses.

However, these are just possibilities, so it's vital you see a healthcare provider for physical examination and perhaps laboratory tests if needed. They'll be able to give you a definitive diagnosis after considering all potential causes and taking into account your health history. Remember there is no substitute for in-person consultation with a doctor. Please seek professional help immediately.

input: Hi doctor,I had periods on 26th and had protected sex on the 4th of the following month. After that, I took an i-pill within 2 hours. Now, I am bleeding like my periods ie after 8 days of i-pill. Is this my period? If not, can I expect my periods on the coming 26th?
output:
The bleeding you're experiencing right now could be withdrawal bleeding induced by the emergency contraceptive pill, or "i-pill," that you took. This kind of bleeding is usually lighter than a regular period and it's a common side effect of emergency contraception.

Having said that, taking emergency contraceptives can sometimes disrupt your regular menstrual cycle and cause your periods to come earlier or later than expected. You might not necessarily have your next period on the expected date (26th). It could be earlier or delayed by a week or so. If there's significant delay in your menstrual cycle, it would be wise to take a pregnancy test just to rule out any possibility of pregnancy. 

However, I must stress the importance of using regular methods of contraception instead of relying on emergency pills for avoiding pregnancy. Also ensure proper use of barrier methods to prevent sexually transmitted diseases.

input: Hello doctor,Due to excess of masturbation in my teenage time, I feel my penis size has become short and thin. Now I am 22 years old. So, is it possible to get back that previous size if I follow any instructions advised by you? I do not drink or smoke.
output:
The idea that masturbation alters the size or structure of your penis is a myth. Masturbation does not cause shrinkage or any other type of physical change. It sounds like you're experiencing some anxiety about this, which is quite common and normal.

The average penis size when erect can range from 4 inches to 6 inches approximately, with significant variability. This is all genetically dictated - you cannot make it larger or smaller by any form of exercise, including sexual activity or lack thereof.

However, overall physical health can play a role in penis size. Being overweight can make the penis appear shorter as fat makes up around the base of the penis. Lifestyle choices such as healthy diet, regular exercise and avoiding smoking could certainly help maintain good circulatory health, which also impacts erectile function. 

Keep in mind that it's more important to have a healthy view about our bodies than achieving some sort of 'perfect' size. In terms of actual sexual satisfaction for you and your partner(s), communication, trust, respect and understanding each other's bodies and wants matter far more. If you're concerned about your body or sexual performance, it would be advisable get professional medical advice to alleviate your concerns.

input: Hello doctor,I have many deep acne scars on my face. I have shown to many doctors but did not get a good result. I have found now that lastly, I will have to go for laser treatment. Please suggest me what to do.
output:
As a dermatologist, laser treatment can indeed be an effective method for improving the appearance of deep acne scars. However, it is crucial to ensure you choose the appropriate type of laser treatment as there are several types.

Ablative lasers remove layers of skin around the scar tissue and encourage new, healthy skin to grow in its place. Non-ablative lasers stimulate collagen growth, which helps 'fill in' the scarring from within. Fractional lasers treat microscopic columns of skin at a time which allows for faster healing.

Apart from laser treatments, other options include Chemical peels, Dermabrasion/Microdermabrasion, Fillers, Microneedling (collagen induction therapy), or even surgery depending on the severity of your scars.

Please understand that every individual's skin is unique, so the course of action varies per person. It is advisable to consult with a dermatologist who will examine your skin type, the severity of your scarring, and discuss your desired outcome. They would then be able to suggest the best plan for you based on these findings. Remember not to rush this process as you want to find the most beneficial solution for you.

Also, while undergoing treatment, continue following a good skincare routine. Keep your face clean, use non-comedogenic products, and protect your skin from direct sunlight, as UV radiation can make scars more noticeable and slow down healing.

Remember any procedure involves potential risks and benefits, so ensure you fully understand these before making a decision.

input: Hello doctor,I have been suffering from a fungal infection in the inner thighs for more than a month now. I used Terbinaforce tablets. For a month now, I am using only Sebifin cream. But I cannot see much improvement. Can you please suggest me any better treatment or medicine?
output:
I'm sorry to hear you're having trouble with a fungal infection. It seems like you've been using Terbinaforce (terbinafine) tablet and Sebifin (terbinafine) cream already. If it is not improving, there could be multiple reasons:

1. You may have a resistant strain of fungus which might not be responding to terbinafine.
2. The dosage or duration of treatment might need adjustment.
3. It may not be a simple fungal infection anymore - secondary bacterial involvement can complicate the situation.

Please visit your healthcare provider as soon as possible because they can examine the infected area and suggest appropriate treatment according to the type and severity of the infection. They might send swabs for culture to determine if a specifically resistant organism is causing this issue. 

However, in the meantime keep the area clean, dry, wear loose breathable clothing and continue applying the antifungal ointment until instructed otherwise by your doctor. Please avoid self-medication as it may worsen the condition.

input: Hello doctor, I am getting severe pain on the left side of the shoulder and chest for the past four days. Is this a cardiac problem?
output:
As a doctor, I'd say it's important to not ignore this kind of severe pain particularly when it's in the chest area. While some heart attacks are sudden and intense, many start slowly with mild pain or discomfort only occasionally escalating into more intense pain. Other conditions, such as lung diseases or gastrointestinal disorders, could also cause similar symptoms.

But remember, online advice is never a substitute for professional medical advice. You should really be seen by a healthcare provider right away - if the pain is severe, you experience shortness of breath, or other associated symptoms, please go to an emergency department immediately. Don't take chances with your health!

input: Hello doctor,Impact injury to right ankle eight months ago, still painful and gets swollen. MRI was done on it. I am 20 years old, 158 cm, and 52 kg. All healthy apart from this. My daily medication is 20 mg Fluoxetine.
output:
The symptoms of pain and swelling over a long duration post injury suggests that there might be an unresolved issue in your ankle. This could range from chronic ligament tear, bone bruising, cartilage damage, stress fracture or even the development of arthritis due to persistent stress on the injured joint.

Fluoxetine is generally used for depression or obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) and it's not very likely this would interfere with the healing process of your ankle, unless you have been much less active as a result of mood issues.

As per your report, you have already had an MRI done, which should give us more detailed information about soft tissue structures like ligaments and tendons. I'm assuming you've not provided those details here - so please go back and consult with the healthcare provider who ordered your MRI scan, and ask for an interpretation that may help explain your ongoing symptoms. They will also guide you towards proper management either through medication, physiotherapy or possibly surgery; depending upon the nature of your injury.
  
In addition, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), rest, ice packs and elevation of foot can provide symptomatic relief. Please seek local health professionals for more guidance and follow their advice diligently.

input: Hello doctor,I had unprotected oral sex with a CSW. I ejaculated in her mouth. She ran quickly to spit. I do not know if she was HIV positive or not. Should I be worried about my health?
output:
While the risk of HIV transmission through oral sex is generally lower compared to vaginal or anal sex, it's not zero. There are several factors that can increase this risk such as the presence of gum diseases, open sores in the mouth, or genital infections on your part. Given that you have had an unprotected sexual encounter with a commercial sex worker whose HIV status is unknown, I would advise you to get tested for HIV and other sexually transmitted infections (STIs) as soon as possible for your peace of mind.

If you believe you may have been exposed to HIV within the past 72 hours, discuss with your healthcare provider about Post-Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP), which involves taking antiretroviral medicines as soon as possible after potential exposure to reduce the chance of becoming HIV-positive. 

Lastly, remember to use protection (condoms/dental dams) during any future sexual encounters. It's especially important for potentially risky situations such as relations with someone whose STI status you don't know.

input: Hi doctor,I am 17 years old female. I have persistent depression and social anxiety disorder. I have not ever taken medication for this issue. My social anxiety usually springs me into full-blown panic attacks like shaking, feeling unsteady, trouble catching breathes, extreme twitchiness and my throat close up. I wanted to go for an audition for a singing competition, but I have social anxiety, and it is a severe debilitating symptom. I have been wondering if there is any medicine to take as a temporary sedate as it is enough for me to perform, and to stop taking them when it is not needed.
output:
I am really sorry to hear about your struggles with anxiety and depression. As a physician, it's important for me to tell you that while there are medications that can help manage these symptoms short term, they should not be used as a standalone treatment.

Beta-adrenergic blockers such as Propranolol is often used 'as needed' to control physical symptoms of anxiety like shaking and twitchiness. It doesn't directly affect the emotional symptoms of anxiety but by reducing physical symptoms, it can help to feel more in control of the situation.

In addition to the potential use of medication, I strongly recommend seeking long-term therapy and support from a qualified healthcare professional or counselor. Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) has been shown to be very effective in managing social anxiety disorder and could help to address the root cause of these symptoms, making situations like your audition easier to deal with in the future.

Always remember any medication must be prescribed and monitored by a healthcare professional due to potential side effects and interactions with other possible medications you're taking.

input: Hi doctor,I have flaky skin on my scalp. My doctor told me it is sebopsoriasis. The flaking is limited to the scalp, and my doctor has prescribed Folitrax 5 mg and Aprezo 30 mg. I am having this problem for about four to five years. I am able to control flaking in the scalp by washing with shampoo but, it reoccurs after a day with hair loss. Can it be controlled? Or can it spread to other parts of the body?
output:
Sebopsoriasis is a complex skin condition that has features of both seborrheic dermatitis and psoriasis, which is characterized by flakes on the scalp and sometimes other parts of the body. It often flares up periodically then resolves, but can become more persistent.

Folitrax (Methotrexate) and Aprezo (Apremilast) are medications commonly used to treat psoriasis. They help reduce inflammation in your body, thereby helping to control symptoms like flaking and redness.

The condition itself doesn't usually spread to uninvolved areas of the body. Instead, new spots may appear on different skin surfaces independent from places where it's already established. Also, the severity of the disease and its progression vary for each individual. Sometimes, lifestyle modifications such as minimizing alcohol intake, maintaining a balanced diet, reducing stress, avoiding harsh soaps/shampoos, and using emollients can assist with managing the condition. 

Your hair loss could be due to relentless inflammation, scratching or friction on your scalp. This should improve as you continue treatment, but if it does not, it would be worth mentioning this concern to your doctor.

Washing your hair regularly with a medicated shampoo specifically designed to tackle sebopsoriasis can be beneficial. These types of shampoos contain ingredients like ketoconazole, zinc pyrithione, tar etc. which have anti-inflammatory and antifungal properties which will help control the scale and flake build

input: Hello doctor,I am suffering from follicles on legs from six months it is non-itchy and painless, and when I apply any cream Clop-G it becomes tiny, and after stopping the cream becomes as usual, and from six months, I saw a minor change in the increase or decrease in size. Please suggest what is this? And how I can clear this?
output:
The condition you are describing could possibly be folliculitis, an inflammation of the hair follicles, or keratosis pilaris, a common skin condition that causes tiny bumps on the skin surface. These conditions can sometimes appear similar but have different treatments.

In case of folliculitis, it is often caused by bacterial infections, fungal infections, viruses, or even injury to your hair follicles. They usually resolve with time provided proper hygiene is maintained. Topical antibiotics are also used in some cases. 

Keratosis pilaris on the other hand has no cure as it's chronic and tends to flare up periodically. It can be managed with routines that involve regular moisturizing and exfoliation. Also, keeping the skin at warm instead of hot water when bathing helps.

Creams like Clop-G (which contain steroids) might decrease the inflammation temporarily making them look smaller for a while, however these creams should not be stopped abruptly without consulting a doctor as they may cause unwanted side effects like thinning of skin, discoloration etc., if used for longer periods without supervision.

I would suggest you to consult a dermatologist who can examine you properly, confirm the diagnosis and put you on suitable treatment regimen. If required, don't hesitate to ask for prescription alternatives for long term use which have minimal side effects.  

Remember, never to self medicate with prescription drugs, always follow the instructions of a qualified healthcare provider.

input: Hi doctor,My nephew is 3 and a half years old. He fell from the bed and hurt his nose around 7 or 8 months back. Now, as the doctors have said, his bone there is moving in the wrong direction, that is towards inside. What is the best course of action for him? Should he go under the knife? I am pleased for your advice.
output:
If your nephew's nasal bone is indeed deviated inwards due to the fall, he may have a condition commonly known as a deviated septum. This condition may interfere with normal breathing and might lead to nosebleeds or frequent sinus infections.

If an otolaryngologist (ear-nose-throat specialist) has diagnosed this condition and the child is experiencing significant symptoms such as difficulty breathing or recurrent infections, surgery like a septoplasty may be considered. But typically, ENT doctors prefer to wait until a child's facial bones are fully developed before they consider surgical intervention unless there are serious breathing issues, frequent nosebleeds, or recurrent sinus infections. Understandably, these decisions are often made on a case-by-case basis by the consulting doctor who can assess all aspects of the patient's health status.

In any case, please continue seeking medical advice from a pediatric ENT specialist. They will guide you on the best course of action including decisions about whether surgery would be right for your nephew now, or if it should wait.

input: Hi doctor,I am a 46 year old female. I am suffering from extreme rage and irritability for the past two years. I am on Femilon for three months for adenomyosis and adenomyoma. I feel desperate. Please suggest some medication for my rage.
output:
I'm sorry to hear that you're going through this. The feelings of rage and irritation could be due to multiple causes which include hormonal changes, stress, mental health conditions like depression or anxiety, etc.

However, it's important that you don't start any medication without proper evaluation. I would recommend consulting with a psychiatrist. You might benefit from some form of psychological therapy like cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) or even medications such as mood stabilizers or selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors(SSRIs).

That being said, your current issues of irritability, extreme rage and desperation need urgent attention. If these feelings are accompanied by any thoughts of harm towards self or others, seek immediate help at nearest emergency room.

input: Hi doctor,I have a protruded mole on my leg (light color but it will become black if in contact with water), it lasts for about two or three years or more. I have no symptoms other than it will fall off as time pasts and grow back itself. I was wondering what would it be as I am worried if that is some kind of melanoma?
output: Moles are usually harmless and can change over time. However, given that your mole changes color when in contact with water and falls off to then regrow, I would recommend you have it examined by a dermatologist as soon as possible. Although it may not necessarily be malignant or cancerous such as melanoma, these characteristics do warrant further investigation. Please remember, it's always better to get any skin changes checked out early for peace of mind.

input: Hello doctor,When I was 11 years old, I was knocked off my bike and cracked my front tooth in half horizontally, shortly after the dentist fixed it. Since then I have had no problems with it and had multiple x-rays to check on it. When it happened, the color of the tooth changed very slightly, to a very slightly more yellow shade than the rest of my teeth. I am curious to know what happened when the trauma occurred. Did my tooth die? What are they checking for when they x-ray the tooth?
output:
Hello! Traumatic dental injuries can affect the tooth in various ways, depending on the severity of the injury. When you suffered your accident, it's possible that the impact affected the pulp inside the tooth - the living tissue containing blood vessels and nerves. This might have led to some discoloration. An x-ray after such an event would allow a dentist to see any damage that isn't visible from the outside, such as fractures that extend into the root or potential damage to the surrounding bone.

The concern is that if the pulp was significantly injured, it could result in pulp necrosis, essentially meaning the tooth "dies" because its vital tissues are no longer healthy. Dead or dying pulpal cells can leak out, staining the dentin within the tooth, thus causing further discoloration. However, given that you've reported no other symptoms (like pain or discomfort), it's likely that your tooth pulp survived the trauma or at least didn't die immediately, especially since the dentist repaired it promptly!

During subsequent check-ups and x-rays, they probably wanted to make sure there were no signs of infection or abscesses forming, which could be complications if the tooth had indeed died and not been treated properly. The fact that you've experienced no major complications since then suggests that the interventions were successful!

input: Hi doctor,I have been wearing braces for teeth alignment. I am towards the end of my treatment and have developed a high pitched sound in my right ear. I consulted with my orthodontist and temporarily removed the wires on two occasions. Both times, the ringing went down after some weeks. When I put on again, the sound started. One ENT I consulted said it could be an allergy to dust in the area I live in. Based on the information I received and the symptoms, I am not sure how to proceed. What is the cause of this issue?
output:
Your symptoms sound like tinnitus, which is defined as the perception of noise or ringing in the ears. It's a common problem that affects about 15 to 20 percent of people and is often associated with some level of hearing loss, but it can also be related to stress, ear infection, medications, exposure to loud noises, and certain medical conditions.

It is interesting that you note an association between wearing your braces and the start of the sound. While there's no established direct link between orthodontic treatment and tinnitus, dental issues such as teeth grinding (bruxism), misalignment of the jaw joints (temporomandibular joint disorder - TMJ), or muscle tension could potentially contribute.

The advice from the ENT doctor could also be possible as allergies may lead to eustachian tube dysfunction, leading to ear fullness and tinnitus. 

Given your unique situation, I suggest you discussing this again with both your ENT specialist and your orthodontist, possibly having them collaborate if necessary. This way they can create a more specific plan tailored just for you and help figure out exactly what may be causing your symptoms. You might benefit from visiting a dentist specializing in TMJ disorders as well. Make sure to mention any other symptoms you have so they can evaluate you thoroughly.

input: Hello doctor,I am 68 years old with a weight of 76 kg and a height of 5 feet 9 inches. I had a bypass surgery seven years ago. I used to walk 45 minutes daily. I feel completely fit and fine. A week ago, I felt that my heart rhythm was irregular. After going through a Holter test, I found that my heart rate increases and slows down with a pause of 1.8 seconds. My minimal heart rate is 50 and the maximum is 144 BPM. My average heart rate is 89. Is there anything serious?More details about the presenting complaint include I rarely get a headache with no other symptoms. I am currently taking Razel Gold once a day. In the past, I have been on Concor 5 mg once a day and Razel Gold once a day. I have gone through TMT three to four months ago with a normal outcome. The doctor also did an echocardiogram and everything seemed normal. Please help.
output:
Based on the symptoms you have described, it seems like you may be experiencing a heart rhythm disorder, possibly atrial fibrillation or paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). However, without actually examining your Holter test results and consulting with you in-person, I cannot definitively diagnose your condition.

Your history of cardiac bypass surgery puts you at an increased risk for heart rhythm disorders. The irregular heart rhythm coupled with a pause of 1.8 seconds could indicate a problem, despite the lack of other symptoms typically associated with these conditions (like dizziness, shortness of breath, chest discomfort etc.).

To manage this situation carefully, you should consult your cardiologist promptly. You may be recommended to undergo further tests such as a stress echocardiogram or electrophysiology study. Depending upon the test results, treatment options can include medication, lifestyle changes, cardioversion, or potentially a procedure called ablation that helps correct heart rhythm problems.

Don't panic – many people live normal lives with heart rhythm disorders, especially when properly diagnosed and treated. It's important, though, that you address this issue with your medical team.

input: Hi doctor,I have a small freckle about 3-4 mm on the side of my foot. It is not different from my skin in appearance. It just seems to be a brown blemish. I think, I have it for a number of years and now I am a bit anxious about what it could be. Thank you.
output:
Hello! It sounds like what you're describing could be a mole, which is usually harmless and happens when skin cells grow in a cluster instead of being spread throughout your skin. They can develop anywhere on your body, including your feet.

Although most moles are non-cancerous, it's important to monitor them for changes. This could include things like growth, change in color or shape, asymmetry, irregular borders, or becoming painful or itchy.

Since you said that this mole hasn't changed over years and you haven't noticed anything unusual about it besides its existence, it likely doesn't pose any risk. However, if you're concerned, it's always best to consult with a dermatologist or primary care physician who can examine the mole in person and provide you with an accurate diagnosis.

Seeing a doctor will help ease your anxiety and ensure healthful practices. Even though it may not seem dangerous at the moment, regular check-ups in the future would be beneficial as part of preventive medicine.

input: Hello doctor,I am 35 years old. My period was a month back. It sustained for four days. I generally use 3 to 4 pads in my periods. I had sex 10 days later. On the very next day, I had two Ovral G at around 9 AM and there after 12 hours again two Ovral G tablets. I noticed my period 12 days later, though it lasted for four days, the period was less and usually, my period happens four days earlier. In this month, it was six days earlier. I did hCG beta blood test. I am sending you the report. Can I be pregnant or conceive? Please advise because I want to abort. I am an unmarried woman. Can the blood test be wrong? What laboratory test I should do to get to know whether the fetus is there beyond uterus (ectopic pregnancy) as I m 35+. When should I go for ultrasound vagina testing to get the true picture? After that I did not have any sex, so then again can I be pregnant and that could not be detected now and can be detected on later?
output:
You've mentioned a few things here, let's try to address each one. 

Firstly, the Ovral G you took is an oral contraceptive pill which can be used as emergency contraception if taken within 72 hours of unprotected sex. So if you had taken that appropriately, it would decrease the chances of conception.

Secondly, the change in your cycle and the lighter period may very well be due to the hormonal changes caused by taking Ovral G.

The Beta hCG blood test is a reliable way to determine pregnancy around 10 days after ovulation or one week after missed periods. If this test came out negative, and there hasn't been further sexual activity, then it's unlikely that you're pregnant. However, errors in lab tests may happen but are rare.

Regarding checking for ectopic pregnancy, a transvaginal ultrasound is typically useful after five weeks from last menstrual period (or one week after a missed period) as it can help determine location of fetus.

Please remember, though, that an ultrasound should be performed under guidance of a healthcare professional and based on symptoms and clinical judgement as asymptomatic women have low risk of ectopic pregnancy.

It’s important to consult with your personal doctor or gynecologist to supervise all these procedures and guide you through this time. These sources of information shouldn't replace a consultation with your personal health care provider.

input: Hello doctor,I am hoping you can advise me. I have a mole on my chest that has been changing for about a month now. It is itchy at times and it has bled (small spots) as I am sure from the itching. I am worried it is skin cancer. Can you help?
output:
Yes, it's very important to get this checked out further. Moles that change size, color or shape, become itchy and especially moles that bleed could potentially be melanoma, a type of skin cancer. However, only a detailed checkup and a biopsy can confirm the nature of your mole. Please visit a dermatologist as soon as possible for an in-person evaluation. Remember, the earlier potential skin cancers are identified, the better their treatment outcomes usually are.

Meanwhile, try not to scratch the mole even if it's itchy because scratching may exacerbate symptoms and cause further bleeding. Of course, this advice doesn't substitute seeing a doctor, but should help until you manage to go.

input: Hello doctor,I am a 41-year-old female and have been diagnosed with viral conjunctivitis by a specialist. My eye health is otherwise perfect (had them checked out a week before this came on). After a few days, it spread to the other eye. I expect the first eye will heal first, even though the second eye is not as bad. One question is when the first eye heals, do I need to protect it from re-infection from the one that is still healing?Also, on the typical length of healing, I am not quite at two weeks yet (this is day 11 for the first eye), but the lack of improvement in my condition is becoming frustrating to me. Today the vision in the first eye is smudgy, and the vision in the second eye is better, but not perfect. The specialist was aware of the vision problems, and she said that it was normal (though I think they have worsened).I was told this could take weeks to heal, beyond the normal one or two. How many weeks are weeks generally? I was told I have a mild to moderate case, but all I know is that I have seen no real progress, and I think the virus might have even spread to one of my sinuses. My mental health is suffering from not knowing how long I am going to be cooped up, partially visually impaired and contagious. Am I impatient or should I have them looked at by a specialist again?
output:
Sorry to hear you're going through such discomfort. Viral conjunctivitis, also known as pink eye, can indeed be very frustrating due to its potentially prolonged course of illness and its ability to spread to the other eye.

To answer your first question about reinfection, while it is theoretically possible to "re-infect" one eye from another with viral particles, this isn't usually a significant issue. The immune system would have already started producing antibodies against the virus in your affected eyes, making re-infection less likely.

Viral conjunctivitis often lasts anywhere between 1-3 weeks but can extend up to 4-6 weeks or more, especially in severe cases. It sounds like you are still within the typical healing time range.

Vision changes during an episode of viral conjunctivitis are common due to corneal involvement (the clear window on the front of our eye that can get inflamed during the infection) and it's relatively normal to experience variable vision quality.

While it is entirely reasonable for you to feel impatient given the discomfort and uncertainty surrounding the recovery timeline, at nearly 2 weeks into the illness, you are still well within normal healing times. However, if your symptoms worsen dramatically, your vision changes significantly, or the pain increases, then I would suggest seeking further evaluation sooner rather than later.

Remember that hand hygiene is absolutely crucial in the management of viral conjunctivitis; frequent washing can help prevent the spread of the virus to other people

input: Hello doctor,I am 20 years old. My height is 6'4", and weight is 205 lbs. I noticed three decent sized painless blisters, looking like bumps on the shaft of my penis. I had sex before two and a half week. I do feel like I masturbate a lot which I am hoping it is, but I am freaking out with it.
output:
