input: Hello doctor,This query is regarding my husband\s health. Three months back, my husband underwent surgery for pituitary macroadenoma. He was advised Hisone steroid tablet for three months. But he has a headache on and off. He has gained 9 kg in three months, though he eats very little. Yesterday, we took the third month follow up MRI scan and I wanted to share below findings in the MRI report.Post-operative changes noted in sphenoid sinus and sellar fossa.Pituitary stalk mildly deviated to the left side.No evidence of enhancing residual and recurrent tumor seen.Polypoidal mucosal thickening noted in bilateral maxillary, ethmoidal, and right frontal sinuses.Also when I look at the scan films, near the pituitary gland few residual part of the tumor is seen. I am requesting you to have a look at my query and respond me how the report looks like. I am more anxious to know about this. Please help me to understand the current status of my husband\s health.
output:
Based on the MRI findings you've described, it appears that your husband is doing well since his pituitary macroadenoma surgery three months ago. The post-operative changes in the sphenoid sinus and sellar fossa are expected following this type of surgery, as the surgeon likely accessed the pituitary through the sphenoid sinus.

The fact that there's no evidence of enhancing residual or recurrent tumor seen implies that the surgery appears to have been successful in removing the majority, if not all, of the tumor.

Regarding the deviation of the pituitary stalk, mild deviations can be normal variations or due to physical manipulation during surgery. This by itself would not typically cause symptoms.

The polypoidal mucosal thickening noted in bilateral maxillary, ethmoidal, and right frontal sinuses might suggest the presence of sinusitis, a condition that causes inflammation and swelling of the tissue lining the sinuses, which could potentially contribute to his headache.

His weight gain, despite eating little, could be related to the Hisone (Hydrocortisone) steroid medication prescribed after surgery. Steroids can lead to an increase in appetite and subtle changes in metabolism leading to weight gain.

However, regarding the visualized residual part of the tumor in the scan films, without physically having the scans, I cannot offer a precise analysis. Therefore, discussing these points with your husband's neurosurgeon/neurologist/endocrinologist who has access to all the relevant medical information will

input: Hi doctor,Can you tell me within how many days angiography must be done after a heart attack?
output:
Timing for an angiography after a heart attack can vary greatly and is dependent upon various factors such as the severity of the heart attack, the patient's symptoms, overall health condition, and stability. 

In some cases, if it was a severe heart attack with ongoing chest pain, angiography may need to be done immediately- this is often called primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). For less serious heart attacks, or those that are stabilized, an angiogram might be performed within 24 to 72 hours post-heart attack.

However, every patient is different, so the timing should be individualized and discussed with the cardiologist managing the case.

input: Hello doctor,I have had many years of health problems including severe joint pain, inability to lose weight, chronic fatigue, transient pains, and abdominal pains that seem to come and go in cycles sometimes lasting for days or even months. I have a medical phobia, so have not been to the doctor unless it was an emergency. But over 20 years ago I ended up going to the ER and had several tests. I was told I had lupus, osteoarthritis, PCOS, and thyroid issues. I have tried to treat myself and pain naturally over the years with a healthy lifestyle and natural aids, but the pain finally became so bad over the last couple of years that I have gone to some appointments.I was referred to a rhuematologist that did blood work and said I was fine except low vitamin D. I told the new doctor about the early diagnosis and she said it was probably wrong but she would run blood test anyway. When the test results came back, she said I did not have an autoimmune problem and I was fine except that I had low Vitamin D. I have a copy of the test results that look like there are some problems to me and based on her reviews and my personal experience with my health, I would very much like a second opinion. I am taking Xanax when needed. Some tests are attached. I have also had an MRI that showed osteitis pubis, fatty liver, and mild bladder inflammation.
output:
As a doctor AI model, unfortunately, I can't view your attached images but based on your symptoms and taking into consideration the diseases you were diagnosed with earlier (lupus, osteoarthritis, PCOS, and thyroid issues), my evaluation will be based on your text.

1. Lupus - It's an autoimmune disease that can cause severe fatigue, joint pain, skin lesions, shortness of breath among others. The diagnosis is usually clinical aided by specific antibody testing.
 
2. Osteoarthritis – usually presents as transient joint pains which worsen over time and affect daily life activities.

3. PCOS (polycystic ovarian syndrome) – might cause weight-gain/ inability to lose weight, abdominal pain, irregular periods, excess facial hair etc.

4. Thyroid Issues – Like hypothyroidism could lead to weight gain & chronic fatigue

5. Fatty liver indicates abnormality in lipid metabolism which may also lead to weight gain if not monitored closely. 

6. Osteitis pubis is inflammation of the pubic symphysis causing lower abdominal components including groin pain.

It seems like you have many complex medical issues going on at the same time, which is why it’s important for you to regularly see a doctor or multiple specialized doctors who can manage your conditions. Moreover, treating one condition (like optimizing Vitamin-D levels or controlling thyroid functioning) may improve other symptoms like unexplained weight gain or joint pain. 

The purpose of second opinion

input: Hi doctor,I broke a foot blister with a pin and the skin appeared intact. I disinfected it and put a dressing. But it hurts when I walk. Is this normal?
output:
Yes, it's normal for a broken blister to be sensitive and cause discomfort when you walk, as the skin underneath the blister is tender and hasn't been exposed to external pressures before. As long as there aren't any signs of infection such as redness, warmth, swelling, pus, or increasing pain, there's likely no need for concern.

However, puncturing a blister on your own can introduce bacteria and potentially cause an infection, so it isn't generally recommended. It's better to protect the blister with a bandage or padding and let it heal naturally.

If you start to see signs of infection or if the pain continues to increase, get in touch with a healthcare provider right away.

input: Hi doctor,There is a white patch on my tongue that started out as a red, inflamed taste bud. It is very painful, and the patch has got bigger.
output:
Based on the symptoms you've described, this might be oral thrush or a canker sore; however, it could also be a sign of something more serious such as oral leukoplakia, which often occurs in those who smoke or drink heavily. It's important that I clarify though that without a physical examination and further medical history, this is speculation.

Regardless, any persistent changes to your mouth should ideally be evaluated by a healthcare professional. If the condition worsens, doesn't improve after two weeks, or if you have other concerning symptoms like difficulty swallowing or unexplained weight loss, please see an oral health specialist or your primary care physician as soon as possible for evaluation and treatment.

input: Hello doctor,I have been having big rashes every night and they disappear in the morning. Sometimes, I wake up with a swollen lip, I went to the hospital and they gave me an allergy injection and some drugs Promethazine and Prednisolone tablets. They stopped and I stopped taking the drugs. Now they are back. I am a female, age 21 years.
output:
It sounds like you may be experiencing a condition known as urticaria, commonly referred to as hives. Urticaria is usually an allergic reaction, but it can also occur for other reasons such as stress or unknown causes (idiopathic). You mentioned that the hospital treated you with anti-allergy medications before and the symptoms stopped. It's possible the allergen wasn't completely eliminated from your environment.

Since the drugs provided reprieve previously, they likely addressed an underlying cause related to allergies – histamine release in your body. Prednisolone suppresses your immune system activity, which can reduce these reactions, while Promethazine is an antihistamine that directly combats the effects of histamines in your body. 

Given that your symptoms have returned after discontinuing medication, it seems that either the allergen is still present or there might be a non-avoidable trigger present (like stress, pressure, or temperature changes.)

You should speak with your doctor right away given this recurrence and particularly with the swelling of lips, so-called angioedema, which could indicate a more serious allergic reaction. Make sure to provide them any details about changes in your diet, products you have started using etc, anything new that may act as an allergen. In the meantime, continue taking the prescriptions you were initially given since they provided relief.

input: Hello doctor,I am a 20 year old female and had sex for the first time. I took Regestrone to delay my periods because I planned to get intimate the same day as my periods. I took them for three to four days before my expected period date and had the tablet two to three times a day. Last dose I had it just the night before having sex. I had sex many times the next night but with protection and took an i-pill to be sure. Next week got light periods that were very painful. But ignored it thinking it was because of hormonal imbalance. Both of us were affected by flu and it turned into a stomach infection with alternate periods of diarrhea and constipation that was accompanied with mild nausea but had no vomiting. I became very weak and then eventually recovered by taking Pantocid, Digene and Zandu pancharishta. I am six days overdue and had slight back pain, nausea and increased urination. I do have migraine issues as well as I am quite obese with a BMI of 33.8. I got two home pregnancy tests done and both of them turned out to be negative. However, I still have not got my periods yet and I have been insisted to check for PCOS and get an ultrasound done. I am worried if the ultrasound shows that I am pregnant. I have gained about 4 kg. Is it possible to get a false negative six weeks after having sex? What can I do to get my periods early? Please advice.
output:
From what you've explained, it sounds like there could be multiple factors contributing to your period delay. It's important to understand that having sex for the first time, using hormonal tablets like Regestrone and i-pill, dealing with an infection as well as stress, can all disrupt your menstrual cycle. As you are obese, this can also affect hormone levels and normal menstruation.

According to research, home pregnancy tests are about 99% accurate when taken correctly, and false negatives are very rare especially six weeks after intercourse so it is highly unlikely that you may have had a false negative result twice if followed instructions properly. But there is still a very small chance, so if you are really concerned, you could see a healthcare provider and discuss the possibility of taking a blood test, which offers higher accuracy. 

For PCOS diagnosis, an ultrasound is one of the methods. However, it’s also possible to diagnose based on other symptoms or blood tests, and the ultrasound finding would just confirm the clinical suspicion. If you do have PCOS, weight reduction, diet changes, and sometimes hormonal therapy under guidance can help regulate your periods.

In terms of inducing your period earlier, unless absolutely necessary, it's better to let your body get back into its rhythm naturally. However, if you have any further doubts, do not hesitate to consult your gynecologist for proper evaluation.

input: Hello doctor,Should I get a permanent retainer months after braces and use of a removable retainer? Part of my overbite has returned since I got my braces off due to tongue thrusting. Partly because I never wore my retainers as much as I should have. Can I get a permanent retainer at this point? Or is it too late?
output:
Yes, you can consider getting a permanent retainer even months after your braces have been removed. However, it's important to review this decision with your orthodontist first. Permanent retainers can be great for maintaining tooth alignment because they take the responsibility of remembering to wear your removable retainer out of your hands. 

But remember, permanent retainers do not prevent changes in bite or the return of an overbite due to tongue thrusting. They mainly keep teeth in place. You might need additional treatment like tongue thrust therapy or other specific interventions depending on the severity of your condition.

So I would strongly recommend booking an appointment with your orthodontist who can evaluate your current situation and advise you accordingly.

input: Hello doctor,After having intercourse with my husband, I had taken Unwanted 72 within 12 hours of intercourse. But, I missed my periods and got pregnant. Now, my question is will this ECP damage the fetus in any way? I also want to let you know that six months back, I had an abortion as my child was very low. Kindly suggest me, is it safe to continue my pregnancy with all these problems?
output:
Emergency Contraceptive Pills (ECP) like Unwanted 72 are meant to prevent pregnancy, not end an ongoing pregnancy. There's currently no evidence that ECPs harm a developing fetus if they're unsuccessful in preventing a pregnancy. That being said, data on the impact of such pills on an ongoing pregnancy is limited.

Previous abortions typically don't lead to problems with future pregnancies unless there were complications during or after the procedure. However, it would be important to discuss with your obstetrician about your previous abortion for further evaluations.

The decision to continue with your current pregnancy involves considering several factors--the health of both you and the fetus, as well as social, psychological and financial readiness. Consultation with your doctor should help you make this decision. 

I'd recommend you get prenatal care as soon as possible to manage any risks. If you decide to proceed with the pregnancy, regular check-ups and ultrasounds will help monitor the development and health of your fetus.

input: Hi doctor,I am a 38-year-old male, 174 cm tall and weight is 73 kg. I have been having puffed up nipples since long and can feel slight hardness under the nipple surface. It is painless and there is no discharge. I suspect gynecomastia. I can provide you photographs. Need your advice on treatment.
output:
Your symptoms do sound consistent with gynecomastia, which is enlargement or swelling of breast tissue in males. Gynecomastia can be caused by an imbalance of hormones - estrogen and testosterone. A variety of medical conditions, medications (like steroids, anti-anxiety drugs, antibiotics), use of recreational drugs and alcohol can also cause it.

As per ethical guidelines, I won't be able to view your photographs, but I suggest you book a physical consultation with a doctor who can examine you properly. 

In terms of treatment options, they largely depend on the underlying cause:

1. If gynecomastia is due to certain medications or substances, discontinuation should solve the problem. Of course, discuss this first with your physician - don't stop prescribed meds without their approval.
2. If it's due to hormone fluctuation during puberty or aging process, it can go away on its own within six months to two years.
3. If a known medical condition is causing it, treating that will often resolve the issue.
4. In cases where it does not resolve spontaneously or if the cause cannot be addressed directly, treatment may involve medication or even surgical intervention like liposuction or mastectomy.

Remember, only a diagnosis from a trained professional can confirm your suspicions and point you towards appropriate treatment. Be sure to schedule an appointment and discuss your concerns.

input: Hello doctor,I am a 31-year-old female. My right eye is red and very sensitive to light. It is painful while I move the eyeballs. Center of the eye is paining with irritation.
output:
Your symptoms such as a red, painful eye with sensitivity to light and pain on moving the eyeball might suggest a condition called uveitis. This is an inflammation of the middle layer of the eye which includes the iris (colored part of the eye) and adjacent tissue, known collectively as the uvea.

However, these symptoms could also be related to other eye conditions such as conjunctivitis or glaucoma. It's very important that you seek immediate medical attention as some of these conditions can lead to permanent vision loss if not promptly treated. An ophthalmologist will use special instruments to examine your eye thoroughly and determine the cause of your symptoms. Please remember it's inappropriate and unsafe to self-diagnose or delay seeking professional help in this case.

For temporary relief, avoid bright lights and use sunglasses. But do not delay getting medical help.

input: Hi doctor,I did a test. I got my results that my erection transmitter is 2.99, testosterone is 4.459. vitamins E, K, and C are also slightly low. Could this be the reason I have premature ejaculation? At times, I also have a weak erection after one ejaculation. What should I take to treat these? Thanks.
output:
Premature ejaculation can have various causes. Although low testosterone levels might be a factor in premature ejaculation, your level seems to be within normal range if we assume 4.459 nmol/L (however it would still depend on the reference range used by the lab you used).

A condition called erectile dysfunction could be contributing to your weak erections, which may also relate to your transmitter level and hormonal profile that you mentioned. Other factors include psychological stress, excessive alcohol consumption, smoking, and underlying medical conditions like diabetes or heart disease.

Taking supplements to address vitamin deficiencies would be necessary, given that vitamins E, K and C play crucial roles in overall health, including reproductive and sexual health. However, they should be complemented with a balanced diet and healthy lifestyle habits.

Treatments for premature ejaculation and weak erections involve behavioral techniques, topical anesthetics, medications, and counseling. Medications such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors are generally prescribed. But every treatment has its pros and cons and must be tailored according to individual requirement.

However, I would strongly recommend discussing these results with your primary doctor or consulting a urologist or sex therapist, who will understand your case better and give the appropriate advice and treatment. Attempting self-medication without proper guidance may do more harm than good.

input: Hi doctor,I had a wart on my foot. I used highly acidic vinegar on it. It burnt and became worse. I used ancient oil on it and it swelled and now it looks like a big black-brown in color. It is not recovering. What should I do?
output:
You should stop using home remedies immediately and consult with a healthcare professional or dermatologist. You might have caused irritation or an infection by trying to treat the wart yourself, which could explain why it's swollen and discolored. 

For future reference, over-the-counter treatments containing salicylic acid are typically recommended for treating warts. However, if these don't work or if your wart becomes painful, starts bleeding, or changes in appearance, it's important to seek medical attention.

As of now, please keep the area clean and try not to touch or pick at the wart too much to avoid spreading it. Consult with a healthcare provider and they can provide treatments like cryotherapy (freezing), minor surgery, or prescription creams.
  
Remember, online advice is not a substitute for a clinical examination. Make sure to set up an appointment with your doctor as soon as you can.

input: Hello doctor,My wife was pregnant last year, but a miscarriage occurred. We consulted our gynecologist and he suggested we have a TORCH test. The result of TORCH was rubella IgG 270.30 and IgM 0.42, and CMV IgG 118.60 and IgM 0.26. We are unable to understand the report. Is this hike in the value of Rubella IgG and CMV IgG the cause of miscarriage? Please guide us.
output:
I'm sorry to hear that you've gone through this difficult time. The TORCH test checks for infections in the body. 

The rubella IgG test being positive (270.30) means that your wife has been exposed to, and created antibodies to fight off rubella virus at some point in her life. It does not necessarily mean a recent infection as these antibodies can stay in the body for a long-time after an infection is completely resolved.

A negative rubella IgM result (0.42) typically suggests that she most likely did not have a recent rubella infection. This is because IgM refers to the type of antibodies produced immediately when the body encounters a new infection.

Similarly, the high CMV IgG value (118.60) signifies past exposure to cytomegalovirus and antibody development by the immune system. A low or negative CMV IgM level (0.26) indicates no recent infection.

So, the high Rubella IgG and CMV IgG levels indicate previous rather than active infections. They do not necessarily indicate the cause of the miscarriage. Miscarriages can be caused by various factors such as chromosomal abnormalities, certain medical conditions in the mother, lifestyle factors etc. It would be best if you continue working with your doctor or a fertility specialist for further investigation into the cause and future prevention of miscarriages.

input: Hello doctor,I have recently chipped the top of one of my teeth off, it is quite sharp and hurts when I eat certain things (sugary things it seems). The part that came off was very thin but I am worried my tooth could become more sensitive and more could break off so I would really like to fix this in some way. What is the best way to go about this?
output:
You should definitely see a dentist to have this examined. It sounds like you may need dental bonding or a dental crown, depending on the size of the chip and the extent of damage to the tooth. The chipped tooth is noticeably more sensitive because the enamel, which protects against variations in temperatures, has been damaged.

Meanwhile, avoid eating hard food with the affected tooth; try not to consume very hot or cold foods/drinks if it gives too much sensitivity. Over-the-counter pain relievers can be used for temporary relief but using them for a long period of time isn't recommended without consulting with a healthcare professional. 

Remember it's better to get it treated sooner than later to prevent further complications.

input: Hi doctor,My daughter has skin lesions that started last year. They are on one side of the body. Initially, she got eczema kind small red rashes for which we applied Corticosteroid and later we observed whitish patches developing on those spots. Initially, the GP thought it could be tinea versicolor and suspected it could also be vitiligo.He referred us to a skin specialist and initially, the skin specialist thought it could be hypopigmentation and after a month, in the next appointment, she thought it could be vitiligo and started with Tacrolimus and Corticosteroid cream.Even before we started applying this Tacrolimus, we saw some repigmentation in some areas but it was slow repigmentation. We were confused as is it vitiligo or not and also as we are applying strong creams for a 6-year-old girl. Any long-term issues?We want to have a second opinion. I live in a city where it is very difficult to get skin specialist appointments. They give for every three to six months. Could you please help us in diagnosing the skin patches and treatment? I can send in the photos. I uploaded the photos:They all are on one side of the body (right side).On the hand, it started four months ago with a small white patch and gradually increased to the size and then we are seeing some repigmentation slowly very slowly to normal skin color.On the chest also, it started around the same time this year and not increased and stable.On the neck, it started early last month and it is not that whitish (like little less brownish).As said, the doctors diagnosed differently (postinflammatory hypopigmentation, tinea versicolor and finally vitiligo) so far and we are confused. Could you please look into this and help us?In all these spots, we applied Corticosteroid last year for eczema (hand, neck, chest and back) at the same spots where the white patches started and then grown big now. The only spot where we have not applied Corticosteroid but observed white patch is on the eye. We started seeing a white patch on the right eye as well from the last three weeks.
output:
As an AI developed by OpenAI, I'm able to provide general advice based on information, but it's important to remember that it cannot replace a face-to-face examination or substitute the expert advice of a dermatologist. When in doubt, you should always seek care from a healthcare professional.

Based on your daughter's history, she has eczema followed by hypopigmented patches and your doctors are considering vitiligo. Tacrolimus is used as a second-line treatment for moderate to severe eczema when other treatments have not worked well enough. It also has been found effective in repigmenting vitiligo patches especially in facial and neck lesions. The rate at which skin repigmentation occurs can be variable, with some people seeing changes within weeks, others may take several months to notice a difference.

Tacrolimus is generally safe but common side effects include skin burning or itching.

Without seeing the photos, I cannot definitively diagnose the condition. You should continue following up with your dermatologist, who knows your child's medical history best and can adjust treatments as needed. Remember that skin conditions often require trial and error before finding the most effective treatment, and this can take time.

If you're concerned about long-term potential side effects of these treatments, bringing this up with her specialist will allow them to possibly adjust the regimen and reassure you on safety and efficacy profiles of these medications.

Last but not least, more immediate access to specialist care using telemedicine might be an option -

input: Hello doctor,My 6-year-old child is having asthma and is coughing in the night. He uses a nebulizer. I am giving him normal saline. Please help.
output:
Managing asthma in children can be challenging. Your use of a nebulizer is a good step, however instead of normal saline, asthma usually needs to be treated with bronchodilators (like albuterol) or corticosteroids which relax and open up the airways. These medications are often prescribed by a doctor.

It's also quite important that you consult with a pediatrician if your son's coughing continues despite using the nebulizer. The coughing spells during the night could indicate poor control of his asthma symptoms, and his treatment may need adjustments. Frequent medication reviews are essential for anyone with asthma, especially children given their varying growth rates and changing environments (e.g school, sports, etc). 

Nonetheless, continue ensuring he avoids triggers such as allergens, infections, exercise, changes in weather, and others that could potentially worsen his asthma.

Remember, this advice is based on the limited information provided and you should urgently take him for a proper medical evaluation.

input: Hi doctor,I have good health with occasional atrial fibrillation. Last night, I had a flare up of atrial fibrillation and my resting heart rate was 130 beats per minute which happened a few hours ago. My normal resting heart rate is 70 beats per minute. I am taking Magnesium and Potassium.
output:
It sounds like you are experiencing an episode of rapid heart rate associated with your atrial fibrillation (AFib). Although magnesium and potassium can help maintain heart health, they might not be sufficient to control AFib episodes when they occur. 

Firstly, please ensure that the elevated heart rate episode has resolved. If it still persists or if you experience symptoms such as chest pain, extreme shortness of breath, fainting, or severe fatigue, seek immediate medical care.

Secondly, you should arrange a visit with your cardiologist or primary care physician as soon as possible. They may want to readjust your treatment plan which could mean adding additional medications to help manage your heart rate or prevent these episodes. Options include beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, digoxin or possibly antiarrhythmic drugs depending on your overall health condition. 

Moreover, lifestyle modifications such as limiting caffeine and alcohol, quitting smoking, maintaining a healthy weight, reducing stress and regular exercise may also help in controlling AFib.

Remember this advice is intended to be general in nature, and specific causes may require different treatments. Always consult with your healthcare provider about any symptoms or concerns.

input: Hi doctor,I had a protein shake for three weeks, around five scoops a day. Since then I get a pulsation in my buttocks and legs. This also causes dizziness most of the time. If I eat too much this problem gets worse. Drinking a lot of water helps but it is not sorting out the problem. I was advised to see a toxicologist for this problem as someone said to me that it could have given me protein toxicity.Anything I eat with high protein like chicken, lamb, fish, etc., makes this problem go worse. I also tried to stop eating that for a bit. It did help a little but again it did not sort out the problem. I have tried taking Detox as well.I am suffering through this problem for the last one year. I have been running around my gp. I am really fed up with this problem. All blood tests were done and everything normal. I have also tried taking vitamin C it did help a lot. But I experienced some pains around my kidney area so I stopped taking that too. This shake has definitely done something to me and nothing was helpful. I have tried a lot to find a toxicologist because I think who is the right person to help me with this issue. Could you please suggest me the correct medication for this problem as it is messing me up and stopping me from work as well? Please help.
output:
I'm really sorry to hear you're experiencing these issues. It sounds quite complex and without the complete medical history and physical examination, it's difficult for me to provide specific advice. However, overconsumption of protein can affect people differently. Some people might develop kidney stones, others might experience digestive problems; while some symptoms might not be directly related to protein toxicity at all.

Your description suggests that your high consumption of protein shakes in the past might have disrupted your body's metabolic balance. Despite this situation being quite rare, high intakes of protein in short periods might put stress on liver and kidneys, resulting in increased synthesis of urea or even nephrolithiasis (kidney stones). Symptoms like pain around the kidney area, dizziness and pulsation sensation could potentially relate to those conditions. 

Keep in mind though, that nutrient imbalance regarding other minerals and vitamins is also possible when consuming large amounts of single-nutrient products like protein powder.

You're right in thinking a toxicologist may help if this is indeed due to protein toxicity - but often this will be ruled out by a thorough medical assessment first by a primary care doctor who might redirect you to other specialists such as a nephrologist (kidney specialist) or a neurologist depending on the symptoms. 

In terms of immediate steps and medications: do continue keeping yourself well hydrated as this can help protect your kidneys. Avoiding high protein foods and supplement until further investigations are sensible precautions. In addition to this, anal

input: Hi doctor,I have low levels of vitamin B12. I have to take vitamin B12. Every time, when I take them, I get a terrible spine pain, and I feel very tired. Please help.
output:
I'm sorry to hear you're feeling this way. It's unusual for vitamin B12 to cause spine pain and fatigue, as it usually helps with energy levels and nerve function. However, each person can react differently to medications or supplements.

Spine pain could stem from a variety of different conditions unrelated to vitamin B12 intake, including musculoskeletal issues, nerve-related problems, or even stress. Fatigue is a very general symptom that can be associated with many medical conditions.

First, we should validate if the vitamin B12 supplement really causes these symptoms, try not taking it for some days and check if the symptoms persist. 

To better evaluate your condition, I would recommend booking an appointment with a healthcare provider who can take a comprehensive health history, conduct a physical exam, and potentially order more tests based on their initial findings. They will be able to better pinpoint what might be causing your discomfort and provide appropriate treatment options.

In the meantime, focus on maintaining a balanced diet rich in Vitamin B12 such as fortified cereals, lean meat, fish, dairy products, and eggs.

Remember, this advice is intended to be general in nature, consult with a healthcare provider before making changes to your health regimen.

input: Hi doctor,I am now seven weeks pregnant. The issue is my hCG at 18 DPO was 664, and then at 22 DPO was 2002, and then a week after the last measure, it was 3900 (different lab). It has not doubled properly. I had a scan at 6 weeks 3 days approx. and fetus measuring around 5 mm with HR of 120, was told its good and measured 6 weeks. Do I still have a chance at a normal pregnancy or will I miscarry due to hCG not doubling as they should?
output:
While it's true that in early pregnancy, hCG normally doubles every 48 to 72 hours, once the levels reach about 6,000 mIU/ml, the doubling time slows down and can even take 4 days. Don't focus exclusively on the numbers. A normal rise in hCG may not necessarily indicate a healthy pregnancy, and a lower rise does not automatically mean a problem – there is a wide range of normal hCG levels.

The fetal heart rate of 120 beats per minute at around 6 weeks is within the normal range, which is usually anywhere from 90-110 bpm at 5-6 weeks and for 6-7 weeks could be anywhere between 110 and 130 bpm. Also, the fetus measuring 5 mm at approximately 6 weeks 3 days seems good.

It's understandable if you're feeling anxious about these results, but it's best to discuss your concerns with your doctor who will interpret your lab results according to specific details about your health status and history. Ultrasounds are generally a more accurate assessment of a viable pregnancy than hCG measurements alone. Remember, the numbers can vary widely and this is only a single measurement. Your healthcare provider will be able to help determine what implications, if any, the slower increase has for your pregnancy.

input: Hello doctor,I have pain and sometimes heavy bleeding during or after sex and I can only do certain positions where I can tolerate the pain. I have already been tested and I am negative for STDs. I also have really heavy periods to the point that I cannot wear tampons because they do not work. What is going on with me?
output:
I'm sorry to hear you're experiencing these symptoms. While I can't diagnose you over the internet, your symptoms might suggest a condition known as endometriosis. Endometriosis is a disease in which tissue similar to the lining inside the uterus (called “the endometrium”), is found outside the uterus, where it induces a chronic inflammatory reaction that may result in scar tissue. It's common among women in their 30s and 40s but can occur at any age. Symptoms vary, some women have no symptoms at all, whereas others might have severe pain and heavy bleeding.

Other possibilities could include uterine fibroids or polyps, both of which are non-cancerous growths that can cause heavy bleeding and pain. Pelvic inflammatory disease could also cause this symptom, although you said you tested negative for STDs, still, it can sometimes occur due to normal bacteria in your vagina.

It is very important that you seek out medical attention to receive an accurate diagnosis. Always make sure to tell your healthcare provider about all of your symptoms so they can choose the most appropriate diagnostic tests. This will likely involve a pelvic exam and possibly imaging studies like ultrasound or MRI. In some cases, a surgical procedure like a laparoscopy might even be necessary for a definitive diagnosis. Treatment will depend on the exact cause and severity of your symptoms, but it usually involves medication such as hormonal treatments or pain relievers and the recommendation to do physiotherapy, physical exercises

Since you're not on any medications that could potentially be causing these symptoms, I suggest you to make an appointment with a sleep specialist for further evaluation. The specialist might recommend a sleep study to better understand your sleeping patterns and identify any potential issues.

These conditions often result from blunt trauma and can cause a hard lump to form.

The fact that you are able to move your arm and pick things up without pain is generally a good sign; it could mean that there isn't any fracture or significant injury. However, if the lump persists or increases in size, becomes warm, red or very painful, these might be signs of infection or another serious complication, which require immediate medical attention.

input: Hi doctor,I went for an HIV test at six weeks after low-risk exposure and get false positive. At eight weeks both fourth generation and HIV RNA PCR are negative. At 9 and 10 weeks rapid test is negative. At 12 weeks HIV RNA PCR is negative. Is it conclusive? My doctor told me no need for further tests.
output:
Based on your testing and results, it does seem that you are very likely negative for HIV. The initial false positive result you received could have been due to a variety of reasons, including errors in the test itself or other factors such as recent vaccinations or various medical conditions. Subsequent tests at 8 weeks with 4th generation and HIV RNA PCR, both of which are highly accurate, came back negative, further implying that you do not have HIV.

Afterwards, two rapid tests at 9 and 10 weeks were also negative. Your presumed final test, an HIV RNA PCR at 12 weeks, was likewise negative.

HIV testing guidelines from many expert institutions, including the CDC, recommend retesting at three months (or 12 weeks) post-exposure for conclusive results, which is where you are currently at. Given the number of negative results from different types of tests over multiple intervals, it appears that your doctor is following these guidelines and is confident about the reliability of your results. That's why your doctor mentioned there's no need for further testing. 

However, should any new symptoms arise, or should you engage in high-risk behaviors again, then testing becomes advisable. But based on this assessment, you would appear to be HIV-negative. Please continue practicing safe behaviors to ensure it stays this way!

Don't use any over-the-counter eye medications without the direction of your doctor.

input: Hello doctor,I want to know how bad or serious is type II (Galassi) arachnoid cyst located on the left temporal lobe? No strong pain, only a minor one when my heart pounds fast. But I have to pay attention in order to feel it, it is very subtle. I am currently taking mild anti-stress natural medication and a quarter tablet of Betaloc-ZOK 50 mg in the evening to lower my pulse. I have done my MRI also.
output:
Arachnoid cysts are relatively common and are often harmless, not causing any symptoms or requiring treatment. However, whether a type II (Galassi) arachnoid cyst located on the left temporal lobe can cause psychiatric symptoms, such as mood fluctuations, depression and panic attacks, is still controversial in scientific literature. 

In some cases, research has shown that cysts like this situated near areas of the brain involved in emotion regulation (like the temporal lobes) could, theoretically, interfere with these functions and result in relevant symptoms. However, other studies have found no strong association between arachnoid cysts and psychiatric disorders.

What seems to be agreed upon by most researchers is that when an arachnoid cyst causes symptoms due to its size, location, or the pressure it places on nearby structures, it's primarily neurological symptoms - like headaches, seizures, focal neurological deficits, etc.

Depression, anxiety, and panic attacks can be influenced by numerous factors, including recent life stressors like you've mentioned—losing a father and changes in your life.

Mild pain associated with increased heart rate may not necessarily be related to the cyst but should be evaluated nonetheless.

You're already under treatment for your concerns, which is good. Keep conversing with your doctor about monitoring your symptoms and adjusting treatment as necessary. Therapies like cognitive-behavioral approaches also work well for managing stressors and mitigating depressive/anxiety symptomology.

input: Hello doctor,I see a black dot that has not gone away since yesterday does not move when I rub my eye or blink. It is more significant than floaters I usually see. It seems to move when I jiggle my eye a lot and moves slowly down after I shake my eye.
output:
It sounds like you might be experiencing what's known as a "floater." Floaters can appear as black dots, lines, or cobwebs in your field of vision. They usually move when your eyes move and kind of drift away when you try to directly look at them. Though typically not harmful and seen as normal with ageing, a sudden increase in floaters, especially if accompanied by light flashes or peripheral vision loss, could indicate a retinal detachment which is medical emergency.

However, since the floater you've described seems more significant than usual to you, it would also be prudent to have this checked out by an optometrist or ophthalmologist to ensure there isn't a problem such as Retinal Detachment, Optic Neuritis, Macular Hole, etc. It's important not to panic though, as it very well may be benign, but only a professional will be able to give a proper assessment.

Please seek immediate medial care for vision changes.

input: Hi doctor,Can the adult palate narrow or change shape due to age or stress or hormonal factors?
output:
The shape of the adult palate is generally considered to be quite stable and does not typically change due to aging, stress or hormonal factors. Once an individual has reached full maturity, their skeletal structure, including the jaw and palate, usually remains relatively consistent unless impacted by trauma, disease such as cancer or specific conditions that affect bone density such as osteoporosis.

However, what can affect the perception of changes in oral cavity or palate could actually be other factors. For example, loss of teeth without proper prosthetic replacement can lead to bone resorption over time, changing the feel and function within the mouth. Oral diseases, mucosal issues and temporomandibular disorders (issues with the jaw joint) could potentially give a feeling of change or narrowing in the oral cavity. Problems with your sinuses and allergies can also cause discomfort and even facial changes if they lead to chronic inflammation.

Furthermore, chronic stress can theoretically influence oral health indirectly through neglect of hygiene, poor diet or parafunctional habits like teeth grinding which may over time contribute to changes in the mouth environment but it wouldn't directly change or narrow the palate itself.

If you are experiencing any discomfort, changes in speech, eating or breathing, make sure you discuss these with your healthcare provider to rule out serious conditions and find the appropriate treatment. It's always best to get checked out if you notice anything out of the ordinary.

input: Hi doctor,I have a weird rash on my foot. That has been persistently itchy, peeling and building. It does not burn, but it is unappetizing to look at. I do take Lyderm for it. It seems to stop the itching, but not the spreading of the rash. It has been on my leg for a year now. Please help.

Anti-fungal medication could potentially help for a fungal infection. In the case of eczema or psoriasis, steroid creams (like Lyderm you've been using) often help with itching and inflammation but do not necessarily get rid of the problem entirely.

Since you mentioned that this has been going on for a year now, you need to schedule an appointment with a dermatologist who can further assess the situation. You would likely require a stronger prescription medication or a different course of treatment than what you're currently utilizing.

output:
If you are actively trying to conceive, it's natural to look for any symptoms that may indicate pregnancy. However, a negative pregnancy test might be an accurate indicator that you're not pregnant right now. Most home pregnancy tests are pretty reliable (about 97% of the time when used correctly). Sometimes, though, you could get a false negative if you took the test too soon — it's usually best to wait until after your missed period.

The symptoms you have described can indeed sometimes be related to early stages of pregnancy such as implantation spotting, increased urination etc., but they can also be because of hormonal changes, stress, lifestyle changes and alterations in metabolism or diet. 

Deviry contains Medroxyprogesterone which is a synthetic form of progesterone. It is typically used to regulate periods, particularly in conditions where irregular menstrual cycles occur. If you were pregnant, this medication could potentially cause harm to the baby, so it should ideally not be taken without first confirming whether or not you're pregnant. However, it won't prevent ovulation or affect your chances of becoming pregnant in upcoming cycles, once you stop taking it. 

Continue communicating with your doctor about these symptoms and your concerns as You know your body better than anyone, so if you still feel like something's off, I would suggest seeing your doctor again or consider getting a blood test to check the hCG levels to confirm pregnancy.

input: Hi doctor, My last exposure was protected but I am not sure about whether the vaginal fluid touched or not since I was drunk that time. After that, I went to an HIV specialist and he suggested me HIV DNA PCR test at 66 days period. The result is HIV 1 not detected.Then at 83 days, tridot rapid test is negative. 88-day tridot rapid test negative. 93-day tridot non-reactive. 99-day tridot (immuno filtration) antibodies 1 and 2 nonreactive. Then I took HbsAg, HCV, VRD total all are non-reactive.Is it enough for HIV testing? Is DNA PCR at 66 days (in window ) period useful? Is tridot test useful or not?In the window period time, I used fever tablets, antibiotics, and Levocetirizine many days. Will it affect my window period? Please give me brief information. I have a family and a child. Can I have sex with my wife without protection? Next test needed or not?
output:
Based on your description, you have had several negative tests, including HIV DNA PCR and antibody tests, for a prolonged period after the potential exposure, each showing a negative result. This is very reassuring; it strongly suggests that you did not acquire HIV from this encounter.

The HIV DNA PCR test can typically detect HIV about 2-3 weeks after infection and is more than 99% accurate at ruling out infection after 4 weeks or longer since the exposure.

The Tri-Dot Rapid Test can reliably detect infections approximately 3 to 12 weeks (21 to 84 days) following exposure. A negative test result at 99 days post-exposure implies non-infection with HIV unless there has been a risk event in the meantime.

While medications like antibiotics and antipyretics won't affect the results of these tests, certain factors such as recent infection, other concurrent medical conditions, or treatment with Post-Exposure Prophylaxis, could lengthen the window period for an HIV test.

However, considering your negative tests were performed well beyond the standard "window" period, you are most likely HIV negative. Therefore, according to the test outcomes you are sharing, sexual intercourse without protection should pose no risks related to HIV transmission to your spouse based on this encounter. It would also seem unlikely that further HIV testing related to this incident would be necessary.

input: Hi,I am approaching you since I am concerned about a situation regarding which I am very embarrassed. I am a 43 year old female. I am normally healthy. I am 178cm tall and I weigh 75kg. Around 9-12 months ago, I started to suffer from anal itching.It is rather intense at night, after passing stools and during/after having intercourse or anal masturbation.I also have few lumps on my anal ring that seem to grow outside of my anal opening as an extended piece of flesh.They are very sensitive but they are odd and it really troubles me.I fear that my problem started as a result of anal masturbation and anal sex.I feel very ashamed to say this. I was using anal toys and hand and I am afraid that during these years I myself  have created problems to my health and I do not know how to fix it.I do not have constipation and my stool is normal.I pass motion once a day and I have no abdominal pain while passing stools.Sometimes when I have anal sex I start bleeding from my rectum for a few seconds and then it stops.It does not bleed when I pass stools or any other time.I have not attained menopause even though my period seems to be every 6-7 weeks these days.I would appreciate if you can help me understand how to treat this issue and what should I do (i.e, special diet, special creams, instructions on how to clean the area etc.)Help me please, I am looking for a very discreet way to handle my situation since I am too concerned about talking with my spouse.
output:
From your symptoms, it's likely that you have developed a condition called hemorrhoids. Hemorrhoids are swollen veins in the lower part of the anus and rectum that often enlarge and protrude externally during anal sex or masturbation due to increased pressure. Some common symptoms include bleeding during bowel movements as well as itching and discomfort.

Because they can prolapse, or extend outside of the anal opening, hemorrhoids resemble fleshy growths and might be what you're feeling. Don't worry, this is quite common and there's no need for embarrassment. Hemorrhoids aren't dangerous, but they can cause significant discomfort.

In terms of management and reduction of symptoms:

1. High-Fiber Diet: Eating foods rich in dietary fiber can help make stools softer and easier to pass, reducing the urge to strain, which can potentially exacerbate hemorrhoids.

2. Over-the-Counter Creams and Aids: Topical creams or ointments containing hydrocortisone can provide relief, as can pads containing witch hazel or numbing agents.

3. Soak Regularly in Warm Water: A sitz bath, where only the hips and buttocks are soaked in warm water, can help relieve pain and itching from hemorrhoids.

4. Cold Compresses: Applying ice or cold packs on the affected area can reduce swelling.

5. Analgesics: Non-prescription pain relievers can be used to manage discomfort.

Care when cleaning the area after a bowel movement is essential

input: Hello doctor,I had unprotected sex on my infertile day, but I was quite scared, so I took post-pill a week later I had another unprotected sex this time in my fertile days but did not receive the post-pill immediately next day I saw a slight spotting which prompted me into taking the emergency pill. Now a week later, I have been bleeding for two days. I hope this is not a sign of pregnancy. Please help me understand it better.
output:
The symptoms you're describing are most likely due to the emergency contraceptive pill, also known as the "morning-after" pill. These medications can cause side effects like spotting or irregular bleeding, nausea, and abdominal pain.

When taken within 72 hours (and ideally within 24 hours) after unprotected sex, emergency contraceptives like Plan B are highly effective in preventing pregnancy. That said, they do not offer any protection against pregnancy from subsequent episodes of unprotected sex happening after the pill is taken.

If you have been sexually active on your fertile days without using contraception, there's a chance you could become pregnant regardless of whether you've taken an emergency contraceptive earlier in your cycle. Taking the morning-after pill a week before does not provide continuous protection.

The bleeding that you're experiencing now could be withdrawal bleeding triggered by the emergency contraceptive, although it's also possible that it could be implantation bleeding, which sometimes occurs when a fertilized egg implants into the uterus.

I would advise taking a home pregnancy test if you miss your next period or if the bleeding doesn't seem normal for you, just to confirm whether or not you're pregnant.

Also remember that no method of birth control is 100% perfect at preventing pregnancy—except for abstinence—and emergency contraception should not be used as a regular form of contraception. It is advisable to use regular contraception such as condoms, the pill, IUDs etc; speak with your healthcare provider about what options might work best for you.

input: Hello doctor,I have been getting sores and things that look like blood blisters in my mouth for around six months. I had a swab test and blood work was done to rule out HSV. It came back negative. However, there is still a chance it could be HSV as it takes three to six months to show up in your blood. I am concerned. This is completely out of the normal for me. I do not smoke, drink moderately a few times a week, eat healthily and exercise. Any ideas? Would oral or genital herpes look like this in the mouth? Could it be mouth cancer?
output:
Oral or genital herpes in the mouth can indeed cause sores and blisters, but if your tests came back negative for HSV then it's less likely. It's true that sometimes HSV doesn't show up in tests until several months after infection, but symptoms usually appear within 2 to 12 days of transmission. Furthermore, herpes outbreaks generally heal on their own within a week or two.

Your symptoms have been persisting for long enough time to be inconsistent with typical presentations of herpes simplex virus. Although herpes sores look like blood blisters, they are generally painful and reappear periodically at the same site of initial infection.

Mouth cancer also presents with sores, semi-permanent ulcers or lumps, and these do not heal easily over time, however, these are often associated with other signs such as unexplained bleeding, numbness, difficulty swallowing or moving the jaw.

There are many possible causes besides HSV and mouth cancer that could lead to oral lesions: stress or certain vitamin deficiencies; autoimmune diseases, such as Behcet’s disease or lupus; oral thrush caused by a yeast (Candida) infection; Hand Foot Mouth Disease; Oral Lichen Planus etc.

Although your concern is understandable, immediately jumping to the conclusion of cancer may not be appropriate without further testing. You should return to your doctor and express your ongoing concerns. They may recommend you to a specialist who can look into more in-depth possibilities based on your symptoms and personal medical history. Please do

input: Hello doctor,Can an echocardiogram and ECG diagnose restrictive cardiomyopathy because I have had like three of them but I am still confused? All I have is just some premature ventricular contractions.
output:
As a type of noninvasive test, an echocardiogram can be used to help diagnose restrictive cardiomyopathy. It works by using ultrasound waves to create pictures of the heart and its functioning. This allows doctors to observe the size and shape of your heart and its chambers, measure how well your heart is functioning and pumping blood, identify areas of poor blood flow and heart muscle that's not contracting normally, as well as problems with the valves. 

However, for restrictive cardiomyopathy, your doctor may have difficulty distinguishing it from constrictive pericarditis on an echocardiogram. He or she might need to use additional imaging tests such as cardiac MRI or CT scan.

Electrocardiogram (ECG) is also useful in diagnosing this condition but not specific. The ECG shows abnormal heart rhythms, which are often seen in people with restrictive cardiomyopathy.

Premature ventricular contractions could be associated with various cardiac conditions, not specifically restrictive cardiomyopathy. They happen when the ventricles of the heart beat out of rhythm or prematurely. This can sometimes feel like a fluttering or skipped heartbeat.

Depending on the results of these tests and related symptoms, your doctor can better determine whether you have restrictive cardiomyopathy or another type of heart disease. If there is still confusion after the aforementioned tests, further diagnostic methods including coronary angiography, cardiac catheterization, or even biopsy of heart tissue may be required.
  
You should continue your conversation

input: Hello Doctor,My son is 2 and a half years old and has very jagged (crescent-shaped) front teeth. I have brought him to two dentists.One said it appeared to be an enamel deficiency and the other said it was due to him grinding his teeth. I have never seen or heard him grind.
output:
As a doctor interpreting your situation, the discrepancy in diagnosis between the two dentists could be due to different interpretations of the signs and symptom presentation. 

Dental enamel hypoplasia or enamel deficiency may indeed present as jagged or irregular tooth surfaces, usually caused by problems during the formation of teeth. This condition is typically a developmental issue that occurs when teeth are still forming and can result from various causes including nutritional deficiencies, premature birth, infections etc.

On the other hand, bruxism (teeth grinding) can also cause wearing down of the teeth leading to abnormal shapes. It often happens at night during sleep, which makes it hard for parents to notice. Some signs of bruxism besides wear on the teeth include complaints about facial pain, headaches, especially in the morning, or increased tooth sensitivity.

It would be appropriate to seek further consultation with a pediatric dentist for a more definitive evaluation. A thorough clinical examination along with knowing any associated symptoms or family history can help determine the main cause behind your son's jagged, crescent-shaped front teeth.

input: Hello doctor,I am currently on 40 mg of Fluoxetine. For the past four days, I was put up from 30 mg to 40 mg as my 20 mg stopped working after three years. While on the 30 mg, my symptoms got better for a couple weeks and then I went back down to where I was, in the beginning, feeling extremely depressed, anxious and completely awful. I was wondering why this happened?
output:
It's not uncommon for people to experience what you're going through. This phenomenon, known as antidepressant tolerance — occurs when the brain's capacity to respond to an antidepressant diminishes over time. This can happen for a variety of reasons:

1) The dosage may need adjusting: As your body adjusts to the medication, it might become less effective at the same dose. It is possible that increasing the dose of Fluoxetine from 30 mg to 40 mg might have a more pronounced effect.

2) Individual biochemistry and genetic differences: People metabolize medicines at different rates, based on their individual biochemistry and genetic makeup. Certain individuals may develop resistance or sensitivity to a drug more quickly than others.

3) Changes in the body: With prolonged usage, your body might start perceiving the medication as a foreign substance and increase efforts to remove it, making the drug less effective.

4) Severity or change in symptoms: Sometimes, depression can manifest in cycles, where there are periodical increases in intensity. During these 'lows', it might feel like your medication isn't working.

Remember, though, that all patients react differently to medications, and what works well for one person may not work as well for another. Please consult with your physician or psychiatrist about the lack of effectiveness. They can evaluate your symptoms again and might propose other treatments which could include changing medication, augmenting with another medication, psychotherapy, lifestyle changes etc. Also, don't hesitate to reach out if you're

I got an ECG, x-ray, CBC and HbA1c done today. I am worried about my ECG being abnormal. I am scared that there could be something wrong and I have no other symptoms besides shortness of breath.
output:
As a doctor, I would first want to reassure you that feeling fluttering in the chest can sometimes be due to things like stress or caffeine, and may not necessarily indicate a heart problem. However, it's good you've taken initiative to get an ECG along with other tests.

It is impossible for me to interpret your results without seeing them. For this reason, please refer to your primary care provider or a cardiologist who can properly evaluate your results taking into account your personal history and clinical examination which could provide more information about your condition. 

If your shortness of breath persists or if you develop other symptoms such as chest pain, lightheadedness, fainting, or rapid and irregular heartbeat, seek immediate medical attention.

input: Hello doctor,I would like an opinion on my X-ray if it shows any signs of a stress fracture in the heel. I took up running and increased it too fast.It hurts to walk on the sides of the heel. Pressing on either side of the heel hurts a lot. There is swelling but no bruising.The swelling is decreasing now but the pain is not. I want to know what I am dealing with. I cannot see the GP for another week or so.
output:
As an AI, I am unable to physically examine or see your X-ray images which makes giving a definitive answer impossible. However, based on the symptoms you've described, your issue might be consistent with plantar fasciitis or a stress fracture of the heel. The pain and swelling could suggest inflammation. A stress fracture would typically come with such symptoms but also is usually accompanied by localized sharp pain and tenderness when touched. It's best to avoid any weight-bearing activities until you can have it properly diagnosed.

Please note that both of these conditions require professional medical diagnosis. Additionally, treating these conditions without a proper plan can lead to chronic issues.

I recommend seeing a healthcare professional as soon as possible to get appropriate treatment before complications arise. You may need to be referred to a radiologist to properly evaluate your x-ray. Remember this advice does not substitute for a professional medical opinion.

input: Hi doctor,I am a 28-year-old female. I have always had a small, raised, symmetrical mole on the right side of my chin. It has always been very benign and had a hair growing out of it that I consistently plucked. About two weeks ago, I noticed a small, shiny whiteish bump on the mole and called my dermatologist. Because of the holidays, I could not get an appointment anytime soon and still have another week to wait. Over the last couple of days, the mole has gotten bigger though it has stayed symmetrical and is still slightly smaller than a pencil eraser. It is slightly more raised and it stings to touch. I also realized that it has been a month or two since I had to pluck any hair. None has grown.I have had a zit on this mole a couple times but this does not really look like the previous moles. I am conscious it could be another more severe zit or maybe a cyst but I am very nervous that it is cancer. I had a couple of moles removed in childhood that were not quite suspicious but that the dermatologist removed just to be safe. My mother has had several basal cell cancers removed. I spent many summers in my youth outside and am worried that this is melanoma or nodular melanoma even though it is not dark.
output:
Though it's understandable that you're feeling worried, especially considering your family history and the changes in your mole over a short period of time, please remember that not all changes to moles are due to cancer. It could indeed be related an ingrown hair, a pimple, cyst or benign growth.

However, any changes to moles — including changes in size, color, shape or sensation (bleeding, itchiness or tenderness) — should be checked as soon as possible by a healthcare professional proficient in assessing skin lesions. While melanoma usually presents as a dark, asymmetrical lesion, certain types, like amelanotic melanoma, can appear pink or even white.

A definitive diagnosis can only be made after appropriate tests, such as a skin biopsy done by your dermatologist. I would urge you not to panic but do stress the urgency when contacting your doctor's office again, considering the changes you've seen. Avoid touching or messing with it further until you see a health professional.

input: Hello doctor,I am a 27-year-old female. I am experiencing sharp pain in the area below my left breast and near the rib cage. Could it be something serious?
output:
As a physician, without physically examining you it's hard to say definitively what could be causing the pain. However, various conditions can lead to similar symptoms including musculoskeletal strains, gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), heart diseases, such as angina or even panic attack or anxiety. If it is related to a scary cause like heart disease, there would usually be other serious symptoms like shortness of breath, jaw pain, arm pain and sweating.

If this sharp pain persists, becomes more severe or frequently occurs, I would recommend you seek medical attention immediately to get a proper diagnosis. Please don't delay if you experience any other symptoms like nausea, vomiting, sweating or shortness of breath along with the pain.

input: Hello doctor,I began presenting last fall with some chronic fatigue. The initial blood work showed low iron saturation without anemia. I have attached reports of the same. There were other endocrine-related findings as well. In the course of various endocrine-related treatments and corresponding blood work, I began iron supplementation in the form of ferrous sulfate 143 mg daily. I began this before the blood work was done. So, you can see that that the levels have increased. Subsequent testing, a month later, showed a decline despite continuing treatment. Most recently, you can see that the levels are back up. Note that the ferritin levels began a bit low around 27 ng/mL and had increased to 30 ng/mL.I have received a wide range of conflicting advice about whether low iron levels in the absence of anemia can cause fatigue. I have also received a range of conflicting advice about whether to continue iron supplementation. One doctor told me to continue taking the iron until the ferritin is up around 50 or so. Another said that would be unnecessary and to discontinue it and wait for three months to re-measure the blood work. It is all quite puzzling. Please help me to understand iron\s role, if any, in fatigue in the absence of anemia. And help me to then understand the rationale for treatment or lack thereof. And finally, please give me some sense of when iron toxicity emerges in terms of blood work measurements and at what frequency one needs to check the iron levels during any supplementation.
output:
Iron plays a critical role in transporting oxygen to all parts of the body via hemoglobin in the red blood cells. It also functions in supporting your muscle metabolism and healthy connective tissues, as well as being necessary for physical growth, neurological development, cellular functioning, and synthesis of some hormones.

Even without anemia, iron deficiency could cause fatigue. This may be due to its role in metabolic processes such as energy production, DNA synthesis, and cell function, all of which if impaired, can lead to feelings of tiredness or exhaustion. However, currently the evidence regarding this is still inconclusive with some studies suggesting a link while others don't.

As for supplementation, it's a balance between correcting iron deficiency and avoiding toxicity. Ferritin levels above 200 ng/mL for women and 300 ng/mL for men might raise suspicions about iron overload. Iron overdose can lead to life-threatening cardiogenic shock, liver failure, and coagulopathy.

Your doctor’s suggestion to target around 50 ng/ml ferritin level might be a safe zone to ensure optimal function without risking toxicity though there are variations to these values based on individual responses and thresholds. 

Iron levels should be monitored periodically during treatment to avoid both shortages and excess. The frequency varies depending upon individuals and severity of their deficiency. For those taking supplements, rechecking every few months (as per your doctor's advice) seems reasonable. 

Regarding conflicting advice, you may want consult with a hematologist who specializes in conditions involving the blood including iron

input: Hello doctor,I am suffering from a migraine for the past five years. I took Sibelium for four years, but it caused me to put on so much weight. So, I stopped taking it. Now, I have a migraine again. What should I do?
output:
It seems you're experiencing a recurrent migraine which used to be controlled by Sibelium (Flunarizine). Given your concern about the weight gain associated with this medication, I would recommend scheduling an appointment with either your primary care physician or a neurologist for further evaluation and discussion of alternative treatments.

There are a number of other prophylactic medications that can be used in the management of migraines such as propranolol, amitriptyline, topiramate, valproate or Botox injections. Non-pharmacological interventions like cognitive behavioral therapy, biofeedback, and relaxation techniques can also be beneficial for some people.

In terms of acute treatment of migraines, NSAIDs, triptans, and antiemetics are commonly used. Newer classes of medication - CGRP inhibitors - have also shown promise in preventing migraines, and could be considered based on the severity of your condition and under medical guidance.

Apart from medications, lifestyle modifications including regular sleep patterns, hydration, balanced diet, and stress management play a pivotal role in managing migraines. It's important to discuss these options with your doctor to find the best approach for you. And remember, any change of treatment should be done under medical supervision.

input: Hello doctor,I have just had a sinus lift graft and implants placed. The dentist has prescribed 500 mg of Levofloxacin every 12 hours for 10 days, plus Augmentin, plus Ibuprofen and Dexamethasone. My question is whether the Levofloxacin is necessary and why is it such a high dose? I have read it should not be taken with Ibuprofen and Dexamethasone. My dentist said it is fine, but I am very worried as I have heard this antibiotic is very toxic. What is your advice concerning this issue, please?
output:
Your dentist has prescribed you Levofloxacin, which is a broad-spectrum antibiotic used to treat a wide variety of bacterial infections. Typically, its use in dental procedures such as a sinus lift graft and implant placement is to prevent any possible infection post-procedure.

The dose and duration seem about right for such a procedure. Still, depending on your body weight, overall health condition and susceptibility to infections, the prescriptions can vary. This is only from a general perspective, and specific clinical cases may require different approaches.

Concerning interactions between Levofloxacin, ibuprofen and Dexamethasone, it's true that there is some potential for interaction but not significant enough to cause concern in most cases. However, since Levofloxacin may increase the risk of tendinitis and tendon rupture, concurrent administration of corticosteroids like dexamethasone can potentially exacerbate this risk.

Levofloxacin does have side effects, with a small percentage of patients experiencing more severe reactions. All antibiotics can potentially be toxic if taken incorrectly or if the patient has an unusual reaction, but they are generally safe when used as directed by a healthcare professional.

Given your concerns, I'd advise discussing them further with your dentist. They are familiar with your specific situation and would be best suited to address your questions comprehensively. You have every right to understand why certain medications are being recommended for you and what risks they pose.

If the concern persists or if you experience any unexpected symptoms,

input: Hello doctor,I was given Medroxyprogesterone. Today is my last day but I have not got my period. My doctor suggested PCOS. What shall I do next?
output: If your doctor prescribed Medroxyprogesterone and you still haven't started your period after the medication course, I'd recommend contacting your healthcare provider to discuss this. It's possible that it may take a few more days for your period to start, but it's important to update them about your situation. If you have Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS), this condition can cause irregular menstruation or even lack of menstruation among other symptoms. There are numerous treatments for PCOS including lifestyle changes, medication, and potentially hormone therapy. Each individual is different so a treatment plan would be tailored around your specific medical history, needs, and goals. The best thing for now is to get in touch with your doctor for further evaluation and advice.

input: Hi doctor,I have a sore throat for the past 15 days. I tried taking all the medicines. But there is no use. I had also done four tests for HIV in this period. I had protected sex. All the results came negative. Why do I have a sore throat? If I am doing another HIV test, do I need to test with the morning blood?
output:
Sore throat has many potential causes, including viral infections like the common cold, bacterial infections like strep throat, smoking or exposure to smoke, allergies, and dry air. It's unlikely that your condition is related to HIV especially with your recent protected sexual encounter and multiple negative test results.

If you've had a persistent sore throat for over two weeks, it could be a sign of a more serious issue. I would recommend seeing an otolaryngologist (an Ear, Nose, Throat doctor) who can perform a detailed evaluation and possibly determine the cause of your persistent sore throat. 

As for your question regarding the timing of the blood draw for HIV tests, there is no specific time that is deemed optimal or necessary for sampling. The important thing is not the time when the sample is taken but the window period: the time between potential exposure to HIV infection and the point when the test will give an accurate result. Most HIV tests are highly accurate after a 4-6 week window period from the time of potential exposure.

Continuous testing might not help here as you have already performed four tests which came back negative in this timeframe. Instead, focus on figuring out other possible causes for your symptoms.

input: Hi doctor, I am taking rabies vaccination. Right now I have completed two doses of my injection. My question is if I get another bite during my vaccination do I have to restart my rabies course from starting or should I continue the same course?
output: No, you don't need to restart the series if you're bitten again. However, you should definitely visit your healthcare provider immediately after any potential exposure to rabies, even if you are in the process of vaccine administration. They would assess the situation and might decide to continue with the schedule or administer additional doses depending on your risk level. Post-exposure prophylaxis may also be recommended which consists of one dose of immune globulin and four doses of rabies vaccine given over a 14-day period. So, while it might not be starting over, there might be additional treatment needed. Always consult your health care provider in these situations.

input: Hello doctor,I have since I can remember, a runny nose, especially in the morning. Not uncommonly there are streaks of blood. Quite often also post-nasal drip. At times, I have itchy runny eyes. My doctor has prescribed an ointment Otocomb which sometimes help. In the past few months, I have noticed a sore in my inside of the left nostril. It feels like it runs neatly along the rise or cartilage. It sometimes forms a scab that I pick at. I am worried that it is not improving.
output:
From your description, it sounds like you could be suffering from something called allergic rhinitis which is an overactive immune response to allergens in the air such as dust, pet dander or pollen. The symptoms often include a runny nose, post-nasal drip and itchy eyes among others.

The nosebleeds can occur due to the constant irritation from blowing or rubbing your nose frequently. Blood-streaked nasal discharge indicates trauma to small blood vessels, most commonly from repeated nose-blowing.

The sore inside your nostril that appears to have formed a scab could also be related to this but might also be due to dryness, especially if you're in a cold climate or using indoor heating which reduces humidity and tends to dry out the nostrils. Repeatedly scratching or picking at this area could make the damage worse and prolong healing time.

However, it's also worth noting that any persistent unhealed sore should warrant further evaluation. If the sore has been there for more than 2-3 weeks, I would recommend seeing an ENT specialist to inspect it and rule out other potential causes, particularly since you describe it forming along the cartilage of your nose.
